questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl with leprosy comes for follow-up. 4 slit skin smears are obtained from her lesions and sent to the laboratory for examination. The following are the findings of the four slides:
  1. 25 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field
  2. 4 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field
  3. 7 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field
  4. 75 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field

What is the bacteriological index of this patient?
questions.solution:
The bacterial index (BI) of this patient according to the Ridley's logarithmic scale is 3.5+.

Bacterial Index (BI) indicates the density of the leprosy bacilli in smears and includes both living and dead bacilli. The living bacilli show solid staining and the dead bacilli show frangmented or granular staining. It is the only method available to monitor the effect of treatment.

According to Ridley's logarithmic scale, it ranges from 0 to 6+. It is based on the number of bacilli seen in an average microscopic field of the smear using an oil-immersion objective. BI is calculated by adding the index from each site examined and dividing the total by the number of sites examined.

In this case,

  • 2 samples with 10-100 bacilli in each oil immersion field implies an index of 4+ on each.
  • 2 samples with 1-10 bacilli in each oil immersion field implies an index of 3+ on each.

Hence, BI = (4+4+3+3) / 4

BI = 14/4

BI = 3.5+

Related Pearl: Ridley's logarithmic scale in determining Bacterial Index

Bacterial Index(BI) indicates the density of the leprosy bacilli in smears and includes both living and dead bacilli.

According to Ridley's logarithmic scale, the range is from 0 to 6+ and is based on the number of bacilli seen in an average microscopic field of the smear using an oil-immersion objective.

0

No bacilli in any of the 100 oil-immersion field

1+

1-10 bacilli, on average, in 100 oil-immersion field

2+

1-10 bacilli, on average, in 10 oil-immersion field

3+

1-10 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field

4+

10-100 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field

5+

100-1000 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field 

6+

More than 1000 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field 

BI is calculated by adding up the index from each site examined and dividing the total by the number of sites examined.

questions.text: A 2-week-old female baby was brought to the clinic with mucopurulent discharge from both eyes. On examination, the eyelids appear swollen and the conjunctiva is erythematous. PCR done on the conjunctival scrapings detected Chlamydia trachomatis.  What would be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette with the time of presentation of symptoms is strongly suggestive of ophthalmia neonatorum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The most appropriate treatment for this condition among the given options is oral erythromycin. 

Ophthalmia neonatorum or neonatal conjunctivitis can be considered as conjunctivitis that develops within the first month of life. The causative agents are Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, Haemophilus influenzae, herpes simplex virus, streptococci, staphylococci, and chemical causes.

Chlamydia is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries and neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis is caused by serotypes D to K.

Clinically, Chlamydia trachomatis inclusion conjunctivitis manifests relatively late, usually over one week and up to three weeks after birth with a mucopurulent discharge, and swelling of the eyelids as shown below.

Diagnosis is usually established by PCR. Conjunctival scrapings may be used to perform a PCR. 

The treatment includes oral erythromycin for two weeks. Topical erythromycin to tetracycline ointment may also be used. 

Other options-

Option A: IM or IV ceftriaxone is used in the treatment of gonococcal neonatal conjunctivitis. It usually presents within the first week of life and is characterized by copious hyperpurulent discharge and severe eyelid edema. Supportive management may include saline irrigation to clear the copious discharge. 

Option B: IV acyclovir is used in the treatment of herpes simplex viral conjunctivitis which presents in one to two weeks with a watery discharge. It is characterized by eyelid and periocular vesicles. A corneal examination may reveal dendritic or geographic epithelial lesions. 

Option D: 1% topical silver nitrate was used as a prophylactic measure to prevent gonococcal neonatal conjunctivitis. However, it is an irritant and causes chemical conjunctivitis in the first few days of life. Hence, conservatively treatment with supportive measures such as artificial tears is preferred.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presented with headache and blurred vision. She is a known case of hypertension. Renal arteriography shows segmental stenosis, resembling a string of beads. Which of the following histological types is most commonly seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a hypertensive woman presenting with headache, blurred vision, and renal artery angiography showing segmental stenosis is suggestive of fibromuscular dysplasia. The most common histological subtype of fibromuscular dysplasia is medial fibroplasia. 

Fibromuscular dysplasia is a hyperplastic disorder characterized by focal irregular thickening in medium and large muscular arteries. It usually involves renal, carotid, iliac, and subclavian arteries. It is predominantly seen in female patients.

Histologically, fibromuscular dysplasia is classified into three main types based on the arterial layer involved:

  • Intimal fibroplasia (focal)
  • Medial dysplasia (multifocal). It is further subdivided into:
    • Medial fibroplasia (most common)
    • Perimedial fibroplasia
    • Medial hyperplasia
  • Adventitial hyperplasia

Medial fibroplasia is the most common type. It is characterized by regions of thick fibrodysplastic media alternating with regions of thinned media. In the renal arteries, this can be a cause of renovascular hypertension. 

On angiography, the vessels are said to have a “string of beads” appearance as shown below:

questions.text: A 28-year-old was on antitubercular therapy (ATT). Which of the following drugs used in ATT causes anterior uveitis when used in high doses along with clarithromycin?
questions.solution:
Rifabutin causes anterior uveitis when used along with clarithromycin.

Rifamycins are macrocyclic antibiotics used in the treatment of mycobacterial diseases. Three rifamycins described are:

  1. Rifampicin
  2. Rifabutin
  3. Rifapentine

The side effects of rifabutin are:

  • Rash, GI intolerance, neutropenia
  • Uveitis and arthralgias with doses greater than 450 mg daily in combination with clarithromycin or fluconazole.
  • Orange-tan discoloration of skin, urine, feces, saliva, tears, and contact lenses.
  • Unique side effects include polymyalgia, pseudojaundice, and anterior uveitis.

Other Options:

Option A - Ethambutol causes side effects like optic neuritis with loss of red-green vision.

Option C - Rifampicin causes side effects like flu-like symptoms, orange color to urine, sweat, and tears, light chain proteinuria, hepatitis, teratogenicity, rashes, thrombocytopenia, and interstitial nephritis.

Option D - Isoniazid causes side effects like fever, skin rashes, drug-induced lupus, isoniazid-induced hepatitis, and peripheral neuropathy that occurs in slow acetylators.

questions.text: A study was conducted on an experimental animal to demonstrate the change in breathing patterns with transections at different levels of the brainstem. Which of the following breathing pattern is most likely observed with a complete transection at midway between pons and medulla?

choices.text: Regular breathing continues but depth of inspiration increases

questions.solution:
The most likely breathing pattern in the above scenario is irregular but rhythmic respiration.

Pre Botzinger complex in the medulla is responsible for rhythmic respiration. The pnuemotaxic center in the pons further modifies this rhythmic discharge and plays a role in switching between inspiration and expiration. So a complete transection at midway between pons and medulla causes irregular but rhythmic respiration.

 Respiratory centers of the brain:

  • Pre-Botzinger complex- This produces rhythmic and automatic respiration. Therefore damage to the medulla results in loss of spontaneous respiration.
  • Pneumotaxic centers- The rhythmic discharge produced by the pre-Botziger complex is further modified by the pneumotaxic centers. Stimulation of the pneumotaxic center results in an increase in the respiratory rate and a decrease in the tidal volume. 
  • Vagus nerve- Stretching of the lung initiates impulses in the pulmonary vagal fibers. These signals inhibit further inspiration. Therefore in vagotomy, the inspiration has not inhibited this results in increased depth of inspiration. There will also be prolonged inspiratory spasms that resemble breath-holding (apneusis)

Other options:

Option B- Apneusis occurs in a transection through mid pontine level with vagotomy.

Option C- Spontaneous respiration ceases in a complete transection through the medulla.

Option D- Regular breathing with deep inspiration occurs in complete transection above the pons.

Related Pearl: Effects of Various Lesions and Brainstem Transections

Level of transection

Vagi cut

Regular breathing continues

Regular breathing continues but depth of inspiration increases

B

Regular breathing continues

C

questions.text: A newborn baby was brought to the dermatology department. His mother says blisters are formed at the site of handling as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the above condition is epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

A newborn with trauma-related bullae and vesicles at the site of handling over knees and feet points towards the diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

Epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS) is a type of blistering disease. It occurs due to the mutation in the keratin gene (KRT5 or KRT14) encoding for keratin 5 or 14 expressed in the basal cell layer. This mutation causes the production of defective intermediate filaments. This makes epidermal basal cells fragile and subsequently causes blisters on physical pressure. The separation in EBS is within the epidermis (basal cell layer). 

The child is affected at birth and caregivers present the baby with blisters on the hands, elbows, feet, and ankle. More blisters will appear as the baby starts crawling. 

Epidermolysis bullosa is a group of mechano-bullous diseases in which blisters develop in areas of mechanical trauma. There are three types of epidermolysis bullosa:

  • Epidermolysis bullosa simplex -  defect in K5/K14.
  • Junctional epidermolysis bullosa -  defect in laminin.
  • Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa -  defect in collagen-7.

Other options:

Option B- Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by large, tense subepidermal bullae in the groin, axilla, and flexors of the forearm. Most frequently they occur in the elderly population.

Option C- Pemphigus foliaceus is characterized by flaccid bullae. They rupture as soon as they appear and crusting occurs. Most frequently they occur in adults of age 40 to 50 years. It shows positive Nikolsky sign.

Option D- Cicatricial pemphigoid is also known as mucous membrane pemphigoid. It is characterized by vesicles that rupture quickly and form ulcers. These are usually seen in mucous membranes like conjunctiva and oral mucosa. Most frequently they occur in older women.

Related Pearl: Classification of Vesiculobullous Disorders

questions.text: A first-year MBBS student came to OPD with intermittent episodes of a feeling of impending doom accompanied by intense perspiration. Usually, the episodes occur prior to her exams. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient is panic disorder.

A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort. Recurrent panic attacks for more than one month is classified as panic disorder.

Panic attacks can occur in mental disorders other than panic disorder, particu­larly in specific phobia, social phobia, and PTSD.

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
1. Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about an additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

Immediate: Benzodiazepines
Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias

during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.

anxiety disorder (Social phobia)

Generalized anxiety disorder

a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.

  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding kidney transplantation from a live donor.

choices.text: Donor's renal artery is end-to-end anastomosed  with internal iliac artery
Donor's renal vein is end-to-end anastomosed  with internal iliac vein
It is a type of orthotopic organ transplantation
The maximum safe cold storage time is 18 hours

questions.solution:
In a live donor kidney transplantation, the donor's renal artery is end-to-end anastomosed with the internal iliac artery.

In the kidney transplant,

  • The renal vein is anastomosed end-to-side to the external iliac vein.
  • In the case of a cadaveric donor, the renal artery is anastomosed end-to-side to the external iliac artery.
  • In the case of a living donor, as the renal artery lacks an aortic patch, it may be preferable to anastomose the donor artery end-to-end to the recipient's internal iliac artery.

The below image shows the different types of anastomosis in kidney transplantation from live and deceased donors.

The iliac fossa, in the retroperitoneal position, is the usual site for kidney transplantation making it a heterotopic type of transplantation. The diseased kidney is left in situ.

The optimal cold storage time for the kidney is 18 hours and the maximum safe cold storage time for the kidney is 36 hours.

Optimal and maximum safe cold storage time for various organs are as follows:

Organs Optimal time(hours) Maximum time(hours)
1) Kidney <18 <36
2) Liver <12 <18
3) Pancreas <10 <18
4) Small intestine <4 <6
5) Heart <3 <6
6) Lungs <3 <8

 

In orthotopic graft/transplantation, the graft is placed in its normal anatomical site. However, in heterotopic graft/transplantation, the graft is placed at a site different from its normal anatomical site.

questions.text: A 22-year-old girl enquires if there are any surgical options for the correction of her myopia. She does not wish to wear her glasses or switch to contact lenses. What is the minimum time frame for which her refractive error has to be stable before laser assisted in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK) can be considered?
questions.solution:
The patient's refractive error has to be stable for a minimum period of at least 1 year before undergoing laser-assisted in-situ keratomileusis. (LASIK).

Myopia also known as shortsightedness is a refractive error in which parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused in front of the retina with the accommodation at rest. 

Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) is performed using excimer laser. It is the commonly done surgery for myopia. Excimer laser beam reshapes the cornea by ablating the superficial stroma to a predetermined extent after lifting a flap of the cornea with a sharp microkeratome. 

Patient selection criteria:

  • In individuals aged 21 years and above.
  • In individuals who have a stable refractive error for at least 1 year.
  • In individuals who have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment.
  • In individuals in whom corneal-thinning disorders such as keratoconus have been ruled out.

Complications:

  • Tear instability (dry eye)
  • Wrinkling, distortion, or dislocation of the flap
  • Subepithelial haze with resultant glare, especially at night.
  • Persistent epithelial defects.
  • Epithelial ingrowth under the flap.
  • Diffuse lamellar keratitis (sands of the Sahara)
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Keratoconus

Related Pearl: Surgical correction of Myopia

Cornea-based procedures Lens-based procedures

Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK)

Laser in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK)(Most common)

questions.text: A patient files a case in the district consumer court alleging medical negligence. If he wins the case, what would be the maximum compensation that this court can dispense?
questions.solution:
If the patient wins the case in the district consumer court, the maximum compensation that can be given is upto Rs. 50 lakhs.

A complaint against the medical professional can be filed in the consumer court. It should contain all the details of the case, an expert certificate or opinion from the doctor of the concerned speciality. It should state the complaint is prima facie true and needs further investigation. It should also specify the amount demanded.

According to the Consumer Protection Act, 2021, these courts can only give compensation. The monetary limits of the compensation that can be granted by the consumer courts are

  • District Consumer Court - up to Rs. 50 lakhs
  • State Commission - Rs. 50 lakhs to Rs. 2 crore
  • National Commission - above Rs. 2 crore

Note: The MCQ has been updated according to the latest Consumer Protection Act (2021). The monetary limits of the compensation that was granted by the consumer courts according to the Consumer Protection Act, 1986 were

  • District Consumer Court - up to Rs. 20 lakhs
  • State Commission - Rs. 20 lakhs to Rs. 1 crore
  • National Commission - above Rs. 1 crore

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought with a soft, compressible swelling at the root of the nose. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of isolated solitary mass arising from the root of the nose should raise the index of suspicion of nasal meningocele or meningoencephalocele. It is the herniation of brain tissue along with its meninges through a congenital bony defect.

Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. It presents as a cystic, bluish, compressible, translucent mass at the root of the nose (nasofrontal variety), side of the nose (nasoethmoid variety), or at the anteromedial aspect of the orbit (nasoorbital variety).

Furstenberg's test: compression of the ipsilateral internal jugular vein usually causes an encephalocele to enlarge.

Investigation: CT or MRI.

Treatment: Transnasal endoscopic excision with the closure of the defect using bone or cartilage graft along with temporalis fascia and fat.

questions.text: A 35-year-male patient presents to the surgery outpatient unit with a history of blunt force trauma to the right side of the neck. He complains of an inability to comb his hair with his right hand. On examination, lateral winging of the scapula is noted on the right side. There is no difficulty in turning the head to the left side. The cause of his presentation is due to damage to the __________ nerve present in ____________ area of neck.
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes an injury to the spinal accessory nerve present in the occipital triangle which is a part of the posterior triangle of the neck.

The spinal accessory nerve has 2 roots: a cranial root that arises from the postolivary groove of the dorsolateral medulla and a spinal root that arises from the cervical segment of the spinal cord. The spinal root ascends the vertebral canal and passes through the foramen magnum to join the cranial root in the skull. The bundle of cranial and spinal roots divide into internal and external branches after leaving the jugular foramen. The external branch descends into the neck and while entering the occipital triangle, it pierces the sternocleidomastoid muscle supplying the muscle. It travels through the occipital triangle and reaches up to the trapezius and ends there. 

If the spinal accessory nerve is injured in the occipital triangle, the sternocleidomastoid will be spared but the trapezius will be affected resulting in :

  • Difficulty in overhead abduction
  • Difficulty in shrugging of shoulders
  • Lateral winging of the scapula
  • No difficulty in turning the head to the opposite side (due to sparing of sternocleidomastoid muscle)

 The posterior triangle of the neck is further subdivided into the occipital triangle and supraclavicular triangle.

Contents of the occipital triangle:

  • Occipital artery, branch of external carotid artery
  • Transverse cervical vessels
  • Spinal accessory nerve
  • Cutaneous and muscular branches of cervical plexus
  • Uppermost part of the brachial plexus
  • Supraclavicular nerve

Contents of the supraclavicular triangle:

  • Trunks of the brachial plexus
  • Nerve to subclavius
  • Supraclavicular nerves
  • Subclavian vessels 

Other options:

The long thoracic nerve arises from branches of the ventral primary rami of C5, C6 and C7. The trunk of the nerve passes posterolateral to the scalenus medius muscle, on the floor of the posterior triangle deep to the suprascapular nerve. It innervates the serratus anterior muscle. Due to its long course, the long thoracic nerve is susceptible to injury.

Winging of the scapula can be caused by paralysis of the serratus anterior or trapezius. It causes an inability to lift, pull and push heavy objects due to loss of power and limited flexion and abduction of the upper limb. Medial winging of scapula occurs in serratus anterior paralysis (long thoracic nerve injury) and lateral winging of scapula occurs in trapezius paralysis (spinal accessory nerve injury). 

The below image shows winging of the scapula due to trapezius paralysis.

The below image shows winging of scapula due to serratus anterior paralysis.

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text: A man was stuck inside a building that caught fire. He died of suffocation due to smoke. Burn injuries were minimal. Which of the following postmortem changes is likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
The person died of suffocation due to smoke. This indicates carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning, which causes cherry-red postmortem hypostasis.

Victims of smoke inhalation are affected by carbon monoxide poisoning. Carbon monoxide has a higher affinity to haemoglobin as compared to oxygen and hence the amount of haemoglobin available for oxygen transport is markedly reduced. It can cause anaemic hypoxia. The binding of CO to haemoglobin results in cherry-red discolouration.

Other options:

Option A- Greenish-blue postmortem hypostasis is seen in poisoning due to hydrogen sulphide poisoning.

Option B- Pugilistic attitude is seen when muscle proteins are coagulated at high temperatures. Since this person did not die of burn injuries, a pugilistic attitude will not be seen.

Option D- Rigor mortis is not delayed. On the contrary, it may have a rapid onset because of heat.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient, who is on chronic antiarrhythmic drug therapy, presents with hypotension, photosensitivity, and cold intolerance. He also complains of difficulty in getting up from the squatting position. Pulmonary function tests revealed a restrictive pattern of lung disease.  What is the most likely drug implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The most likely drug implicated in this scenario is amiodarone. Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug.

Amiodarone is used to convert atrial fibrillation and to slow ventricular rate in the treatment of tachyarrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardias, paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), and recurrent VF. It is also used in the treatment of cardiac arrest if epinephrine therapy is not effective.

The clinical spectrum of hypotension; photosensitivity; cold intolerance, which is indicative of hypothyroidism; difficulty in getting up from the squatting position indicative of proximal muscle weakness; and restrictive pattern on PFT, which is indicative of pulmonary fibrosis are all side effects of amiodarone.

The other significant side effects of amiodarone include the following:

  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Optic neuritis
  • Abnormal liver function tests
  • Peripheral neuropathy

The below image shows skin pigmentation in a patient due to prolonged amiodarone therapy.

Other options:

Option A - The side effects of adenosine are short-lived due to rapid transport into the cell and deamination. The side effects seen are transient asystole, transient dyspnea, and rarely transient atrial fibrillation.

Option B - The side effects of digoxin are common and include GI symptoms, visual and cognitive dysfunction, and arrhythmias, typically atrial tachycardia with AV block. Other arrhythmias that can occur are ventricular bigeminy, bidirectional ventricular tachycardia—a rare entity—and AV junctional tachycardias.

Option C - The side effects of quinidine are diarrhea, diarrhea-induced hypokalemia, marked QT prolongation, and a high risk of torsades de pointes at therapeutic or subtherapeutic concentrations. Cinchonism is a syndrome associated with quinidine intake, which includes symptoms of headache and tinnitus.

questions.text: A study was conducted in a village to evaluate the effects of water fluoridation on dental health. Which of the following categories of studies does this study belong to?
questions.solution:
A study to evaluate the effect of water fluoridation on dental health is categorized as a community intervention study.

To evaluate the effect of interventions on health outcomes within a group that may be defined geographically like a city or village or socially like a workplace or school, we use community interventions studies. Community intervention studies come under experimental studies.

All the other options mentioned above are analytical studies.

Classification of epidemiological studies:

Observational studies:

  1. Descriptive studies
  2. Analytical studies:
    • Ecological studies or correlational studies
    • Cross-sectional or prevalence studies
    • Case-control or case-reference studies
    • Cohort or follow-up studies

Experimental studies or intervention studies:

  1. Randomized controlled trials or clinical trials
  2. Field trials
  3. Community trials or community intervention studies

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).

questions.text: A 23 year old  presented with fever, myalgia, and skin lesion as shown in the image. What is the causative organism for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows erythema migrans, seen in Lyme disease. It is caused by Borrelia Burgdoferi. 

The lesion has a target center with partial central clearing and a  bright red outer border. It usually begins as a red macule or papule at the site of the tick bite.

The tick implicated is the black-legged tick, Ixodes scapularis, shown in the image below.

Lyme disease has three stages of the disease:

  • Early localized stage is characterized by an erythema migrans(EM) rash, a characteristic "bull's-eye" rash. Patients can also have fatigue, fever, chills, headache, muscle and joint aches, and swollen lymph nodes.
  • Early disseminated stage is characterized by multiple EM Rashes and neurological Symptoms such as facial palsy (Bell’s palsy). Patients can also have cardiac symptoms such as Lyme carditis with features of heart block. There can also be migratory joint pain and swelling, often affecting large joints like the knees.
  • Late features include neurological manifestations including peripheral neuropathy, encephalopathy, and persistent joint pains. 

Related Pearl: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.

 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.

 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text:
A male patient came with complaints of fatigue, weakness, and irritability for a few weeks. He was on antitubercular drugs for the past 1 month. The laboratory investigations are given below. The most likely diagnosis is :
  • Hemoglobin - Reduced
  • Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) - Reduced
  • Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) - Raised
  • Serum ferritin - Raised
  • Serum iron - Raised
  • Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) - Normal
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is sideroblastic anemia. 

The following are the points given in the question pointing to this diagnosis: 

  • Symptoms of anemia - fatigue, weakness
  • History of taking anti-tubercular drugs (isoniazid)
  • Laboratory investigations showing - reduced MCH, raised MCV, raised serum iron, raised serum ferritin, and normal TIBC 

Isoniazid has a pyridoxine antagonistic action, which results in defective heme synthesis. Pyridoxine acts as a cofactor of the aminolevulinic acid (ALA) synthetase enzyme, which is the rate-limiting enzyme in heme synthesis. Isoniazid-induced sideroblastic anemia is a rare condition due to defective heme synthesis.

Sideroblastic anemia is a group of disorders characterized by the presence of sideroblasts. Sideroblasts are nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing non-heme siderotic granules and stain Prussian blue positive. Based on etiology, sideroblastic anemia is classified into hereditary and acquired types.

Hereditary sideroblastic anemia: 

It is an X-linked disorder caused by a defect in the activity of ALA synthetase required for heme synthesis. Affected females act as carriers, but males have moderate to marked anemia, which manifests in childhood or early adulthood.

Acquired sideroblastic anemia: This is further divided into - 

1) Primary acquired/idiopathic/refractory - it is regarded as a myelodysplastic disorder in the FAB classification. It occurs in middle-aged and elderly individuals of both sexes. This occurs due to the reduced activity of the ALA synthetase enzyme. This furthermore causes disturbed growth and maturation of the erythroid precursors (hematopoietic stem cells). Anaemia is moderate to severe and appears gradually.

2) Secondary Acquired - may occur secondary to - 

  • Drugs, chemicals, and toxins - isoniazid, alcohol, and lead
  • Hematological disorders - myelofibrosis, acute leukemia, lymphoma, and hemolytic anemia.
  • Miscellaneous - inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus.

Peripheral smear in sideroblastic anemia shows hypochromic microcytic (sometimes normocytic) anemia. MCH and MCV are reduced in the hereditary type and raised in the acquired type. Serum ferritin and serum iron are raised, and TIBC shows complete saturation. Bone marrow examination shows erythroid hyperplasia with pathognomonic ring sideroblasts, as shown below.

Pyridoxine for 2-3 months is administered routinely to all cases of sideroblastic anemia. Blood transfusion and other supportive therapy may be required. In cases of secondary sideroblastic anemia, the primary focus is the removal of the offending agent.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who was previously diagnosed with an ovarian fibroma presents with gradually progressive abdominal distension, cough, breathlessness, and pleuritic chest pain on the right side. On examination, the abdomen is distended, and fluid thrill is present. Chest x-ray shows a right-sided pleural effusion. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the triad of benign ovarian fibroma, right-sided pleural effusion, and ascites are suggestive of Meigs syndrome.

The following triad of features favors the diagnosis:

  • Gradual progressive distension of abdomen, positive fluid thrill – points towards ascites.
  • Cough on lying to the right side, breathlessness, chest pain on the right side, chest X-ray – point towards right-sided pleural effusion.
  • Diagnosis of ovarian fibroma– benign ovarian tumor.

Meigs syndrome is mostly caused by ovarian fibroma. CA-125 levels may also be elevated. As it is a diagnosis of exclusion, a workup should be done to rule out malignancy. Exploratory laparotomy with surgical staging is the treatment of choice. Conservative surgery (salpingo-oophorectomy) is done. The clinical features resolve on resection of the fibroma.

Other options: 

Option B: Pseudo-Meigs syndrome, which presents with ascites and pleural effusion in association with benign tumors of the ovary (other than fibromas). Other features may include fibroids/leiomyoma, secondary metastatic tumors to the ovary, Brenners tumors, and benign ovarian cysts (such as struma ovarii, mucinous cystadenoma, and teratomas).

Option C: Pseudo-pseudo Meigs syndrome is a manifestation of SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus) defined by ascites, pleural effusion, and elevated CA-125 levels.

Option D: Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome occurs as a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhea. It is characterized by the inflammation of the peritoneum and the tissues surrounding the liver (perihepatitis). Symptoms include sudden onset of severe pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, fever, chills, and malaise.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman who is a known case of neurofibromatosis type 2 presented with a headache for a few days and  2 episodes of seizures. MRI brain shows a tumor. The biopsy of the tumor specimen is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of headache, seizures, and histopathology showing the syncytial or whorled clusters of epithelial tumour cells in a female patient of neurofibromatosis type 2 is highly suggestive of meningioma.

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumours, usually attached to the dura. They are predominantly seen in females and in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2, which is an autosomal disorder associated with multiple meningiomas, schwannomas, and ependymomas.

They arise from the meningothelial cells or arachnoid cap cells. The most common karyotypic abnormality is the loss of the long arm of chromosome 22. Meningiomas often express hormone receptors (eg: Progesterone), hence, they may grow rapidly in pregnancy.

Meningiomas are rubbery, rounded, or bosselated dural masses. They compress the underlying brain tissue. They present with headaches, seizures, or focal neurological deficits. 

The tumour spreads in a sheet-like manner along the surface of the dura causing reactive hyperostotic changes in adjacent bones. They are mostly located in cerebral convexities. The lesions may be finely gritty due to numerous psammomatous calcifications. 

Grades of meningioma based on histologic subtypes by WHO are:

Grade I is the benign meningioma that has a relatively low risk of recurrence or aggressive growth. The histologic patterns are:

  • Meningothelial or syncytial (most common). They are clusters of epitheliod tumour cells that sit in tight groups without visible cell membranes as shown below.
  • Fibroblastic
  • Transitional
  • Psammomatous

The image below shows a meningothelial or syncytial pattern:

 

Grade II is the atypical meningioma which has a high recurrence rate and more aggressive local growth. Histologic patterns are clear cell and chordoid. 

Grade III is the anaplastic or malignant meningioma is highly aggressive often resembling carcinoma or sarcoma. Histologic patterns are papillary and rhabdoid.

The image below shows a well-defined, hyper-intense, and homogeneously enhanced mass close to the midline suggestive of meningioma.

 

When the meningiomas are small and asymptomatic, observation with serial MRI studies is done. When larger and symptomatic, they should be excised. External beam radiotherapy is done for unresectable tumours.

Other options:

Option B- Schwannomas are benign tumours arising from the Schwann cells. Acoustic or vestibular schwannoma arising from the vestibular portion of the eighth nerve is the most common schwannoma. Histopathologically they are composed of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B respectively. In Antoni A area, a central nuclear-free area ramified by palisading nuclei is termed as Verocay bodies. Schwannomas are associated with NF2, but they typically arise from the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII), leading to hearing loss and balance problems, not headaches and seizures. 

The image below shows the histology of schwannoma.

Option C- Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumour seen predominantly in children. Histopathologically Homer Wright rosettes formed by tumour cells are seen as shown below.

Option D- Oligodendroglioma arises from the glial cells. A histopathologically delicate network of anastomosing capillaries resembling chicken wire is seen as shown below.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A drug having a half-life of 8 hours is administered orally thrice daily. How much time will be taken for the plasma concentration to reach a steady state?
questions.solution:
The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives. As the half-life of the given drug is 8 hours, so it will take 32-40 hours to reach a steady state. Hence, 36 hours will be the most appropriate answer.

Steady-state: The amount of drug administered is equal to the amount of drug eliminated within one dosing interval resulting in a plateau or constant drug plasma concentration, with the plasma concentration fluctuating between a minimum and maximum.

The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives.

Drugs with a shorter half-life reach a steady state rapidly, whereas drugs with longer half-life take days to weeks to attain a steady state.

Steady-state concentration (Css) = F x Dosing rate/ CL

  • where dosing rate is the dose per time interval and is dose/T
  • F is the fractional bioavailability, CL is clearance.

In the case of intravenous infusion,

Steady-state concentration (Css) = Rate of infusion/ CL

Pharmacokinetics of repeated drug dosing:

Plasma concentration of the drug will increase, reach a maximum, and decline after the first dose. A second dose will be administered before the first dose is completely eliminated. Consequently, the plasma concentration resulting from the second dose will be higher than from the first dose.

This increase in plasma concentration of the drug will occur continuously on repeated dosing (drug accumulation occurs) until a steady state at which drug elimination is equal to drug administration is reached. This is known as the plateau principle of drug accumulation.

A graph is plotted between plasma drug concentration and time as shown below. The given graph depicts the plateau principle of drug accumulation on repeated oral dosing.

questions.text: You were assisting an emergency abdominal laparotomy. At the end of the surgery, the surgeon asked you to perform abdominal wall closure. Which of the following suture materials would be ideal for abdominal wall closure?
questions.solution:
Polydioxanone is an ideal suture material for abdominal wall closure.

Polydioxanone is a slowly absorbing monofilament suture. Since they are monofilament sutures, they can resist infection than braided multifilament sutures. They also have the longer tensile strength to prevent abdominal wall disruption.

An ideal suture material for abdominal wall closure should:

  • Resist infection
  • Provide adequate tensile strength to prevent abdominal wall disruption
  • Reduce tissue damage
  • Be an absorbable material

Other options:

Option A- Polyglactin is an absorbable braided multifilament suture. It has less tensile strength and absorption time as compared with polydioxanone. It is also less resistant to infection then polydiaxone.

Option C and Option D - Both polypropylene and polyester are non-absorbable sutures. They have been associated with post-surgical sinus track formation and increased pain. Polypropylene can also be used for abdominal wall closure but it is not ideal.

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals the following finding. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. What is the most common cause of this condition in such patients?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with a positive Kernig's sign, is suggestive of meningitis. Cryptococcus is the leading infectious cause of meningitis in patients with AIDS. It generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL.            

Most patients present with a picture of subacute meningoencephalitis. The CSF profile may show modest elevations in WBC or protein levels and decrease in glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated (yeast colonies obstruct the free flow of CSF causing increased CSF pressure).

The diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made by identification of Cryptococcus neoformans yeast cells in CSF with india ink stain or by the detection of cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination (CrAg).

Prophylaxis: Oral fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/μL.

Treatment:

  • Induction - IV or liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, continuing with amphotericin alone ideally until the CSF culture turns negative.
  • Maintenance -  Oral fluconazole until the CD4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/μL for 6 months in response to cART.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with pruritic hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest as seen in the image. Which of the following color would you expect on Wood's lamp examination?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of pruritic lesions over the trunk and image showing sharply demarcated multiple hypopigmented macules coalescing into patches with fine scales is suggestive of pityriasis versicolor or tinea versicolor. On Wood's lamp examination, these lesions show pale yellow fluorescence. 

Wood's lamp is a source of ultraviolet rays. All visible rays from this source are excluded by Wood's filter. In fungal infections like pityriasis versicolor, it shows the pale yellow fluorescence as given below.

Pityriasis versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales. Azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species competitively inhibits tyrosinase and results in hypopigmentation.

The most commonly affected site is the upper trunk, but it often spreads to the upper arms, neck, and abdomen. Occasionaly it presents as pruritic lesion. The color of the scales may vary from pale ochre to medium brown, and so the term versicolor. Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur.

The image below shows the scales seen in Tinea versicolor.

The characteristic appearance on KOH mount and microscopy has been likened to ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes’. 

Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail) is an important diagnostic clue when the scales are not visible. Here the barely perceptible scales are made to stand out by scratching the lesion with fingernails.

Patients are treated with topical azoles or 1% terbinafine cream twice daily for 2 to 3 weeks or ketoconazole shampoo twice weekly for the same duration. Relapse is very common. 

Other options:

Option A: Coral pink fluorescence is seen in erythrasma.

Option B: Red fluorescence is seen in squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

Option D: Green fluorescence is seen in tinea capitis infections associated with Microspora species and favus.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Tinea capitis

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy with recurrent hemarthrosis was found to have deficiency of factor VIII. He was adopted and his family history is unknown. What is the inheritance pattern of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hemophilia A. It is an X-linked recessive disorder.

Hemophilia is of two types:

  • Hemophilia A - due to mutations in the F8 gene leading to factor VIII deficiency 
  • Hemophilia B - due to mutations in the F9 gene leading to factor IX deficiency

Affected children often present with prolonged bleeding after procedures like circumcision or major bleeds like intracranial hemorrhages. When the child begins to walk, bleeding into the joint (hemarthrosis) may occur, causing painful swellings and reddening. 

Laboratory investigations show elevated aPTT, with normal PT and platelet count. It is treated by the administration of factor VIII or factor IX concentrates.

questions.text: You have been asked to perform fundoscopy by your senior resident in one of his patients diagnosed with hypermetropia. Which of the following options represent the findings that could be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Shot silk appearance with pseudopapillitis can be seen on fundal examination of the hypermetropic eye.

Hypermetropia is a refractive error of the eye in which parallel rays of light from infinity focus behind the retina when accommodation is at rest. Fundoscopy findings in hypermetropia include shot silk appearance (retina may shine due to the greater brilliance of light reflections) and pseudopapillitis (optic disc is small, hypervascular, with ill-defined margins without disc edema).

Other signs of hypermetropia include small eyeball, small cornea and short anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

Convex lens (plus lens) is used for the correction of hypermetropia.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old child weighing 40 Kg involved in a fire accident presented to the emergency room with 40% TBSA third-degree burns. What is the rate of initial fluid resuscitation required in this patient?

TBSA-Total body surface area

choices.text: 0.8 L over 8 hours, followed by 0.8 L over 16 hours
1.6 L over 8 hours, followed by 1.6 L over 16 hours
2.4 L over 8 hours, followed by 2.4 L over 16 hours
3.2 L over 8 hours, followed by 3.2 L over 16 hours

questions.solution:
The rate of initial fluid resuscitation required in this patient is 2.4 L over 8 hours, followed by 2.4 L over 16 hours.

As per the recent update in Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) 10th edition (2018),  the fluid resuscitation in a pediatric patient < 14 years age is:

Percentage of burn x body weight (kg) x 3 = volume in ml

In this case, (percentage of burn) 40 x (body weight in kg) 40 x 3 = 4800ml

The volume in ml is 4800. Therefore volume in liters is 4.8 liters.

Half of the fluid is given in the first 8 hours of burns and the rest half in the next 16 hours.

Hence 2.4 litres has to be given in the first 8 hours, followed by 2.4 litres in the next 16 hours. 

#RecentUpdate: The initial fluid rate used for burns resuscitation has been updated by the American Burn Association to reflect concerns about over-resuscitation when using the traditional Parkland formula. According to the 10th Edition of ATLS (2018), fluid resuscitation in a pediatric patient < 14 years should begin at 3 ml of lactated Ringer’s x patient’s body weight in kg x % TBSA for second and third-degree burns. 

Note:

  • The superficial/1st-degree burns are not considered for the formula. Only the % TBSA of 2nd and 3rd-degree burns is calculated for the formula.
  • If the patient is < 1 year or < 30 kg body weight, then the fluid resuscitation will be 3 ml of lactated Ringer's lactate x patient's body weight in kg x % TBSA along with 5% dextrose at a maintenance rate.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: A mother brings her 10-year-old girl to the clinic with concerns regarding the girl's short height. On examination, the child has a short and wide neck, broad chest, and widely spaced nipples. A murmur is heard on auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely congenital heart defect seen in such patients?
questions.solution:
Physical findings of short stature, short and wide neck, broad chest, and widely spaced nipples are strongly suggestive of Turner’s syndrome. Among the given options, the congenital heart defect most likely to be found in patients with Turner’s syndrome is the bicuspid aortic valve.

Turner’s syndrome is characterized by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome (45, XO). It is associated with various phenotypic features including cubitus valgus, congenital hip dislocation, and low posterior hairline in addition to the features mentioned above.

Congenital heart defects and renal anomalies are common in such patients. It is also associated with primary amenorrhea and a lack of secondary sexual characteristics. The gonads are generally streaks of fibrous tissue (gonadal dysgenesis). Most patients tend to be of normal intelligence although intellectual disability is seen in a few cases.

Other options:

Option A: Atrial septal defects, ventricular septal defects, and complete atrioventricular canal defects are more common in Down’s syndrome.

Option B: Mitral valve prolapse is more common in connective tissue disorders such as Marfan’s and Ehler-Danlos syndromes.

Option C: Endocardial cushion defects are the most common congenital heart defects present in Down’s syndrome.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman undergoing surgery was intubated after administering rocuronium for neuromuscular blockade. Before anesthesia induction, a mechanosensor was incorporated with electrodes, as shown in the image below. The contraction of which muscle does it assess to monitor neuromuscular activity?
questions.solution:
The mechanosensor with electrodes is placed over the region of the ulnar nerve, thus assessing the contraction of the adductor pollicis muscle to monitor neuromuscular activity.

Monitoring of neuromuscular blockade is required to monitor the blockade intraoperatively, ensure its complete reversal postoperatively, and prevent residual blockade. To monitor the neuromuscular function, a peripheral motor nerve is supramaximally stimulated and the response of the muscle is assessed.

The most commonly assessed nerve-muscle unit is the ulnar nerve-adductor pollicis muscle. This is because it is easily accessible, has the lowest risk of direct muscle stimulation, and the response can be evaluated tactilely, visually, or by objective methods. To stimulate the ulnar nerve, the electrodes are best applied to the volar aspect of the wrist.

Other nerve-muscle units that can be assessed include:

  • Posterior tibial nerve-flexor hallucis brevis muscle
  • Facial nerve-orbicularis oculi muscle
  • Facial nerve-corrugator supercilii muscle

Many methods can be used for objective monitoring of neuromuscular function:

  • Mechanomyography (MMG)
  • Electromyography (EMG)
  • Acceleration of the muscle response (AMG)
  • Kinemyography (KMG)
  • Cuff pressure modality (CPM)
  • Compressomyography (CMG)
  • Phonomyography (PMG)

The image shows AMG, which is based on Newton’s second law: force = mass × acceleration. It measures the isotonic acceleration of the stimulated muscle.

questions.text: The nucleus indicated by the arrow shown in the longitudinal section of the nerve fibers in the image belongs to ______
questions.solution:
The image shows the nucleus of Schwann cells.

Nerve fibers (axons) in the peripheral nervous system may be myelinated or unmyelinated. The myelin sheath surrounding the myelinated nerve fibers is provided by the Schwann cells. The cytoplasm and the nucleus of the Schwann cells are pushed to the periphery. Since each axon is surrounded by myelin sheaths provided by several axons, on H&E staining, several nuclei of these Schwann cells appear as basophilic structures on either side of the axon along its length.

Other options:

  • In the question, it is already mentioned that the given section is of the nerve fiber. However, in case it is not mentioned, on H&E stain the smooth muscle cells appear spindle-shaped, with a centrally placed, elongated nucleus.
  • The fibroblasts may be seen in the perineurium or endoneurium surrounding the bundles of nerve fibers. They are elongated and stain denser than the nuclei of Schwann cells.
  • The dorsal root ganglion consists of cell bodies of the neurons, with satellite cells.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the hospital with complaints of fever and sore throat. On clinical examination, there is a right side upper jugular lymphadenopathy on palpation. What is the level of this lymph node?
questions.solution:
The upper jugular group of lymph nodes corresponds to level two neck lymph nodes.

questions.text: A patient is being administered flumazenil to reverse benzodiazepine anesthesia. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to administer this drug?
questions.solution:
Continuous infusion of flumazenil is needed to reverse benzodiazepine anesthesia. This is because flumazenil has a short half-life of 1 hour.

Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site of the GABAA receptor. It antagonizes both the agonist (benzodiazepines) and inverse-agonist (beta-carbolines) of this receptor.

To maintain a constant therapeutic blood level over a prolonged time, either repeated administration or a continuous infusion is necessary.

The duration of clinical effects usually is only 30–60 min. It is absorbed rapidly after oral administration, less than a quarter of the drug reaches the systemic circulation. This is due to the extensive first-pass hepatic metabolism. Flumazenil is eliminated almost entirely by hepatic metabolism to inactive products with a t1/2 of about 1 hour.

It is primarily indicated for the management of benzodiazepine overdose and the reversal of benzodiazepine anesthesia.

Flumazenil is only available for intravenous administration. It reliably reverses the sedation, respiratory depression, and amnesia caused by benzodiazepines.

It can also be used to diagnose benzodiazepine dependence. It has also been used successfully to reverse the effects of chloral hydrate and cannabis intoxication in children, carbamazepine and alcohol overdose, and antihistamines overdose.

In patients using large doses of benzodiazepines over long periods, the administration of flumazenil may precipitate the symptoms of benzodiazepine withdrawal, including seizures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with intermittent blood in the urine and pain in the left flank. He is a chronic smoker. On examination, the patient appears weak and has a palpable mass in the left flank. CT shows a renal tumor. A radical nephrectomy was performed and the histology of the specimen is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and histology specimen showing round or polygonal tumor cells with clear cytoplasm is suggestive of clear cell carcinoma. 

Clear cell carcinoma is the most common renal cell carcinoma. The growth pattern of clear cell carcinomas varies from solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular. Cells are round or polygonal in shape. The cytoplasm is clear or granular and it contains glycogen and lipid.

Clear cell carcinoma mostly arises from the proximal tubular epithelium. It is associated with the loss of the short arm of chromosome 3. The VHL gene (tumor suppressor gene) is located on chromosome 3p.

Clear cell carcinomas are usually single and unilateral. They are spherical masses that vary in size. Composed of yellow-colored tissue that distorts the renal outline. The yellow color is due to the accumulation of lipids in tumor cells.

The most common risk factors of renal cell carcinoma are tobacco usage, obesity, hypertension, and unopposed estrogen therapy. 

Other options:

Option A- Chromophobe carcinoma arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting duct. Tumor cells have pale eosinophilic cytoplasm with a halo around the nucleus and prominent cell membranes as shown below.

Option B- Papillary carcinoma arises from distal convoluted tubules. They can be multifocal and bilateral. The most common cytogenetic abnormalities associated are trisomies 7, 17 and loss of Y. Tumor cells are cuboidal or low columnar cells arranged in papillary formation with psammoma bodies as shown below.

Option D- Collecting duct carcinoma is a rare type of renal cell carcinoma that arises from the collecting duct cells in the medulla. They show irregular channels lined by atypical epithelium with a hobnail pattern as shown below.

Related Pearl: Familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes

Syndrome Mutation in 
Clinical manifestations
von Hippel–Lindau VHL gene (3p 25-26)
  • Clear cell RCC, renal cysts
  • Retinal angiomas (benign)
  • CNS hemangioblastomas (benign)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors
  • Cystadenoma
  • Endolymphatic sac tumors
Hereditary papillary RCC C-met proto-oncogene (7q31)
  • Multiple & bilateral type1 papillary RCC
Tuberous sclerosis  TSC1 (9q34) TSC2 (16p13)
  • Clear cell RCC
  • Multiple renal angiomyolipomas
  • Polycystic kidney disease
  • Cutaneous angiofibroma
  • Periungual fibroma
  • Shagreen patch
  • Ashleaf macules
  • Cardiac Rhabdomyoma
  • Subependymal nodules
  • Cortical tubers in CNS
  • Pulmonary lymphangiomyomatosis
Birt–Hogg–Dube  BHD gene: Folliculin (17p11)
  • Multiple chromophobe RCC
  • Hybrid oncocytic tumor 
  • Oncocytomas                   
  • Clear-cell RCC          
  • Papillary RCC                 
  • Facial fibrofoliculomas   
  • Lung cysts               
  • Spontaneous pneumothorax
Hereditary leiomyomatosis Fumarate hydratase (1q42-43)
  • Type 2 papillary RCC   
  • Collecting-duct RCC 
  • Leiomyomas of skin or uterus
  • Uterine leiomyosarcomas
Cowden syndrome PTEN (10q23) 
  • Benign and malignant breast tumors 
  • Epithelial thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary RCC or other histological subtypes
 

Note: RCC with syndromic associations tends to be bilateral. They also occur early in life.

VHL: von Hippel–Lindau

RCC: Renal cell carcinoma

PTEN: phosphatase and tensin homolog gene

BHD: Birt Hogg Dube

TSC: Tuberous sclerosis complex

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: While assessing the developmental milestones of a child,  you notice that he was able to walk upstairs with alternate feet and ride a tricycle. However, he couldn't walk downstairs with alternate feet or hop yet. He knows his full name, age, and gender. He also plays with other children.  What is the developmental age of this child?
questions.solution:
The developmental age of the child is mostly 3 years. 

Milestones in a 3-year-old child are: 

Gross motor:

  • Walks upstairs with alternate foot.
  • Rides a tricycle.

Adaptive:

  • Copies a circle.
  • Makes a tower of 9 blocks.

Language:

  • Knows full name, age, and gender.
  • Asks questions.
  • Begins to count, identifies 1-2 colors, and sings simple rhymes.

Social:

  • Plays simple games.
  • Shares toys.
  • Dress and undress fully if helped with buttons.

He is unable to walk downstairs with alternate feet, and hop since these are milestones usually achieved by 4 years of age.

Related Pearl: Gross motor milestones

 
Age Milestone
3 months Neck holding
5 months Rolls over
6 months Sits with support
8 months Sits without support
9 months Stands with support
12 months

Stands without support

Creeps well

Walks but falls
15 months

Walks without support

Creeps upstairs
18 months Runs
2 years Walks upstairs and downstairs (2 feet/step)
3 years

Walks upstairs with alternate foot

Rides tricycle
4 years

Walks downstairs with alternate foot

Hopping on 1 foot
5 years Can skip without falling to either side

 

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental milestones 

At 1 year

  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months

At 2 years

  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories

At 3 years

  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children

At 4 years

  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
 At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

Related Pearl: Language milestones

 
Age Milestone
1 month Alerts to sound
2 months Coos (musical vowel sound)
4 months Laughs aloud
6 months Monosyllables sounds (ma, ba)
9 months Bisyllables (mama, baba)
12 months 1-2 words with meaning
18 months 8-10 word vocabulary
2 years 2-3 word sentences (uses pronouns like I, me, you)
3 years Asks questions and knows name and gender
4 years Sings songs, poems and tells stories
5 years Asks meaning of words

questions.text: A 1-year-old child presents with pinpoint ecchymoses around the hair follicles and multiple episodes of epistaxis. On examination, he has nodules as seen in the image given below, which are tender on palpation. All of the following radiological signs could be seen in this patient, except ____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of perifollicular hemorrhages and the image showing scorbutic rosary are suggestive of scurvy. The radiological sign cupping and fraying is not seen in this patient. It is seen in rickets. 

Radiological signs in scurvy include:

  • White line of Frankel: Calcified cartilage at metaphyses
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelkan spur: Lateral prolongation of the white line, which is present at the cortical ends
  • Wimberger ring sign: Circular, opaque radiologic shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C, which is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline. Hence, deficiency of vitamin C leads to defective collagen formation resulting in generalized bleeding tendencies.

Hemorrhagic manifestations of scurvy include:

  • Petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points
  • Epistaxis
  • Gum bleeding
  • Perifollicular hemorrhages

Other manifestations are: 

  • Poor wound and fracture healing
  • Hyperkeratosis of hair follicles
  • Arthralgia and muscle weakness
  • Defective osteoid formation
  • Costo-chondral separation leading to the formation of sharply angulated tender nodules or scorbutic rosary

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman presents to the surgery outpatient unit with dilated, tortuous veins in the right leg. The skin finding seen on examination is given in the image below. What is the stage of the clinical classification according to the CEAP (Clinical- etiology- anatomy- pathophysiology for chronic venous disorders) classification?
questions.solution:
The clinical description is suggestive of varicose veins. The given image shows venous eczema which belongs to the C4a stage of the CEAP classification.

Varicose veins refer to subcutaneous dilated veins of more than 3 mm in diameter. 

Risk factors:

  • Females>males
  • Increasing age
  • Increasing body mass and height
  • Pregnancy
  • Family history
  • Smokers 
  • Occupations involving prolonged periods of standing

Clinical classification according to CEAP is:  

  • C0- no signs of venous disease
  • C1- telangiectasia (<1 mm dilatation) or reticular veins (1 mm - 2.9 mm dilatation)
  • C2- varicose vein (>3 mm dilatation)
    • C2r- recurrent varicose veins
  • C3-  edema
  • C4- changes in the skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary to chronic venous disease
    • C4a- pigmentation or eczema
    • C4b- lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
    • C4c- corona phlebectatica
  • C5- healed ulcer
  • C6- active venous ulcer
    • C6r- recurrent active venous ulcer

Each clinical class is further sub-categorized into symptomatic (S) and asymptomatic (A).

Image A - tortuous dilated veins - C2

Image B - Atrophie blanche - C4b

Image C - fan-shaped telangiectasia - C4c

The images below show C5 and C6 - healed and active venous ulcers respectively.

Investigations: 

  • Clinical examination
  • Venous duplex ultrasound of 7.5-13MHz probe intensity which tells about:
    • the site of reflux
    • size of vein
    • location of perforators
    • presence of obstruction in deep venous system
    • indication of pelvic source of reflux or obstruction
  • MR venography
  • Invasive procedures such as contrast venography or intravenous ultrasound.

Management:

  • Endovascular procedures
    • Endovascular laser ablation
    • Radiofrequency ablation
    • Ultrasound guided foam sclerotherapy
    • Catheter directed sclerotherapy and mechanochemical ablation
    • Endovenous glue
  • Open surgeries
    • Saphenofemoral ligation and great saphenous vein stripping
    • Saphenopopliteal junction ligation and small saphenous vein stripping
  • Non-Surgical procedures
    • Compression stockings

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

Clinical classification (C)*

C0

No visible or palpable signs of venous disease

C1

Telangiectases or reticular veins

C2

C2r

Varicose veins

Recurrent varicose veins

C3

Edema

C4

Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary

to chronic venous disease

C4a-Pigmentation or eczema

C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

C4c-Corona phlebectatica

C5

Healed ulcer

C6

C6r

Active ulcer

Recurrent active venous ulcer

S

A

Etiological classification (E)

Ec

Congenital (Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome)

Ep

Esi
