Note:

  • The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.
  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm
  • Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text: An elderly man with a long-standing history of memory loss and behavioral changes passed away. On autopsy, brain atrophy was noted. A histopathology section of his brain showed the following finding. This protein is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Alzheimer’s disease and the above image shows neurofibrillary tangles inside the neuron. These are formed from helical filaments of abnormal tau proteins.

In Alzheimer’s disease, neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques are found in the brain, especially in the hippocampus. Neurofibrillary tangles are deposited inside the neurons, whereas amyloid plaques are deposited around the neurons.

Other options:

Option A: Amyloid plaques are made of beta-amyloid precursor protein (APP). They are deposited around the neurons. Amyloid plaque is shown in the image below:


Option B: Prions deposit in the neurons and cause apoptosis. The degeneration of these neurons leads to spongiform encephalopathy. The protein gets deposited as plaques.

The image given below shows the spongiform appearance of the brain seen in prion disease.


Option D: Alzheimer's disease may also have Lewy body. Lewy bodies are formed due to the clumping of abnormal alpha-synuclein protein in the neurons. They predominantly cause Lewy body dementia but can also be found in Parkinson’s and Alzhiemer's disease.

The image given below shows Lewy body.

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare launches a new national health programme. You are made in charge of the cost accounting management for this program. Which of the following is not a purpose of cost accounting?

choices.text: Comparing the program cost with the results achieved
Allocation of people and financial resources

questions.solution:
Comparison of cost of the program with the results achieved is not a purpose of cost-accounting.

Cost-accounting is a quantitative method of management of healthcare programs that provides basic data on the financial structure of a given program. Financial records are maintained which helps associate costs with the purpose for which they are incurred. Cost-accounting has three important purposes in health services :

  • Cost control
  • Planning and allocation of people and financial resources
  • Pricing of cost reimbursement

Comparison of the cost of the program with the results achieved is included under cost-effective analysis.

Related Pearl: Management Methods in Health Programmes

Methods based on behavioral sciences

Quantitative methods

Organisational design

Personnel management

Communication

Information systems

Management by objectives(MBO)

Cost–Benefit analysis

Cost-Effective analysis

Cost–Accounting

Input–Output analysis

Model

Systems analysis

Network analysis- Includes Programme Evaluation and Review Technique(PERT) and Critical Path Method(CPM)

Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)

Work sampling

Decision making

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient requires percutaneous coronary intervention. He was given an IV infusion of a reversible ADP receptor inhibitor. Which of the following drugs was used?
questions.solution:
Cangrelor is a parenteral, reversible ADP receptor (P2Y12 receptor) inhibitor, administered intravenously.

Abciximab, eptifibatide, and tirofiban are parenteral agents too but, they are GPIIb/IIIa inhibitors.

Related Pearl: Classification of anti-platelet drugs

Class Drugs
Cyclooxygenase- I inhibitors Aspirin
Irreversible P2Y12 inhibitors

Ticlopidine, Clopidogrel, Prasugrel
Reversible P2Y12 inhibitors Ticagrelor, Cangrelor
GpIIb/IIIa inhibitors Abciximab, Eptifibatide, Tirofiban
Thrombin (PAR-1) receptor antagonist Vorapaxar 
Phosphodiesterase inhibitors

Dipyridamole

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient complained of a right breast lump. On examination, it was 4cm in size, hard, immobile, and had no lymph nodes palpable. On a mammogram, there were microcalcifications in the right upper outer quadrant. Biopsy report shows ductal carcinoma in situ. The patient insisted on preserving the breast. During surgery, the surgeon obtained ‘ink on tumor’ 2 times. Which of the following is the absolute contraindication for breast conservative therapy(BCT)?

choices.text: Size of the lump is 4 cm
Ductal carcinoma in situ on biopsy
Lump in the upper outer quadrant
Ink on tumor obtained for 2 times

questions.solution:
The absolute contraindication for breast conservative therapy in this patient is the presence of cancer cells on the edge inked with dye (persistent positive resection margin that is 2 times ink on tumor).

Breast conservative therapy involves resection of primary breast cancer with a 1 cm margin of normal breast tissue along with adjuvant radiotherapy and assessment of regional lymph nodes via a separate incision in the axilla. Removal of primary breast cancer is also called lumpectomy/ tylectomy/ partial mastectomy/ wide local excision.

Absolute contraindications of BCT:

  • Pregnancy
  • Persistently positive margin (2 microscopy shows positive margins)
  • Multicentric lumps
  • Diffuse microcalcification
  • History of therapeutic radiation to the upper trunk

Relative contraindications of BCT:

  • Active SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus), scleroderma  
  • Large lump to breast ratio (>5 cm size lump)
  • Lump just beneath the nipple-areolar complex
  • Multifocal disease

Related Pearl: Contraindications for Breast Conservative Surgery

Absolute contraindications:

  • 1st-trimester pregnancy
  • Diffuse microcalcifications
  • Persistently positive pathologic margin
  • Multicentric tumor
  • History of therapeutic radiation exposure to the chest wall

Relative contraindications:

  • Connective tissue disorders like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE),  scleroderma and rheumatoid arthritis
  • Large lump-to-breast ratio, i.e., a big lump in small breast
  • Lump beneath the nipple-areola complex
  • Multifocal tumor

NOTE : Some authorities do not consider Rheumatoid Arthritis as a relative contraindication as the data on radiation toxicity in RA is sparse.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of recurrent late-trimester abortions is in preterm labor, presumed to be due to chorioamnionitis. She has received one dose of betamethasone injection. This is a precious pregnancy and the relatives are concerned about prematurity-related complications in the baby. Which of the following is useful for assessing lung maturity in this fetus?
questions.solution:
The lecithin–sphingomyelin ratio (L/S ratio) is an amniotic fluid test used to assess fetal lung maturity. L/S ratio of < 2 in amniotic fluid indicates lung immaturity. 

Surfactant starts appearing in the fetal lung by 20 weeks of gestation. Levels indicating lung maturity are detected after 35 weeks.

Surfactant is a complex mixture of lipids, proteins, and carbohydrates produced by type II pneumocytes in the lung epithelium. The absence of surfactant in the liquid film lining the alveoli causes an increase in surface tension and alveolar collapse. If not treated, such atelectasis leads to increased work of breathing, intrapulmonary shunting, ventilation-perfusion mismatch, hypoxia, and eventually respiratory failure. 

The relative concentration of the phospholipids lecithin (L) and sphingomyelin (S) is an indicator of lung maturity. The outward flow of pulmonary secretions from the fetal lungs into the amniotic fluid maintains the level of lecithin and sphingomyelin equally until 32–33 weeks gestation when the lecithin concentration begins to increase significantly while sphingomyelin remains nearly the same. An L–S ratio of 2.5 or more indicates fetal lung maturity while an L/S ratio of less than 1.5 is associated with a high risk of infant respiratory distress syndrome.

Other tests done to assess fetal lung maturity are:

  • Shake test/bubble test
  • Phosphatidyl glycerol measurement
  • Surfactant:albumin ratio
  • Lamellar body counts

questions.text: The standard treatment regimen for brucellosis in adults includes _________.
questions.solution:
The standard treatment regimen for Brucellosis includes streptomycin and doxycycline.

Brucella are small, non-motile, aerobic, capnophilic coccobacilli. The most important species that are pathologic to humans are B.melitensis, B. suis, and B.abortus.

Brucellosis is a zoonotic disease. It is transmitted to humans from contact with or consumption of contaminated products from goats, sheep, cattle, buffaloes, pigs, and other animals.

Once the infection is transmitted, these bacteria resist intracellular digestion and proliferate within the reticuloendothelial system for a long time. This is the reason why brucellosis often becomes chronic and is resistant to simple antimicrobial therapy. 

Clinically, patients may present with an acute infection comprised of undulant fever, characterized by a rising and falling fever. They may also have arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. Chronic infection tends to be episodic with non-specific symptoms. 

Laboratory diagnosis of brucellosis is important and includes several methods such as

  • polymerase chain reaction
  • culture of Brucella species done from specimens including blood, bone marrow aspirate, lymph node aspirate, CSF, and urine. The preferred method and medium of culture is the Castaneda method. 
  • Serological methods include standard agglutination test (SAT), complement fixation test, Coomb’s antiglobulin test, and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). 
  • Tests for animals and animal products include tests such as the milk ring tests and Rose Bengal card tests. 

Milk ring test- A sample of milk is mixed well with hematoxylin-stained brucella antigen and incubated. If the sample contains antibodies to brucella antigens, agglutination occurs with the agglutinate rising to the top as a blue ring. If the sample does not contain antibodies to brucella antigens, the whole of the sample is uniformly stained blue. 

The images below show the Casteneda's medium and the milk ring test respectively.

 

Treatment includes antimicrobial therapy with at least two agents for six weeks duration. The preferred combination is intramuscular streptomycin 0.75-1g per day for two to three weeks along with doxycycline 100mg BD for six weeks.

The WHO states that the main alternative therapy is doxycycline at 100 mg, twice a day for 45 days, plus rifampicin at 15mg/kg/day (600-900mg) for 45 days.

Children and pregnant women in whom tetracyclines are contraindicated can be treated with Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

Significant neurologic disease due to Brucellosis usually requires long-term treatment for around 3-6 months with Ceftriaxone supplementation of a standard regimen.

Prevention of Brucellosis is important by screening and abiding by safety standards in farms and dairy industries, and also by pasteurization of milk and milk products.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing preanesthetic evaluation. He is seated upright with the head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruded, and no phonation. The image of the mouth is given below. Which class does he belong to according to the modified Mallampati score?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the faucial pillars, uvula, and the soft palate are all visible. Therefore, this patient is classified as class I according to the modified Mallampati score. 

The modified Mallampati score is used to assess the difficulty of endotracheal intubation in a patient.

The patient is seated upright with the neutral position of the head, open mouth, and protruded tongue and the patient is asked to not speak. The classification is done based on the visibility of structures through the mouth in this position. The Mallampati classification modified by Samsoon and Young is as follows:

  • Class I: Faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate are visualized.
  • Class II: The base of the uvula, fauces and soft palate are visualized.
  • Class III: Only the soft palate and base of uvula are visualized.
  • Class IV: Only the Hard palate is visualized.

Higher scores on the Mallampati classification indicate a more difficult laryngoscopy and subsequent intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 14 weeks of gestation developed sudden-onset fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, and headache. On further evaluation, she tested positive for the Zika virus. Which of the following is not a mode of transmission of this virus?

choices.text: Bite of an infected Aedes mosquito

questions.solution:
The scenario given above describes Zika virus infection in the mother during pregnancy. Droplet transmission is not a mode of transmission of the Zika virus.

Zika virus is a flavivirus acquired mainly through the bite of an infected female Aedes aegypti mosquito. However, transmission can also occur perinatally, through sexual contact with an infected individual, breastfeeding, and blood transfusion. Congenital transmission of the Zika virus is known to cause fetal microcephaly. 

Although there have been a few cases reported of the Zika virus being transmitted from the infected mother to the infant by breastfeeding, the benefits of breastfeeding definitely outweigh its risks, and it is recommended for people to continue breastfeeding their infants. 

Congenital transmission of the Zika virus leads to fetal microcephaly. Zika virus infection during pregnancy may also lead to other malformations including limb contractures, high muscle tone, eye abnormalities, and hearing loss, known as congenital Zika syndrome.

Zika virus infection is characterized by influenza-like clinical signs including fever, headache, and malaise. An itchy, maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, myalgia, and arthralgia usually accompany or follow those manifestations.

The complications of the Zika virus infection include Guillan-Barre syndrome, encephalitis, meningoencephalitis, peripheral neuropathies, and neurological birth defects. Other complications of pregnancy include preterm birth and miscarriage.

The disease is usually asymptomatic and self-resolving. People with mild symptoms should get plenty of rest, drink fluids, and treat pain and fever with common medicines. If symptoms worsen, they should seek medical care and advice. Pregnant women living in areas with Zika transmission or who develop symptoms of Zika virus infection should seek medical attention for laboratory testing and other clinical care.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman was taken up for Cesarean section. Spinal anesthesia was given and the patient went into hypotension. Which of the following would be the vasopressor of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Phenylephrine is the vasopressor of choice in pregnant patients developing hypotension following neuraxial anesthesia (spinal and epidural).

Phenylephrine is preferred because besides effectively controlling hypotension, it has less placental transfer and lesser chances of fetal acidosis than ephedrine.

The patient should receive an adequate intravenous fluid bolus of crystalloid like Ringer lactate solution (typically 1000–1500 mL) or colloid (typically 250–500 mL) solution at the time of neural blockade to avoid hypotension. On developing hypotension even after adequate fluid management, vasopressors are administered for the further management.

After the administration of the spinal anesthetic injection, the patient is placed supine with left uterine displacement (to prevent aortocaval compression) and supplemental oxygen (40–50%) is given.

Blood pressure should be monitored every 1–2 min until it stabilizes.

Hypotension following epidural anesthesia typically has a slower onset.

Other options:

Option A- Dopamine is not used in pregnant women developing hypotension because it lowers the pO2 levels in umbilical vessels. 

Option B- Vasopressin is reserved for circulatory collapse or patients who do not respond to volume infusion and catecholamines. Hence, it is not preferred here.

Option C- Ephedrine has more placental transfer and there is a higher risk of fetal acidosis.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant who was born at term was presented with complaints of lethargy and poor feeding. On examination, the infant had a puffy face, enlarged fontanelles, and protruding tongue, as shown below. The lower limb x-ray revealed an absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphysis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism.

The clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism include a puffy face, enlarged fontanelles, protruding tongue, prolonged jaundice, lethargy, and a history of poor feeding. The absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses denotes the onset of congenital hypothyroidism. These epiphyses are normally present at birth.

Congenital hypothyroidism is the most common preventable cause of intellectual disability. Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in India accounting for about 75% of all cases.

Congenital hypothyroidism is mostly asymptomatic at birth and is detected mainly by the neonatal screening of TSH levels in the first few weeks of life. Clinical features present after maternal thyroxine wanes.

Screening is usually done on day 2-day 4 postnatally, and usually, dried blood samples are used for this. The most commonly used strategy is screening for TSH first, as they have higher sensitivity compared to the T4-based screening.

In untreated hypothyroidism, as the child grows older, there is a discrepancy between chronological age and osseous development. Epiphyseal dysgenesis wherein there are multiple foci of ossification in the epiphyses, is common. X-rays of the skull reveal large fontanelles, wide sutures, and intersutural (wormian) bones. Radiotracer uptake study with radioactive iodine or technetium should be done as soon as primary congenital hypothyroidism is diagnosed.

Treatment with levothyroxine should be started within 2 weeks in order to maintain normal cognitive and physical development. Thyroxine of dose 10-15 μg/kg/day should be started and adjusted to achieve the normal free T4 range. TSH may be elevated up to 2 years of age with a reset of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. 

Other options:

Option A- Down’s syndrome also presents with developmental delay and hypothyroidism. They have characteristic facial features such as a flat face, depressed nasal bridge, upslanting palpebral fissures, and a single palmar crease. The image shown below depicts an infant with Down's syndrome. Radiological features include atlantoaxial dislocation.

Option B-  Congenital rickets is a rare condition resulting from severe maternal vitamin D deficiency and can present with symptomatic hypocalcemia, intrauterine growth retardation, decreased bone ossification along with classic rachitic changes.

Option D- Hurler's syndrome is a mucopolysaccharidosis which may present after 6 months with hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features, corneal clouding, large tongue, prominent forehead, joint stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old patient presents with nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and malaise for the last week. He has a low-grade fever and developed jaundice yesterday. He does not have fecal incontinence. On abdominal examination, he has tenderness in the right upper quadrant. His laboratory evaluation is given below. What is the management for his condition?
IgM Anti-HAV positive
HBsAg negative
HBeAg negative
anti-HBs positive
serum aminotransferases elevated
questions.solution:
This patient with gastrointestinal symptoms and positive IgM- HAV is likely to have acute hepatitis A infection and requires supportive treatment. 

Since most patients recover spontaneously, only supportive treatment is required. 

Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is an icosahedral, non enveloped virus that causes hepatitis A infection. HAV is transmitted by the fecal-oral route. Usually, it is due to contamination of food or water. It may transmit from person to person due to poor hygiene. It mostly is of mild nature, with only 0.1% of patients developing fulminant hepatitis.

It has an incubation period of 15 - 45 days. It may present with constitutional symptoms of nausea, vomiting, anorexia, malaise, myalgia, arthralgia, headache, and photophobia. 1-2 weeks after the constitutional symptoms, patients present with jaundice and tender hepatomegaly. Low-grade fever may also be present. 

This is followed by a recovery phase where the constitutional symptoms disappear but the hepatomegaly and elevated transaminases are still present. Full recovery is expected 1-2 months after the onset. 

Diagnosis of HAV is confirmed by IgM anti-HAV during acute illness. 

It can be prevented by HAV vaccination.

Other options:

Option B - Antivirals are not needed in HAV. They may be used in hepatitis B or C. 

Option C - Physical isolation is done in hepatitis A patients with fecal incontinence. This patient does not have fecal incontinence. Even then, HAV is excreted in feces in very small amounts. Using gloves to handle fecal matter is sufficient.

Option D - Interferon therapy is useful in the treatment of chronic HCV and HBV infections. They are cytokines that have antiviral, immunomodulatory, and antiproliferative activity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who underwent renal transplantation a year ago presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever with chills, headache, confusion, and vomiting. On cerebrospinal fluid microscopy, gram-positive rods with tumbling motility at 25°C are observed. Which is the most likely mode of transmission of this pathogen?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an immunosuppressed adult with symptoms suggestive of meningitis, and an organism showing tumbling motility at 25°C points to a diagnosis of Listeria monocytogenes. The most likely mode of transmission of Listeria monocytogenes is through the ingestion of contaminated food such as cheese, fruits, or vegetables.

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus that shows characteristic tumbling motility at 25°C and becomes non-motile at 37°C. The image below shows the tumbling motility of Listeria.

Listeria can overcome the food preservation process since it grows at 4°C, with low pH, and high salt concentration. 

It has cell wall surface proteins called internalin A and B that interact with E-cadherin, a receptor on epithelial cells, promoting phagocytosis into the epithelial cells. The virulence factor produced by Listeria is called listeriolysin O. This helps the bacteria to escape and cause septicemia. They are catalase-positive and show beta hemolysis. This helps to differentiate Listeria from other gram-positive bacilli.

Listeriosis can present as gastroenteritis in healthy adults. It usually develops within 48 hours of ingestion of a large inoculum in contaminated food. It can also lead to the formation of an abscess, pharyngitis, pneumonia, and endocarditis. It leads to neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and meningoencephalitis in the elderly and immunocompromised people. Listeriosis in pregnancy can lead to abortion and stillbirth.

Most laboratories do not routinely culture Listeria from stool samples. The diagnosis of systemic listeriosis rests on the isolation of the organism in cultures of blood and spinal fluid.

Ampicillin plus gentamicin is often recommended for therapy. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is the drug of choice for central nervous system infections in patients who are allergic to penicillin. 

Other options:

Option A- Respiratory droplets are the mode of transmission for pathogens including Neisseria meningitides, respiratory syncytial virus, etc.

Option B- Needlestick injury is the mode of transmission for pathogens including Hepatitis B, HIV, etc.

Option D- Arthropod bite is the mode of transmission of various pathogens including dengue virus, yellow fever virus, etc.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient has been using a long-acting beta-agonist to control her exercise-induced asthma. Which of the following is not a systemic effect of the drug due to the stimulation of the receptor involved?

choices.text: Relaxation of the ciliary muscle of eye

questions.solution:
Long-acting beta-agonists used in asthma control act by β2 adrenergic agonism. These drugs do not lead to a decrease in the contraction of the heart. The contraction of the heart is mediated by β1 adrenergic agonism.

Long-acting beta-agonists are used in the prophylaxis of exercise-induced asthma, COPD, and bronchial asthma. Its effect occurs within minutes of inhaling a therapeutic dose of the drug. 

The pharmacological effects due to β2 adrenergic agonism include:

  • Relaxation of the ciliary muscle of the eye
  • Relaxation of bronchial smooth muscle
  • Decreased motility of GIT
  • Increased lipolysis
  • Tremors
  • Increased skeletal muscle glycogenolysis
  • Increased potassium uptake
  • Increased insulin secretion
  • Gallbladder, splenic capsule, detrusor, and uterine relaxation

The effects of stimulation of the other adrenergic receptors are:

Alpha 1

  • Mydriasis
  • Major blood vessel vasoconstriction
  • Gastrointestinal and genitourinary tract sphincter contraction
  • Decreased renin secretion
  • Pregnant uterus contraction
  • Ejaculation
  • Piloerection
  • Liver glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis

Alpha 2

  • Decreased gastrointestinal secretion
  • Decreased insulin secretion
  • Decreased lipolysis

Beta 1

  • Increased heart rate
  • Increased force of contraction of the heart
  • Increased automaticity
  • Increased conduction velocity
  • Increased renin secretion
  • ADH secretion

Beta 3

  • Increased lipolysis

questions.text: A second-year medical student, during the ward rounds, asks one of the patients to keep his fingers as shown in the image, to elicit a clinical finding. Which of the following conditions is least likely to cause an abnormal sign pertaining to this clinical finding?
questions.solution:
The medical student, by asking the patient to keep the dorsal surfaces of his fingers opposed, is trying to elicit clubbing. Irritable bowel syndrome is not associated with clubbing.

In a normal person, when the dorsal surfaces of the distal parts of two fingers are opposed, a diamond-shaped gap is created, called Schamroth's window. 

Obliteration in clubbed fingers of the diamond-shaped window normally produced is called the Schamroth's sign.


Clubbing is the growth of the tips of the fingers which occurs due to connective tissue proliferation. It can be idiopathic, hereditary, or acquired.

The underlying mechanism for clubbing is still unclear but different hypotheses include anoxic, toxic, neurogenic, metabolic, and humoral. 

The different grades of clubbing are as follows: 

Grade 1 Increased fluctuation of the nail bed with loss of onychodermal angle
Grade 2 

Increase in antero-posterior and transverse diameter of the nails. Nails becomes smooth and glossy with loss of longitudinal ridges.
Grade 3

Increased pulp tissue
Grade 4

Wrist and ankle swelling due to hypertrophic osteoarthropathy

Causes of clubbing include: 

  1. Cardiac causes
    1. Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    2. Subacute bacterial endocarditis
    3. Cardiac tumors
    4. Eisenmenger's syndrome
  2. Lung and pleural causes
    1. Bronchiectasis
    2. Lung abscess
    3. Bronchogenic carcinoma
    4. Empyema thoracis
    5. Fibrosing alveolitis
    6. Pleural mesothelioma
    7. Pulmonary arteriovenous fistula
    8. Cystic fibrosis
    9. Fibrocaseous tuberculosis
  3. Ulcerative colitis
  4. Biliary cirrhosis
  5. Intestinal causes
    1. Malabsorption
    2. Crohn's disease
    3. Polyposis coli
    4. Coeliac disease
  6. Normal
  7. Genetic

questions.text:
A patient with asthma is being evaluated. His FEV1 values were measured before and after the administration of a short-acting beta-agonist. Which of the following values represents the minimum change required to demonstrate the reversibility of obstruction after administration of bronchodilators in this condition?

FEV1 - Forced expiratory volume in the first minute

FVC - Forced vital capacity

choices.text: > 12% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 200 mL increase in FEV1
> 50% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 500 mL increase in FEV1
> 20% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 410 mL increase in FEV1
> 6% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 100 mL increase in FEV1

questions.solution:
Reversibility of obstruction in asthma has to be demonstrated by a minimum of 12% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 200 mL increase in FEV1 in response to inhalation of short-acting beta-agonist (SABA).

In asthma, there is reversible bronchoconstriction leading to wheezing, breathlessness, and cough. Thus, on administering a SABA, there is bronchial relaxation and relief of symptoms. 

Asthma is generally diagnosed clinically based on symptoms alone. However, there are a number of other conditions that can be misdiagnosed as asthma such as causes of wheeze (bronchogenic carcinoma, foreign body aspiration), cough (gastroesophageal reflux, chronic bronchitis, rhinitis), and dyspnea (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, pulmonary edema, or obesity). Misdiagnosis would lead to a delay in management. Thus, it is ideal that the clinical diagnosis of asthma is confirmed by pulmonary function tests. 

  • Spirometry: It is a non-invasive investigation that can be used to approximate lung volumes. This shows an obstructive pattern
    • Decreased FEV1
    • Decreased or normal FVC
    • Decreased FEV1/FVC
  • Bronchodilator reversibility: Spirometry is performed both before and after inhalation of a short-acting bronchodilator (400 mcg of β2 agonist or 160 mcg of anticholinergic). A 12% and 200 mL increase in FEV1 compared to pre-bronchodilator value is diagnostic of asthma in adults. 
  • Bronchial provocation test: Provocative stimulus (histamine, methacholine, inhaled mannitol, exercise, eucapnic hyperventilation with dry or cold air) is used to test the presence of airway hyperresponsiveness.  A fall of ≥20% in FEV1 from baseline, with a standard dose of methacholine (methacholine challenge test), is diagnostic of asthma.
  • Peak expiratory flow (PEF): PEF readings are taken twice daily for over 2 weeks. The average daily diurnal PEF variability of >10% is diagnostic of asthma in adults.

questions.text: All the following statements about Wilkie's syndrome are true except:

choices.text: It is also known as superior mesenteric artery syndrome.
It is most commonly seen in elderly obese women.
Compression occurs at third part of duodenum.
One of the surgical treatment includes duodenojejunostomy.

questions.solution:
Wilkie's syndrome is usually seen in young asthenic women. 

Wilkie's syndrome is also known as superior mesenteric artery syndrome (SMA). It is a rare condition that occurs due to the compression of the third part of the duodenum between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta. 

Normally, the angle between the superior mesenteric artery and aorta (aortomesenteric angle) ranges from 38° to 65°. However, decreasing to an angle of less than 25° causes compression of the third part of the duodenum. 

This syndrome is most commonly seen in young, asthenic women. The main predisposing factors are rapid weight loss, supine immobilization, anorexia nervosa, and placement of body cast. So, it is also called cast syndrome.

Symptoms include profound nausea and vomiting; abdominal distension; weight loss; and postprandial epigastric pain, which varies from intermittent to constant, depending on the severity of the duodenal obstruction.

A barium study of the upper gastrointestinal tract demonstrates cessation of the flow of barium from the duodenum to the jejunum. A CT scan can be used to confirm SMA by measuring the aortomesenteric angle. The surgical treatment includes duodenojejunostomy, gastrojejunostomy, and duodenal derotation.

questions.text: Choose the option in which the enzyme and its function are incorrectly matched.

choices.text: DNA polymerase - involved in deoxynucleotide polymerization
Helicase - prevents premature reannealing of double-stranded DNA
Topoisomerase - relieves torsional strain caused by unwinding of DNA
DNA ligase - sealing nicks in DNA strands

questions.solution:
Helicase is not involved in the prevention of premature reannealing of double-stranded DNA (dsDNA); this is the function of single-strand binding proteins (SSBs)

Helicases belong to a class of proteins involved in DNA replication. They are involved in ATP-driven unwinding of DNA.

Other options:

Option A- DNA polymerases - Involved in deoxynucleotide polymerization

Option B- Topoisomerases - Relieve torsional strain resulting from unwinding

Option D- DNA ligase - Seals nicks in the DNA strand during replication

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in DNA Replication

Enzyme Function
DNA Polymerase I (Pol I) Gap filling following DNA replication, repair, and recombination
DNA polymerase II (Pol II) DNA proofreading and repair
DNA polymerase III (Pol III)

Processive, leading strand synthesis, DNA proofreading
DnaG

Primase 
Helicase ATP-driven processive unwinding of DNA.
Primase Initiates synthesis of RNA primers.
Topoisomerase Relieve torsional strain that results from helicase-induced unwinding.
Single-strand binding proteins (SSBs) Prevents premature reannealing of dsDNA.
DNA ligase Seals the single strand nick between the nascent chain and Okazaki fragments on lagging strand.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with complaints of dribbling of urine on coughing or sneezing. A diagnosis of stress urinary incontinence was suspected. All the following tests can help in the diagnosis of this condition, except _____.
questions.solution:
All the above tests can help in the diagnosis of stress urinary incontinence, except the methylene blue 3 swab test. Methylene blue 3 swab test is done for genitourinary fistulae.

Genuine stress incontinence (GSI) is defined as a small involuntary leakage of urine with increased abdominal pressure in the absence of detrusor contraction. It occurs when the bladder pressure exceeds urethral pressure during physical stress in the absence of detrusor contraction. It is generally due to hypermobility of the urethra, loss of posterior angle, or sphincteric dysfunction. The risk factors include older age, post-menopausal status, multiparity, obesity, smoking,  pregnancy and puerperium, and hereditary conditions which lead to loss of collagen tissue.

Tests done for GSI (Genuine stress incontinence) are:

  • Stress test (Option A): The patient is catheterized after she voids urine and the residual urine in the bladder is measured. Examining for objective evidence of a leak:
    • The patient is asked to squat over a preweighed absorbent pad and is asked to cough and strain.
    • The patient is placed in a lithotomy position and asked to cough and strain for further evidence of a leak.
  • Cotton swab stick test (Option B): A Q tip cotton swab is introduced into the urethra. Initially, the tip of the swab would be horizontal to the floor. Upon straining, in patients without GSI, the tip of the swab would not shift more than 10-15 degrees above the horizontal. In patients with GSI, the tip might go beyond 50-70 degrees from the horizontal.
  • Marshall and Bonney test (Option D): The region of the bladder neck is elevated. If there is no leakage of urine on straining, it indicates a favorable outcome following surgical repair.
  • Urethroscopy.
  • Urodynamic evaluation- cystometry, urethrocystometry, uroflowmetry, etc.

Management includes : 

  • Conservative approach: Kegel pelvic floor exercises, magnetic/electric stimulation for nerve injuries, estrogen cream for post-menopausal women, etc
  • Surgical management: The various surgeries include:
    • Marshall–Marchetti–Krantz and Pereyra Burch
    • Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension
    • Slings
      • Tension-free sling
      • Transobturator type
    • Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck

Methylene blue 3 swab test is used to diagnose genitourinary fistulae. Three cotton swabs are placed in the vagina—one at the vault, one in the middle, and one just above the introitus. The methylene blue dye is instilled into the bladder through a rubber catheter and the patient is asked to walk for about 5 minutes. She is then asked to lie down and the swabs are inspected. If the swabs are stained with urine and not with the dye, it is indicative of a ureteric fistula. If the lowermost swab is stained blue, it is indicative of a urethral fistula. If the lower 2 swabs are stained blue, it is indicative of a vesicovaginal fistula.

questions.text: You are an intern in the paediatrics outpatient department. An overweight child, suspected of obesity is brought for assessment of body fat. The consultant on duty asks you to measure the skinfold thickness of the child. Which of the following regions are not commonly measured for skinfold thickness?
questions.solution:
The mid-thigh region is not commonly measured for skinfold thickness.

The assessment of skinfold thickness measures the amount of subcutaneous fat. Measurement of skinfold thickness is done as it is easily accessible. It is a rapid and non-invasive method for assessing body fat. The callipers used for this purpose are called Harpenden skin callipers. 

Measurements are taken from the following four sites :

  1. Mid-triceps region
  2. Biceps region
  3. Subscapular region
  4. Suprailiac region

The sum of the measurements should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls. 

Disadvantages- Standards for subcutaneous fat do not exist for comparison. In extreme obesity, measurements cannot be taken. It has poor repeatability.

Related Pearl: Indicators for Body fat

The indicators for body fat are:

Body weight: +3SD (standard deviations) from the median weight for height as a cut-off point for obesity. For adults, some people calculate various other indicators such as:

  • Body mass index (Quetelet's index): Weight (kg) / Square of height in metres
  • Ponderal index: Weight (kg)/Height^3 (m)
  • Corpulence index: Actual weight /desirable weight.(Should not exceed 1.2)

Broca's index = Height (cm) - 100 . 

Lorentz's formula 
Ht (cm) - 100 - [ (Ht (cm) - 150) / 2 for women or 4 for men ]

Skinfold thickness: Four sites mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular and suprailiac regions. The sum of the measurements should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls.

Waist circumference and waist-hip ratio: At the mid point between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest. There is an increased risk of metabolic complications for men with a waist circumference~ 102 cm, and women with a waist circumference~ 88 cm. A high WHR (> 1.0 in men and> 0.85 in women) indicates abdominal fat accumulation.

Total body water

Total body potassium

Body density

questions.text: An elderly man presents with massive hematemesis. On examination, he has a heart rate of 120 bpm, blood pressure of 80/40mm Hg, and cold extremities. Which of the following should be placed first?
questions.solution:
A peripheral venous catheter should be placed first. This patient has lost a lot of blood volume through hematemesis and is in hypovolemic shock. The goal of care in this scenario is to improve volume status which can be done through placement of large bore intravenous lines (16 gauge or 18 gauge) and administering fluids.

It is important to not delay placement of these catheters, even if it appears that there is easy venous access as the patient’s condition can suddenly worsen. In this case, the veins could collapse and you would have to resort to more invasive procedures to maintain volume status. 

Hypovolemic shock is frequently caused by hemorrhage which can be external due to trauma or internal. The most common cause of internal hemorrhage leading to hypovolemic shock is gastrointestinal bleeding. Massive burns and vomiting are other causes of hypovolemic shock. 

Other options: 

Option B - Arterial lines will aid in measurement of more accurate intravascular blood pressure, mean arterial pressure and acid-base status. It is more useful to determine response to therapy. 

Option C - Central venous catheter would be the next option if the fluid administered through the peripheral venous catheters was not sufficient in volume resuscitation. It can also be used to administer inotropes and for hemodynamic monitoring. It is more invasive procedure so it should be avoided as first line management. 

Option D - Urinary catheters should be placed after volume resuscitation is begun as urine output can be used to monitor renal function and response to treatment.

Related Pearl: Classification of hemorrhagic shock

Parameters Class I Class II Class III Class IV
Blood loss in % <15 15–30 30–40 >40
Pulse rate <100 100–120 120–140 >140
Blood pressure Normal Normal Decreased Greatly decreased
Pulse pressure Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Respiratory rate 14–20 20–30 30–40 >35
Mental status Slightly anxious Mildly anxious Anxious, confused Confused, lethargic
Urine output (mL/hr) >30 20–30 5–15 Minimal

 

Related Pearl: Compensatory responses to hemorrhagic shock

  • Baroreceptor reflex
  • CNS Ischemic response
  • Reverse stress relaxation
  • ↑ secretion of renin by kidneys and formation of Angiotensin II
  • ↑ secretion of ADH
  • ↑Norepinephrine and epinephrine
  • Compensatory mechanisms that return the blood volume back toward normal, including
    • Absorption of large quantities of fluid from the intestinal tract
    • Absorption of fluid into the blood capillaries from the interstitial spaces of the body
    • Conservation of water and salt by the kidneys
    • Increased thirst and increased appetite for salt

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy was suffering from low grade fever and barking cough for one week. During examination, an inspiratory stridor is noticed. His chest X-ray is given below. What is this radiological finding called?
questions.solution:
Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis or croup, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The X-ray finding is the steeple sign due to subglottic narrowing.

The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months-3 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, and low-grade fever.

Management:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the improvement of upper airway obstruction. 
  • Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>IV>IM ). It is indicated in all the grades of croup.
  • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)

Antibiotics are usually not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

Other options:

Option A- Thumb sign is seen in acute epiglottitits. The swollen edematous epiglottis appears like a thumb in the radiograph.

 

Option C- String sign is seen in ileocaecal TB. It refers to the narrowed terminal ileum appearing as a string.

 

Option D- The ice cream cone sign describes the normal appearance of the ear ossicles on a CT scan. The ball of the ice cream is formed by the head of the malleus. The cone is formed by the body of the incus. The tapering conical point is  formed by the short process pointing towards the aditus ad antrum. If this normal appearance is not seen, it indicates ossicular chain disruption.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A 26-year-old athlete came to the orthopedic department with acute onset of pain in the lateral part of the foot while his routine practice. His radiograph of the foot is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows a transverse fracture on the base of the 5th metatarsal at the metaphyseal- diaphyseal junction and the most likely diagnosis is Jones fracture. 

A strong abduction force to the forefoot causes a bending moment in the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction and results in Jones fracture. This type of injury occurs in a sudden change in direction by an athlete.

Patients with Jones fracture usually present with pain, swelling, and tenderness at the outer border of the foot following routine practice or an injury to the foot. Below knee walking plaster cast is applied for 3 weeks.

The image below shows an extra-articular fracture at the base of the 5th metatarsal.

Other options:

Option A- March fracture is a fracture of the 2nd metatarsal. It occurs due to repeated stress from prolonged walking or running. This may occur in new army recruits committed to marching. Hence the name march fracture. These lesions heal spontaneously.

The below radiograph shows a March fracture of the second metatarsal bone.

Option C- Lisfranc fracture is the fracture of metatarsal bases with associated tarsometatarsal dislocation. Lisfranc articulation comprises the tarsometatarsal joints. The tarsometatarsal joints comprise of first, second, and third metatarso-cuneiform joints along with the fourth and fifth metatarso-cuboid joints.

Option D- Aviator's fracture is a fracture of the neck of the talus due to forced dorsiflexion of the ankle.

The below radiograph shows an Aviator’s fracture.

questions.text: A female patient with no relevant past or medication history presents to you with a rash on the cheeks and nose, oral ulcers, and multiple joint pains. Investigations showed low serum complement level. Antibody testing for which of the following is least likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The antibody test least likely to be positive in this scenario is the anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA). 

ANCAs are a group of autoantibodies involved in noninfectious vasculitis, such as microscopic polyangiitis, Churg-Strauss syndrome, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis. They are useful diagnostic markers and can also be used to predict disease recurrence. The two most important ANCAs are anti-proteinase 3 and anti-myeloperoxidase.

SLE is an autoimmune disease that is seen more commonly in women. The abnormal immune response leads to the production of various forms of nucleic acids, proteins, and self-antigens. This, in turn, leads to the production of autoantibodies. In most cases, autoantibodies can be detected years before the start of clinical symptoms. The antibody deposition is then followed by complement-mediated destruction, resulting in tissue damage.

The most common rash seen in SLE is a slightly elevated, photosensitive rash seen around the cheeks and nose (butterfly rash). A few other clinical features include oral ulcers, non-scarring alopecia, and synovitis involving more than two joints. Some immunological features include ANA values more than reference negative values, the presence of Anti-Smith antibodies, low serum complement level, and positive direct Coombs test. 

The presence of at least four criteria with one from each category is a must for diagnosis of SLE, according to the 2012 Systemic Lupus International Collaborating Clinics (SLICC) classification system. 

Other options: 

Option A: The presence of anti-nuclear antibodies is the best screening test for SLE. It is seen in 98% of the cases. Repeated negative tests help to rule out the diagnosis. It has high sensitivity but poor specificity for SLE. 

Option B: Anti-ds DNA antibodies are seen in 70% of the cases. High titers are SLE specific. In a few patients, it indicates disease activity, nephritis, and vasculitis.

Option C: Anti-Smith antibodies are specific for SLE. It is seen more commonly in blacks and Asians than in whites.

More common in black & asians than white

More common in blacks and whites 
Anti-Ro( SS-A) 30 Protein complexed to hY RNA,
Primarily 60kDA and 52kDA		 Not Specific for SLE; associated with sicca syndrome, predisposes to subacute cutaneous lupus & to neonatal lupus with congenital heart block; associated with decrease risk of nephritis

This is not a useful clinical test

questions.text:
A study was conducted in a village with 180 eligible couples, to gather data on the different contraceptive methods used. The data obtained are given below. What is the couple protection rate in the village?

Vasectomy – 15

Tubectomy – 15

Intrauterine device (IUD) users – 8

Oral pill users – 15

Condom users – 7
questions.solution:
Couple protection rate (CPR) is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning. 

In the given scenario, 60 out of 180 eligible couples are using different contraceptive methods. Therefore, CPR = (60/180) x 100 = 33%.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: During dissection, the anatomy professor teaches about the spaces around the shoulder joint. All of the following statements taught by the  professor are true except:

choices.text: Injury to the nerve present in quadrangular space results in difficulty in abduction
Injury to the nerve present in lower triangular space results in wrist drop
The upper triangular space contains circumflex scapular vessels
The quadrangular space of Velpeau is medially bound by short head of triceps

questions.solution:
The quadrangular space of Velpeau is medially bound by the long head of the triceps.

There are 3 spaces around the shoulder joint: triangular space, quadrangular space, and triangular interval.

Triangular space (TS) or upper triangular space:

Boundaries:

  • Superiorly: Subscapularis anteriorly, teres minor posteriorly
  • Laterally: Long head of triceps
  • Inferiorly: Teres major

Contents of the space include circumflex scapular artery(Option C).

Quadrangular space of Velpeau (QS):

Boundaries:

  • Anteriorly: Subscapularis
  • Superiorly: Capsule of the shoulder joint, teres minor
  • Medially: Long head of triceps
  • Inferiorly: Teres major
  • Laterally: Surgical neck of humerus

Contents of the space include axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral vessels. Axillary nerve injury causes difficulty in abduction(Option A).

Triangular interval (TI) or Lower triangular space:

Boundaries:

  • Superiorly: Subscapularis anteriorly, teres major posteriorly
  • Medially: Long head of triceps
  • Laterally: Humerus

Contents of the space include radial nerve and profunda brachii vessels. Radial nerve injury results in wrist drop(Option B).

An easy way to remember these spaces is to represent your 4 fingers as structures around the 3 spaces as shown below.

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors

  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions

questions.text: A middle-aged man was assaulted by his neighbor during an argument. The assailant has admitted that he did assault the victim but did not cause any injury. Which section of the Indian penal code (IPC) can be applied to the assailant?
questions.solution:
The description of the crime fits with assault and the section applicable is section 351 of the IPC.

Section 351 of the IPC - This section defines assault as applying or even attempting to apply force to the body of another individual in a hostile manner. This section can be applied irrespective of whether the assault causes any injury or not. Even hostile gestures such as raising a fist at someone in a hostile manner can constitute assault. Sections 352 to 358 IPC deal with punishments for various types of assaults.

Other options :

Option A- Section 300 of the IPC- This section applies to murder.

Option B- Section 307 of the IPC- This section is applicable in cases of attempt to murder.

Option D- Section 320 of the IPC- This section defines grievous hurt or injury which includes injuries such as:

  • Clause 1 — Emasculation.
  • Clause 2 — Permanent privation of the sight of either eye. 
  • Clause 3 — Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
  • Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint.
  • Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.
  • Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face.
  • Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth.
  • Clause 8 — Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be, during the period of 20 days, in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits.

questions.text: A 25-year-old girl comes to the gynecology clinic with complaints of having a menstrual period at 20-day intervals. Her periods are of 5 days duration, regular, with no history of pain or heavy bleeding. What is this type of menstrual irregularity known as?
questions.solution:
This type of menstrual irregularity is known as polymenorrhea. It denotes frequent episodes of menstruation, occurring at intervals of 21 days or less.

Definitions of various menstrual cycle irregularities:

  • Amenorrhea refers to the absence of menstruation. 
  • Intermenstrual bleeding refers to occasional episodes of bleeding (usually not excessive) that occur between otherwise normal menstrual cycles.
  • Hypomenorrhea refers to regularly timed cycles but having scanty episodes of bleeding.
  • Menorrhagia refers to regularly timed menstrual cycles with excessive bleeding (>80 mL in amount) and/or increased duration of flow (>7 days).
  • Metrorrhagia refers to normal cyclical bleeding with superimposed irregularly timed episodes of bleeding.
  • Menometrorrhagia refers to excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs at irregularly timed and frequent intervals.
  • Oligomenorrhea refers to infrequent, irregularly timed cycles with intervals of more than 35 days.
  • Precocious menstruation refers to the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common triggering factor for the skin lesion shown in the image below?

choices.text: Contact with irritants like poison ivy

questions.solution:
The given image shows characteristic target lesions of Erythema multiforme. It is most commonly associated with a preceding herpes simplex infection (facial or genital).

Target lesions, also known as bull's-eye lesions are a type of rash with a central clearing. They can appear on any part of the body, including the face, upper chest, back, arms, legs, hands, feet, and mucous membranes. They are a typical feature of erythema multiforme, a condition that often resolves in three to six weeks. Erythema multiforme lesions are annular, with a violaceous centre, pink halo, and pale ring. They are usually not painful but may cause a burning sensation. Target lesions are also a typical feature of Lyme disease, where they are known as erythema migrans.

Target lesions have three zones:

  • The central area of dusky erythema or purpura
  • Middle paler zone of edema, and
  • The outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Atypical target lesions have only two of the three zones.

Erythema multiforme is a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis that results from a cell‐mediated hypersensitivity reaction. It presents as a spectrum of macular, papular, or urticarial lesions, as well as the classic form -acral iris or target lesions. These lesions may involve the palms or trunk. The oral and genital mucosa can also be involved, and are associated with erosions.

The common triggers are

  • Herpes simplex infection (most common)
  • Mycoplasma infection
  • Bacterial infections
  • Fungal infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy: carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia (Option B)
  • Drug reactions: sulfonamides, rifampicin, penicillins, hydantoin derivatives (Option C)
  • Miscellaneous: Lupus erythematosus (Rowell Syndrome), Sarcoidosis, Polyarteritis Nodosa

Topical agents like poison ivy can also trigger Erythema multiforme-like reactions but it is not the most common cause (Option A).

The image below shows typical target lesions:

Related Pearl: Erythema multiforme vs. Stevens-Johnson syndrome/Toxic epidermal necrolysis

 

  Erythema multiforme major Stevens-Johnsons Syndrome Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (Lyell syndrome)
% Body Surface-area

<10%

 <10% >30%
Causes Herpes simplex> Mycoplasma infection Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol
Associated Symptoms Less fever and other constitutional symptoms Fever, malaise and headache Fever, malaise and headache
Mucosal Lesions Milder mucosal lesions Severe mucosal involvement Severe mucosal involvement
Lesions Erythematous papules, Target lesions, raised atypical target lesions, occasional bullous lesions

Vesicles on erythematous base, erosions, purpuric macules, Flat atypical target lesions

Nikolsky Sign Positive

Diffuse, generalized epidermal detachment

TEN with spots - with widespread purpuric macules and flat atypical target lesions

TEN without spots- loss of large epidermal sheets without purpuric macules or target lesions

 Nikolsky Sign Positive
Distribution Acral – distal extremities Variable distribution Extensive distribution
Histo-pathology Interface dermatitis – Basal cell vacuolization, apoptotic bodies and inflammatory cells at Dermo-epidermal junction Dermo-epidermal separation, Intense inflammatory cell infiltrates in dermis, some areas of epidermal detachment  Epidermal necrosis, Dermo-epidermal separation, minimal dermal inflammatory cell infiltrate, large areas of epidermal detachment.
Recurrence Common, related to Herpes infections Uncommon, drug-related Uncommon, drug-related
Mortality Rare – recovery in 1 to 4 weeks Elevated mortality Highest mortality

 

Note: Overlap SJS-TEN: There is detachment of 10–30% body surface area, plus widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets.

Erythema Multiforme is regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to infection or drugs.

questions.text:
An ultrasound scan of a 35-year-old woman revealed a unilocular cyst of 5 cm in her ovary. She is asymptomatic. She does not have a family history of breast, ovarian, or colon cancer. She has not received treatment for infertility in the past. CA-125 levels are < 35 U/mL. What is the next best step in her treatment plan?

OCPs - oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a functional cyst in the ovary. Among the given options, the next best step in her treatment plan is to follow up after 1-2 cycles of OCPs. 

A functional cyst is usually asymptomatic, unilocular, and contains clear fluid unless a hemorrhage occurs. In the childbearing period, around 70% of ovarian tumors are functional. They usually regress spontaneously within a few months. It is usually between 3-7 cm in size.

A simple, unilocular cyst of less than 7 cm should be observed. It usually regresses within 4-6 months. Oral contraceptive pills can be prescribed for 3-4 months to women of child-bearing age to hasten its regression. 

A follow-up ultrasound can pick up a persistent cyst. On ultrasound, if any cyst persists for longer than 3 months or its size increases to more than 7 cm, the possibility of malignancy should be investigated. 

Before opting for surgical management, it is important to be certain that the tumor is benign and the other ovary healthy by frozen-section biopsy.

Laparotomy is advised for tumors more than 7 cm to prevent complications or malignant transformation.

In a young woman, in order to conserve the healthy ovary, the ovarian cyst should be enucleated (cystectomy). If this is not possible, ovariotomy should be done. 

Laparoscopic cystectomy–ovariotomy is a minimally invasive surgery done for small ovarian cysts. The other options of treatment are laparoscopy/ ultrasound-guided aspiration and removal of the cyst.

Hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy are recommended in peri-menopausal women, even in the case of benign and unilocular cysts.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman who was a nonsmoker came to the medicine department with complaints of cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. Bronchoscopy suggested a lung carcinoma and biopsy showed a lepidic growth pattern. Which of the following is the most likely immunohistochemical marker for this lesion?

choices.text: Thyroid transcription factor-1 and napsin A

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a non-smoker woman presenting with cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, and lung biopsy showing a lepidic pattern (butterfly on the fence) is suggestive of adenocarcinoma of the lung. Immunohistochemical markers in adenocarcinoma lung are thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) and napsin A.

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer seen in women and nonsmokers. Adenocarcinomas are usually located in the periphery as compared to other lung tumors and are relatively smaller in size. Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia is a precursor lesion of adenocarcinoma. Microscopic examination shows a lepidic pattern of growth at the periphery of the tumor. The tumor cells appear to crawl along the normal-appearing alveolar septa, as shown in the image below.

 

Other options:

Option A: Calretinin and cytokeratin 5/6 positive staining are seen in malignant mesothelioma. It is difficult to differentiate epithelioid mesothelioma grossly and histologically from adenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemical stains help to make this differentiation. The image below shows the epithelioid type of mesothelioma showing cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma. Inset shows strong positivity for calretinin immunohistochemical stain.

 

Option C: p40 and p63 are markers of squamous cell carcinoma lung. It is the most common cancer found in smokers. Histologically it is characterized by the presence of keratinization and markedly eosinophilic cytoplasm as shown below.


Option D: Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers of small cell carcinoma lung. Due to the encrustation by DNA from the necrotic cancer cells, vascular walls in the necrotic area take up basophilic staining as shown below. This is called the Azzopardi effect.

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

 Keratinization, squamous pearls, intercellular bridges Small cells, scant cytoplasm, salt and pepper chromatin, Azzopardi effect
IHC Mucin, TTF-1, Napsin-A p40, p63

Chromogranin, Synaptophysin, and CD56

questions.text: A newborn infant is diagnosed with a congenital urethral abnormality in which the urethral meatus opens on the ventral side of the penis. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: Circumcision is avoided in these patients
Dorsal aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed
Usually associated with a ventral deformity of the erect penis
Does not cause obstruction in the urinary tract

questions.solution:
The ventral aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed ("hooded prepuce") in hypospadias.

Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It is characterized by the combination of a ventrally (underside of penis or perineum) placed urethral meatus, a hooded foreskin, and ventral chordee (bending of the penis).

Types of hypospadias (according to meatal location):

  • Anterior (Distal)
    • Glanular (most common)
    • Coronal
  • Middle
    • Middle penile shaft
    • Distal penile shaft
  • Posterior (Proximal)
    • Proximal penile shaft
    • Penoscrotal
    • Scrotal
    • Perineal

Note:

In hypospadias, ventral chordee is seen, whereas, in epispadias, dorsal chordee is seen.

Circumcision is contraindicated in hypospadias because the foreskin may be used later for reconstruction.

Hypospadias does not cause either obstruction or urinary tract infection.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient comes with complaints of a palpable swelling on her breast. On histopathology examination, dyscohesive infiltrating tumor cells and signet ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets are seen. Immunohistochemistry shows the tumor to be under the luminal group. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of palpable breast mass, with histopathology showing dyscohesive infiltrating tumor cells and signet ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets, is suggestive of invasive lobular carcinoma.

They also show a single file pattern or Indian file pattern on histopathology. Immunohistochemically, lobular carcinoma is a special histologic type that comes under the luminal group, which means that they are ER-positive/HER2-negative. 

The most common genetic abnormality observed in the above lesion is loss of function of the CDH1 gene. The function of the CDH1 gene is to make E-Cadherin protein which makes the cell cohesive. Loss of function makes the cell dyscohesive. 

A histopathology image of invasive lobular carcinoma showing a single file pattern is given below.

 

 

Other options:

Option B- Phyllodes tumor arises from the intralobular stroma and on histology, it appears as increased stromal cellularity with typical leaf-like architecture as shown below.

 

Option C- Fibroadenoma is a benign breast tumor that appears as a delicate and often myxoid stroma that resembles normal intralobular stroma as shown below.

 

Option D- Medullary carcinoma of the breast appears as sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and pushing borders as shown below.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient sustained a head injury in a road traffic accident. During the examination, the patient was unable to recall his name, the name of the place he lives in, or his date of birth. However, he was still able to remember the events such as his marriage. His non-declarative memory is intact. Which of the following areas of the brain is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient had a loss of memory associated with the facts (semantic memory), suggestive of injury to the prefrontal cortex or anterior/lateral temporal cortex.

Forms of memory are classified into two types, explicit and implicit.

Explicit/declarative memory is the memory of factual knowledge about people, places, things, and events. It is associated with consciousness/awareness. They are of two types:

  • Semantic memory (facts) e.g., knowing the capital of India, date of birth, names of people, etc. The parts of the brain involved are the lateral & anterior temporal cortex and prefrontal cortex.
  • Episodic memory (events) e.g., recalling the events that occurred on the first day in college. The parts of the brain involved are the hippocampus, medial temporal lobe, and neocortex. 

Implicit memory/Non-declarative memory does not involve consciousness or awareness. They are of 4 types:

  • Procedural memory refers to skills and habits, which, once acquired, become unconscious and automatic, such as riding a bicycle or driving a car. It is processed in the striatum.
  • Priming refers to the facilitation of the recognition of words or objects by prior exposure to them. It is dependent on the neocortex.
  • Non-associative learning includes habituation and sensitization. It is dependent on various reflex pathways.
  • Associative learning includes classical and operant conditioning in which one learns about the relationship between one stimulus and another. It is dependent on the amygdala for its emotional responses and the cerebellum for the motor responses.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient came to the orthopedics department with complaints of pain in the right leg. He reports a history of a road traffic accident one year back. His X-ray leg is given below. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray shows hypertrophic nonunion of the tibia. The most appropriate treatment is stabilization. 

In the given X-ray, at the site of the fracture, the ends of the bone are enlarged. This suggests osteogenesis is still active or viable. But it is not able to bridge the gap. 

Since it is biologically active, stabilization may lead to the union, and bone grafting is not required.

Stabilization in hypertrophic nonunion is achieved by rigid fixation with a plate and scerw. It can also be treated by the Ilizarov technique with gradual distraction, and realignment by an external fixator. 

In atrophic nonunion, the osteogenesis is absent, X-ray shows tapered bone ends. There will not be new bone formation. Since it is biologically inactive, stabilization with bone grafting (option B) is required. 

Systemic parathyroid hormone therapy like teriparatide is mainly used in atrophic nonunion.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old female patient presents with a bleed in her eye. The patient says that she noticed it in the morning while brushing her hair. She does not recall any events that may have caused it. She does not have a fever or discharge from the eye. She has a history of hypertension that is not adequately managed. Physical examination is unremarkable except for the findings shown in the image. Which of the following statements regarding the underlying diagnosis is false?

NSAIDs - Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs

choices.text: Use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided
Recurrent episodes warrant investigations for a bleeding diathesis or leukemia
If there is no resolution in 1 week, further investigation is necessary

questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and the image showing a homogenous bright red color in the conjunctiva with well-defined limits is suggestive of subconjunctival hemorrhage. The blood gradually changes color and can take 1-3 weeks time to resolve.

A subconjunctival hemorrhage is also called subconjunctival ecchymosis. It is due to the rupture of small blood vessels and can occur spontaneously in elder people with systolic hypertension or after local trauma. They are usually painless.

If the posterior limit is not seen, check for the base of the skull fracture. 

Recurrent episodes warrant investigations for a bleeding diathesis or leukemia. The differential diagnosis includes Kaposi sarcoma.

The use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided since the use of these drugs may increase the risk of subconjunctival hemorrhage.

Artificial tears and ice packs can be used to minimize tissue swelling and provide relief of the discomforts due to subconjunctival hemorrhage.

questions.text: A man who got involved in a road traffic accident after consuming alcohol is brought to the emergency department. What is the minimum blood alcohol concentration to cause impairment of driving skills?
questions.solution:
The minimum blood alcohol concentration to cause impairment of driving skills is 30-50 mg/dL.

This is the reason that in India, the blood alcohol limit is set at 30 mg/dL, measured by a breathalyzer. Anyone driving over that limit is said to be driving under the influence.

The effects of alcohol intoxication at various blood alcohol concentrations are listed below.

Blood alcohol concentration (mg/dL) Effects 
30-50 Impairment of driving and similar skills
50-100 Reduced inhibitions, slurred speech, laughter
100-150 Incoordination, ataxia
150-200 Obvious drunkenness, nausea, staggering gait
200-300 Vomiting, stupor
300-350 Stupor, coma, risk of aspirating vomitus
350-450 and above Danger of death from respiratory paralysis

questions.text: A 1-year-old male baby presents with a history of fever, irritability, and vomiting. On examination, there is moderate hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of serum transaminases and elevated levels of succinylacetone in serum and urine. Which enzyme is deficient in this baby?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and laboratory findings are diagnostic of tyrosinemia type I and the enzyme deficient is fumarylacetoacetate hydroxylase (FAH).

Tyrosinemia type I or Hepatorenal tyrosinemia is caused by FAH deficiency. It is an autosomal recessive disease, caused by a defective FAH gene. This results in the accumulation of fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone which are metabolites of tyrosine degradation. The tissues most affected are hepatic, renal, and nervous tissues. The manifestations of these can be seen in the form of an acute hepatic crisis, such as in this case. They may also present with peripheral neuropathy resembling acute porphyria. Renal involvement is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia, and vitamin D-resistant rickets.

Boiled cabbage odor may be present in classical type 1 tyrosinemia resulting from increased methionine metabolites (sulfur-containing compounds). Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of hypermethioninemia.

The diagnosis can be established by the demonstration of elevated levels of succinylacetone in urine or blood. The treatment of choice is nitisinone (NTBC) which reduces the formation of fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone by inhibiting the degradation of tyrosine. However, this increases the plasma levels of tyrosine. A diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine is also prescribed to patients.

Other options:

Option B: Tyrosine aminotransferase is deficient in tyrosinemia type II (Richner-Hanhart syndrome or oculocutaneous tyrosinemia). It is also an autosomal recessive disease that results in hyperkeratosis, herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability. The laboratory finding here is marked hypertyrosinemia and elevated 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid. The treatment here also involves a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine.

Option C: 4-hydroxy-phenyl pyruvate dioxygenase deficiency causes type III tyrosinemia (neonatal tyrosinemia). Patients might rarely have a mental disability. The liver function is generally normal. Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to deficiency of 4-hydroxy-phenyl pyruvate dioxygenase.

Option D: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency causes phenylketonuria. It manifests as progressive intellectual disability. The diagnosis is made by measurement of plasma phenylalanine levels or by detecting phenyl ketones in the urine. A diet low in phenylalanine is the mainstay of treatment. 

The steps and enzymes of tyrosine metabolism are shown below.
