questions.text: A 15-year-old female presented with complaints of primary amenorrhea to the gynaecology OPD. O/E, she had normal breast development, scanty pubic and axillary hair. Hormonal assays were sent. What is the karyotype of the patient with the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) and the karyotype in this is 46 XY.

AIS (formerly called testicular feminization syndrome) occurs due to mutations in the androgen receptor causing resistance to the effects of androgen. 

Individuals with AIS can have partial or complete AIS. Those with complete AIS have the following features:

  • Female phenotype
  • Normal breast development
  • Blind-ended vagina
  • Absent uterus and ovaries
  • Scanty pubic and axillary hair

The serum level of hormones like gonadotropins and testosterone is variable. They depend on both the degree of resistance as well as the contribution of estradiol to feedback inhibition. 

Most patients present with

  • Inguinal hernias (containing testes) in childhood
  • Primary amenorrhea in late adolescence

Gonadectomy is a recommended course of treatment due to the possible risks of malignancy. The procedure can be scheduled after the individual develops breasts. 

Other options: 

Option A - 45 XO is the karyotype is seen in patients with Turner's syndrome.

Option B - 46 XX is the karyotype for a phenotypically normal female. 

Option D - 47 XXY is the karyotype seen in Klinefelter's syndrome.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is found to be hypotonic. On examination, there is a large anterior fontanelle and hepatomegaly. Further investigations confirmed a diagnosis of the cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome. Which of the following is not a biochemical finding in this case?

choices.text: Elevated levels of very long chain fatty acids

questions.solution:
Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome (Zellweger syndrome) shows a marked reduction of plasmalogens, not elevated plasmalogens.

Plasmalogens belong to a class of glycerophospholipids. They make up about 10 mol percent of total phospholipids. In humans, they are primarily found as membrane structure components. Their synthesis is impaired in Zellweger syndrome. 

Zellweger syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX (Peroxins) family of genes. As a result of this, there is a defective transport of the proteins to the peroxisomes. This results in defective beta-oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA), defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

Biochemical findings will show accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids (option A), phytanic acid (option B), abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids (option C), and marked reduction of plasmalogens.

The child presents with dysmorphic facial features like large anterior fontanelles, hypoplastic supraorbital ridges, micrognathia, and redundant nucha skin folds. Profound developmental delay, profound hypotonia with depressed deep tendon reflexes, neonatal seizures, and impaired hearing are seen. Other observed abnormalities are calcific stippling of the epiphysis, renal cysts, and liver cirrhosis.

There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe and infants rarely survive beyond six months of age.

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with skin lesions over the dorsum of the hand as shown below. On examination, the lesions are firm papules with a rough horny surface. What is the most common causative agent of these lesions?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing multiple firm papules with a rough horny surface on the dorsum are suggestive of Verruca vulgaris or a common wart. The most common causative agent of common wart is the Human Papillomavirus-2 (HPV-2).

Verruca vulgaris or common wart is most commonly caused by HPV-2  but also by the closely related types 27, 57, and types 1 and 4. It is predominantly seen in adolescence and early adulthood and usually presents with firm papules with a rough horny surface.

 The most common sites in adults are the dorsum of the hand and fingers. However, in children, the common site is the knees. Lesions present on palmar aspects of the fingers may be tender when fissured or when growing beneath the nail plate. New lesions can appear at sites of trauma which are called Koebner-like isomorphic phenomena. 

Other options:

HPV-3 and HPV-10 mainly cause plane (flat) warts or verruca plana. HPV 16 and 18 are associated with anogenital warts and cervical cancers. HPV 11 are the causative agent of anogenital warts, laryngeal papillomas, verrucous carcinoma.

questions.text: A patient was started on a drug for the treatment of glaucoma. He came to the ophthalmological outpatient department with a change in the appearance of his eyes, as shown in the given image. Identify the mechanism of action of the drug he was taking.
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of iris pigmentation, which is seen as a side-effect of topical prostaglandin analogs such as latanoprost and bimatoprost. The mechanism of action of these drugs is increased uveoscleral outflow.

Other side effects of topical prostaglandins:

  • Brown pigmentation of iris and eyelash
  • Dry eyes
  • Macular edema
  • Blurred vision
  • Thickening and darkening of eyelashes(Hypertrichosis)

The main classes of drugs used in glaucoma and their respective mechanism of action are illustrated below:

questions.text: Which of the following stimuli decreases antidiuretic hormone secretion?
questions.solution:
A decrease in plasma osmolarity decreases the antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion. 

Osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus rapidly detect the change in osmolarity of extracellular fluid and they control the secretion of ADH.

A decrease in blood volume, blood pressure, and blood oxygenation (hypoxia) increase ADH secretion.

The two magnocellular neurons of the hypothalamus which synthesize ADH are supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei. Five-sixth of ADH is produced by supraoptic nuclei and one-sixth by paraventricular nuclei. 

ADH exerts its antidiuretic action by activation of  V2 receptors and insertion of aquaporin 2 into the luminal side of the collecting duct.

Whenever blood pressure and low blood volume are reduced as in a situation like a hemorrhage, ADH secretion is increased. This results in fluid reabsorption by the kidney and restores the blood pressure and blood volume to normal.

Nausea is a potent stimulus for ADH secretion. 

Increased ADH Decreased ADH

Increased plasma osmolarity

 Decreased plasma osmolarity
Decreased blood pressure Increased blood pressure
Decreased blood volume Increased blood volume
Nausea Drugs: alcohol, clonidine
Hypoxia  
Drugs: morphine, nicotine

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient was diagnosed with extensive AIDS-related Kaposi sarcoma and was started on an anticancer drug given intravenously. She had undergone radiotherapy for breast cancer two years back. She now presents with erythema, desquamation, and local skin reaction on the chest area. Identify the given anticancer drug that is responsible for this reaction.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of radiation recall syndrome and the given anticancer drug is doxorubicin.

In the given clinical scenario, there is the development of local reaction in a previously irradiated area, after 2 years is suggestive of radiation recall syndrome. Intravenous liposomal doxorubicin is used in the treatment of AIDS-related Kaposi sarcoma.

Radiation recall syndrome is an acute inflammatory response confined to the areas that are previously irradiated, which can be triggered by the administration of chemotherapeutic agents. Studies show that the common drugs causing this phenomenon are:

  • Doxorubicin
  • Dactinomycin
  • Docetaxel and paclitaxel
  • Gemcitabine and capecitabine

Radiation sensitization - This is more common than radiation recall. This is a period of enhanced sensitivity in the days after irradiation when the reaction to systemically administered drugs and the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is <7 days. Such reactions can be considered radiation enhancement or sensitization. 

Radiation recall - This is less common than radiation sensitization. When the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is >7 days, months, or even years.

The major side effects of doxorubicin are: 

  • The dose-limiting complication is myelosuppression with maximal leukopenia.
  • Stomatitis, mucositis and alopecia.
  • The long-term toxicity is cardiomyopathy.

Note: Cyclophosphamide when given as a combination with 5-Fluorouracil and epirubicin can cause radiation recall syndrome.

questions.text: You are performing the test shown in the image on a patient. How many days later do you ask the patient to return so that you get an accurate read on the Mitsuda reaction?
questions.solution:
Mitsuda's reaction is read in the 3rd week, i.e., on the 21st day or 20 days after the day of injection.

Lepromin test is a skin test for delayed hypersensitivity to lepra antigens. It is the only method for studying immunity in leprosy. A bacillary suspension of inactivated M. leprae is injected just under the skin.

The first reaction to occur is the early reaction of Fernandez, which consists of erythema and induration developing in 24-48 hours. It usually remains for 3-5 days; it is usually poorly defined and carries less significance. The second and more meaningful result is the late reaction of Mitsuda, starting at 1-2 weeks (7-10 days), reaching a peak in three or four weeks, and gradually subsiding over the next few weeks. On the 21st day, if there is a nodule more than 5 mm in diameter, the reaction is said to be positive. 

Note: The 21st day is 20 days after the day of injection which is counted as the 1st day.

questions.text: You notice the following equipment in the principal biomedical waste handling facility. This equipment is used for the treatment of all the following, except ____

choices.text: Waste sharps such as needles and syringes

questions.solution:
The given image shows an incinerator. Incineration is used for the treatment of all the listed wastes, except waste sharps such as needles and syringes.

In incineration, the biomedical waste material is exposed to a very high temperature inside the incinerator, converting the material into ash. This method is used to dispose of human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste (contaminated dressings, plaster casts, cotton swabs), expired or discarded medicines, microbiological and clinical laboratory waste, etc. It is expensive and is generally used only by very large establishments. 

Waste sharps such as needles and syringes are sterilized by autoclaving, followed by shredding, mutilation, or encapsulation in a metal container or cement concrete. They are then sent for final disposal to iron foundries.

Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization. The autoclave is a device that uses steam under pressure to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, surgical instruments, cardiac catheters, and implants. The image given below shows an autoclave:

questions.text: An emergency thoracotomy is being conducted for a patient who had a penetrated chest trauma as shown below. During the procedure due to inadequate cardiac output, an open cardiac massage is performed. This cardiac massage can be classified as ______.
questions.solution:
Open cardiac massage is classified as a contaminated wound.

Contaminated wounds are class III surgical wounds. They include fresh open accidental wounds, surgeries with a major break in sterile technique, gross spillage of the gastrointestinal tract, or incision through an inflamed nonpurulent tissue. Examples include:

  • Open cardiac massage
  • Penetrating abdominal trauma

Surgical wounds are classified based on the expected amount of bacterial load at the time of surgery. 

Open cardiac massage is performed when there is inadequate cardiac output, after emergency thoracotomy for penetrating chest trauma, during pericardial tamponade.

Class I surgical wounds are clean wounds (option D). They are noninfected surgical wounds without any inflammation. Examples include:

  • Hernia repair
  • Breast biopsy specimen

Class II surgical wounds are clean/contaminated wounds (option A). They are surgical wounds that include an entry hollow viscus such as the respiratory tract or gastrointestinal tract under controlled conditions without significant spillage. Examples include:

  • Cholecystectomy
  • Elective gastrointestinal surgery

Class IV surgical wounds are dirty wounds (option C). They are old traumatic wounds with the presence of necrotic tissue and perforated viscus with a heavy load of contamination. Examples include:

  • Perforated diverticulitis
  • Necrotizing soft tissue infection

Related Pearl: Surgical wound classifications as defined by ACS NSOP

  • Clean: Uninfected operative wounds in which no inflammation is encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered
  • Clean/Contaminated: Operative wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination
  • Contaminated: Open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks insterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered
  • Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera

questions.text:
A patient presents with complaints of hematuria and hemoptysis. His renal biopsy showed crescentic glomerular lesions suggestive of RPGN. Immunofluorescence findings are given in the image below. Which type of RPGN is this condition classified as?

RPGN - Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the immunofluorescence showing a linear, smooth diffuse pattern of staining is suggestive of Goodpasture syndrome, which is classified under type I RPGN.

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a clinical entity with features of nephritic syndrome and rapid loss of renal function. It is a syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and the formation of crescents, but it does not denote a specific etiologic form of glomerulonephritis.

In most cases, RPGN is immune-mediated. Circulating anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) are detected in the pauci-immune type of RPGN. Serum analyses for anti-GBM antibodies, antinuclear antibodies, and ANCAs are helpful in the diagnosis of specific subtypes

Based on immunologic findings, RPGN is classified as:

Anti-GBM antibody-mediated disease (Type I) is characterized by linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3 on immunofluorescence and includes renal limited disease and Goodpasture's disease. Here, the antibodies are produced against a peptide present in the noncollagenous domain of the α3 chain of collagen IV of the GBM. This serves as the antigen which is common to the alveoli and the glomerulus.

Immune complex deposition (Type II) is characterized by granular deposits of antibodies and complement on immunofluorescence and can be a complication of any of the immune complex nephritides which include:

  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  • Lupus nephritis
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura

Pauci-immune (Type III) exhibits no characteristic immunoglobulin or complement deposits on immunofluorescence. It includes

  • ANCA-associated
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • Microscopic polyangiitis

Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disease affecting men more than women, with simultaneous hemorrhagic interstitial pneumonitis and rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis. The GBM antigen is a component of the noncollagenous domain of the α3 chain of type IV collagen, which is common to both alveoli and glomeruli.

On microscopy, the renal biopsy shows show linear GBM fluorescence for Ig and complement. Electron microscopy (EM) shows the wrinkling of the glomerular basement membrane with focal disruptions without any immune complex deposition.

questions.text: During routine dissection classes, you and your friend are discussing the cadaveric specimen of the inferior surface of the liver. Which of the following lobe is referred to as segment I?
questions.solution:
The lobe marked as '3' in the above image represents the caudate lobe which is referred to as segment I.

Couinaud's segmental division of the liver is the functional division based on the portal venous branches in the parenchyma. They are divided into 8 functional segments. The caudate lobe corresponds to segment I of Couinaud's segments.

The caudate lobe of the liver has a portal blood supply and hepatic vein drainage independent of the remainder of the liver and also forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen. 

The caudate lobe is visible as prominent on the inferior and posterior surfaces of the liver. It lies posterior to the porta hepatis and to its right is the groove for the inferior vena cava.

Other markings:

1-Quadrate lobe

2-Right lobe

4-Left Lobe

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient comes for a follow-up after a transient ischaemic attack (TIA) one week back. He complains of not being able to name anything. On examination, he understands and talks normally, but he is unable to repeat the words told to him. Which structure is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The structure affected in this patient is the arcuate fasciculus.

The above clinical features are suggestive of conduction aphasia as his comprehension of spoken language and speech fluency is intact with repetition being impaired. Naming is impaired here. The site of lesion usually affected in conduction aphasia is the arcuate fasciculus.

Arcuate fasciculus is short association fibres that connect the temporal cortex and inferior parietal cortex to the frontal lobe. One of its important connections is that between the Broca's area and Wernicke's area.

Association fibres: They connect various cortical areas within the same hemisphere. They are classified as:

  1. Short association fibres: they connect adjacent gyri. Example: Arcuate fasciculus
  2. Long association fibres: they connect gyri from one lobe to another lobe. Example:
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Fornix 

Other options: 

Option B- Broca's area (Brodmann area 44, 45) is present in the inferior frontal lobe of the dominant cerebral hemisphere. Lesion to this area results in Broca's aphasia or motor aphasia. In Broca's aphasia, comprehension of language is intact, speech fluency, repetition and naming are impaired.

Option C- Wernicke's area (Brodmann's area 22) corresponds to the supramarginal gyrus within the inferior parietal lobule of the dominant cerebral hemisphere. Lesion to this area results in Wernicke's aphasia or sensory aphasia. In Wernicke's aphasia, comprehension of language, repetition and naming are impaired. Speech fluency is increased associated with new words (neologism) resulting in jargon aphasia.

Option D- Middle longitudinal fasciculus is an association fibre in the superior temporal gyrus connecting angular gyrus (area 39) with the superior temporal gyrus (area 22). It plays a role in linguistic processing with information dealing with the spatial organization, memory, and motivational valence.

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

  Comprehension Repetition of Spoken language Naming Fluency
Wernicke's Impaired Impaired Impaired Preserved
Broca's Preserved Impaired Impaired Decreased
Global Impaired Impaired Impaired Decreased
Conduction Preserved Impaired Impaired Preserved
Anterior (nonfluent) transcortical Preserved Preserved Impaired Impaired
Posterior (fluent) transcortical Impaired Preserved Impaired Preserved
Isolation Impaired Echolalia Impaired No purposeful speech
Anomic Preserved Preserved Impaired Preserved except for word finding pauses
Pure Word Deafness Impaired only for spoken language Impaired Preserved Preserved
Pure Alexia Impaired only for reading Preserved Preserved  Preserved

questions.text: Which of the following steps of disaster management is in correct order?
questions.solution:
The correct order is Disaster impact – Response – Rehabilitation – Mitigation.

Disaster management includes three aspects:

1. Disaster impact and response: It involves immediate management of mass casualties as follows:

  • Search, rescue, and first-aid
  • Field care
  • Triage
  • Tagging
  • Identification of dead

2. Rehabilitation or recovery: It involves the restoration of the pre-disaster conditions by taking steps such as:

  • Water supply
  • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene
  • Food safety
  • Vector control

3. Mitigation: Measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing disaster or to reduce the effects of the disaster. This also includes preparedness for any impending disasters or in disaster-prone areas.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes with complaints of nasal stuffiness, watery discharge, and small grape-like masses protruding from both nostrils. He had similar complaints for which he was operated on  5 years ago. He has a history of dust allergy. On examination, multiple, pale masses are seen which do not bleed on probing. Which of these sites is unlikely to be the site of origin of these masses?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ethmoidal nasal polyposis which does not originate from the maxillary sinus.

Ethmoidal polyps originate from the ethmoidal sinus, uncinate process, and the middle turbinate and middle meatus. Antrochoanal polyps are known to originate from the maxillary sinus. 

In the given scenario, the age of the patient, the presence of multiple, bilateral grape-like masses at the nostrils points towards the diagnosis of the ethmoidal polyp. The history of allergy on dust exposure and the history of recurrence are also more common in ethmoidal polyps.

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

Related Pearl: Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy
  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually single and unilateral
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice
  • Findings:
    • Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy
    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation: Nasal endoscopy: Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated. NonContrast CT scan: Gives exquisite bony detail of the paranasal sinus anatomy. It is the primary diagnostic imaging modality.
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: During a surgical procedure, the surgeon noticed small nodules occurring near the upper pole of the epididymis of the left testis. It was grossly well-circumscribed, and he immediately sent a specimen from the lesion for histopathological examination. What is the most common benign paratesticular tumor he would suspect?
questions.solution:
The adenomatoid tumor is the most common benign paratesticular tumor.

Adenomatoid tumors are mesothelial in origin. They are usually seen as small nodules, typically occurring near the upper pole of the epididymis.

Grossly, they are well-circumscribed, but microscopically they can be minimally invasive into the adjacent testis. Adenomatoid tumor is one of the few benign tumors that occur near the testis.

Other options:

Option A- Liposarcoma is the most common malignant paratesticular tumor in adults. 

Option C- Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common malignant paratesticular tumor in children.

Option D- Adenosarcoma is a rare benign endometrial stromal tumor.  

Note:

The paratesticular region includes the contents of the spermatic cord, testicular tunics, and epididymis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to you with complaints of dryness in the mouth and eyes. Serum reveals positivity for anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies. The test shown in the image below was positive with a score of < 5 mm in 5 minutes without anesthesia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The test shown above is Schirmer's test and the likely diagnosis is Sjögren's syndrome. 

Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that involves lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands. This manifests as xerostomia (dry mouth) and keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes). It is associated with autoantibodies anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B.

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca can be diagnosed by Schirmer's test. This test measures the quantity of tears produced. Two marked strips of paper are placed between the globe and the lower eyelid and the patient is instructed to close their eyes for 5 minutes. The tears produced spread along the paper by capillary action. The distance is measured. A score of more than 10 mm is considered to be normal while that of less than 5 mm is considered deficient. 

A number of other systems can be involved as well. For example, atrophic gastritis, esophageal mucosal atrophy, and vaginal dryness. Extraglandular or systemic manifestations can also be present. These manifest as fatigue, arthritis, Raynaud's phenomenon, and myalgia. 

Diagnosis of primary Sjögren's syndrome requires the following: 

  • Eye and/or mouth dryness
  • Eye tests disclose keratoconjunctivitis sicca
  • Mouth evaluation reveals dry oral mucosa and/or
  • Presence of anti-Ro or anti-La autoantibodies

A labial biopsy is a must to confirm the diagnosis and determine the prognosis. 

Treatment of Sjögren's syndrome is directed at treating the symptoms and complications. Artificial tears can be used for dry eyes and propionic acid gel for vaginal dryness. Pilocarpine can help increase oral secretions and hydroxychloroquine can be used to treat arthritis. 

Other options: 

Option A - Scleroderma is associated with xerostomia. However, it is more classically represented by skin thickening, telangiectasia, and lung and renal involvement. In addition, it has anti-topoisomerase and anti-centromere antibodies. 

Option B - Dehydration can present with dry mouth. However, anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies are not involved. 

Option C - Sarcoidosis is a multisystemic inflammatory disease characterized by noncaseating granulomas. Ocular manifestations of sarcoidosis include anterior uveitis, retinitis, and pars planitis. Patients would have increased tearing. 

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

  • Non-specific
    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: A young man with a history of a respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago, is unable to stand or walk for the past 2 weeks. His weakness began in the toes and ankles and progressed to involve his knee and hip joints. His upper limbs are not affected and cranial nerves are intact. On examination, there is an absent knee jerk. Which of the following would you consider as the initial therapy?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario depicting progressive, ascending, symmetrical weakness following a respiratory infection is suggestive of Guillain Barre syndrome (GBS). Intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) would be considered as the initial therapy in this patient.

GBS is an acute, fulminant polyradiculoneuropathy that is autoimmune in nature. Most of the cases occur after a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. GBS is caused when immune response/antibodies are produced against external antigens like infections (Campylobacter jejuni, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, HHV) and vaccines (Influenza). These autoantibodies target similar proteins present in the person's nervous tissue (called molecular mimicry).

GBS manifests as a rapidly evolving motor paralysis with areflexia (or hyporeflexia) with or without sensory disturbance. It is an ascending paralysis that affects the lower limbs more than the upper limbs. It can also affect the cranial nerves leading the bulbar paralysis like difficulty articulating words and excessive drooling.

igh-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis are equally effective for typical GBS. IVIg is the initial therapy chosen because of its ease of administration and good safety record. It contains anti-idiotypic antibodies against autoantibodies. It is administered as five daily infusions for a total dose of 2 g/kg body weight.

Other options: 

Option B - Mechanical ventilation is reserved for those who develop respiratory insufficiency or patients who develop early bulbar weakness. This patient has no bulbar weakness (normal cranial nerves).

Option C - Corticosteroid administration has not been shown to provide many benefits in GBS. 

Option D - Antibiotic administration would not be useful in GBS as the pathophysiology involves axonal degeneration due to a immune cause, not infective. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

Related Pearl: Sensory Loss In peripheral Neuropathies

Symmetrical Sensory Loss

  • Cryptogenic or idiopathic sensory polyneuropathy (CSPN)
  • Diabetes mellitus and other metabolic disorders
  • Drugs and toxins
  • Familial (HSAN), CMT, amyloidosis
  • Inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (GBS and CIDP) 

Asymmetrical Sensory Loss

  • Cancer (paraneoplastic)
  • Sjögren’s syndrome
  • Idiopathic sensory neuronopathy (possible GBS variant)
  • Cisplatin and other chemotherapeutic agents
  • Vitamin B6 toxicity
  • Multifocal CIDP, vasculitis, cryoglobulinemia, amyloidosis, sarcoid, infectious (leprosy, Lyme, hepatitis B, C, or E, HIV, CMV), tumor infiltration 
  • Compressive mononeuropathy, plexopathy, or radiculopathy
  • Polyradiculopathy or plexopathy due to diabetes mellitus
  • Cryptogenic or idiopathic sensory polyneuropathy (CSPN)

questions.text: A 62-year-old female patient presented with a 1 cm black-brown pigmented lesion on the face which is growing rapidly in size as shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 1 cm pigmented lesion which is asymmetrical, with an irregular border, made of black and brown pigments, and growing rapidly in size, point towards a diagnosis of malignant melanoma. 

Melanoma is a malignant tumor originating from melanocytes. They are predominantly seen in men of age more than 60 years. The diagnostic clue for melanoma is the ABCD criteria. It comprises of:

  • Asymmetry
  • Border irregularity
  • Color variegation
  • Diameter more than 6 mm
  • Evolution

Melanoma is mainly classified into four types:

  • Superficial spreading melanoma (most common subtype)
  • Nodular melanoma
  • Lentigo maligna melanoma
  • Acral letigomatous melanoma

The gold standard for the diagnosis of melanoma is histopathological examination.

Histopathology shows individual melanoma cells which are larger than normal melanocytes. They have large nuclei with irregular contours, chromatin is characteristically clumped at the periphery of the nuclear membrane with prominent red eosinophilic nucleoli.

All tumors have a vertical and radial phase of growth and the appearance of melanocytes is similar in both phases. The vertical growth has is often preceded by the appearance of a nodule. This is often indicative of the development of a tumor variant with metastatic potential.

Image of melanoma in radial growth phase, showing irregularly nested and single-cell growth of melanoma cells within the epidermis and an underlying inflammatory response within the dermis:

Breslow index is used to measure the distance between the superficial granular layer to the deepest level of invasion. This helps in the determination of prognosis.

Wide local excision is done after the diagnosis by histopathological examination.

Other options:

Option A- Becker nevus is a hyperpigmented hairy patch. The shoulder, back, and proximal portion of the upper limb are the most common site involved. Mostly seen in males before puberty. 

The image below shows a becker nevus.

Option B- Nevus of Ota is a blue-black macule usually present since birth. Conjunctiva, sclera, and skin supplied by the trigeminal nerve are the most common site involved. They are present throughout life.

The below image shows the nevus of Ota.

Option C- Congenital melanocytic nevus may be small, medium, or large size(>20cm). They are dark pigmented hairy patches and present since birth. Large melanocytic nevus has a risk of melanoma growth.

The below image shows the congenital melanocytic nevus. 

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

Related Pearl: Breslow’s Classification of Malignant Melanoma

Breslow's classification of malignant melanoma:

Stage Depth
Stage I ≤ 0.75mm
Stage II 0.76 mm - 1.50mm
Stage III 1.51 mm - 4 mm
Stage IV >4 mm

 

TNM staging based on the thickness of invasion according to AJCC:

  • T1 - ≤1.0 mm
  • T2 - 1.01-2.0 mm
  • T3 - 2.01-4.0 mm
  • T4 - >4.0 mm

questions.text: Where does the primary tendinosis occur in tennis elbow?
questions.solution:
In tennis elbow, primary tendinosis occurs at 1-2 cm distal to the attachment of extensor carpi radialis brevis muscle to the lateral epicondyle. 

 

Tennis elbow is also known as lateral epicondylitis. This is the most common tendinopathy. It is caused by repetitive contraction of extensor muscles at lateral epicondyle in activities that require repetitive forceful wrist extension and supination. 

It is common in individuals who play tennis, squash, and badminton. The pain improves on rest.

Conservative management with physiotherapy will speed up the recovery. Steroid injections can be used for short-term pain relief. Arthroscopic surgery technique can be used, but it has a higher risk of nerve injury.

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in the tennis elbow
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

Related Pearl: Important conditions of the elbow:

         Condition    Description      

Tennis elbow

Lateral epicondylitis involving common extensor origin

Golfer's elbow

Medial epicondylitis involving the common flexor-pronator origin

Baseball pitcher's elbow

Damage to the bones or soft tissue attached around the elbow due to repeated vigorous throwing activities. Hypertrophy of the lower humerus and incongruity of the joint, or loose body formation and osteoarthritis

Little leaguer's elbow

 Partial avulsion of the medial epicondyle

Javelin thrower's elbow

 Avulsion of the tip of olecranon due to overarm action

Student's elbow/Miner's elbow

 Olecranon bursitis

Pulled elbow/Nurse maid's elbow

 Downward dislocation of the radial head from the annular ligament

questions.text: A patient has a dead space of 150 mL, a functional residual capacity of 3L, tidal volume of 650 mL, expiratory reserve volume of 1.5 L, a total lung capacity of 8L, respiratory rate of 15 breaths/min. What is the rate of alveolar ventilation?
questions.solution:
The rate of alveolar ventilation in this patient is 7.5 L/min.

Alveolar ventilation per minute is the total volume of new air entering the alveoli and adjacent gas exchange areas each minute. It is equal to the respiratory rate times the amount of new air that enters these areas with each breath.

Alveolar ventilation=Respiratory rate X (Tidal volume – Physiologic dead space)

                               = 15 X (650-150)

                               = 7500mL/min or 7.5L/min.

questions.text: A middle-aged hypertensive man presents with acute onset pain and swelling on his toe over the left foot. Local examination showed a swelling over the first metatarsophalangeal joint of the left foot, as shown below. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs can be safely administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with acute onset pain and swelling over the first metatarsophalangeal joint of the left foot suggests the diagnosis of acute gout. Losartan can be safely administered to this patient as it is a uricosuric drug.

Losartan is competitive angiotensin I (AT1) receptor antagonist, which binds to the AT1 receptor with high affinity. Uses of losartan are:

  • Antihypertensive
  • Renoprotective drug in diabetes mellitus
  • Stroke prophylaxis
  • Portal hypertension in cirrhosis without compromising renal function
  • Anti-aggregant as it is a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor 
  • Uricosuric drug as it inhibits reabsorption and actively secretes uric acid in the proximal convoluted tubule

Adverse effects include fetopathic potential, hypotension, renal insufficiency, and hyperkalemia. 

Other options:

Option B: Atenolol is a beta blocker that has been proven to increase serum uric acid levels; hence, it is avoided.

Option C: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic; it is not used in patients with gout as it increases the uric acid level.

Option D: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that causes hyperuricemia due to increased reabsorption of uric acid. It is not used in patients with gout.

Related Pearl: Drugs precipitating Gout

Drugs that precipitate gout are-

Cyclosporine or cancer drugs
Aspirin (low dose)
Niacin
Thiazide
Lasix (furosemide)
Ethambutol
Alcohol
Pyrazinamide

Mnemonic for drugs precipitating gout is 'CANT LEAP'

questions.text: A young patient comes to the emergency with pain in the right leg after falling from a height. The radiological image shows a physeal injury fracture extending to epiphysis. What is the type of Salter-Harris physeal injury mentioned above?
questions.solution:
The type of Salter-Harris injury mentioned above is type III injury.

Type II fracture is an intraarticular fracture. In a type III Salter harris fracture, the fracture splits the epiphysis and divides transversely to the other side through the hypertrophic layer of the physis. This damages the growth plate and results in growth disturbance. 

The fracture lower end of the tibia is an example of a Salter-Harris type 3 fracture.

Salter-Harris type III fracture needs an accurate reduction to restore the joint surface.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: What clinical test is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
The clinical test depicted in the image is Cottle’s test where the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. 

This test is used to assess the patency of the nasal valve in patients with a deviated nasal septum. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve on that side.

Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV.

 

Option B: Heimlich manoeuvre is used in the treatment of accidental inhalation of foreign body. Procedure: Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs can dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.

 

Option D: Trotter’s method is used in the treatment of epistaxis. In Trotter’s method, the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood. He should pinch the nose firmly for 5 to 10 mins and breathe quietly from the mouth.

questions.text: A male patient came to your clinic with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness and tiredness throughout the day. He says that he gets sudden attacks of sleep while he talks to his clients at the office. Which of the following is unlikely to be found associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of narcolepsy. Somniloquy is unlikely to be found associated with this condition.

Somniloquy is the unconscious speech during sleep. It may accompany other sleep disorders like night terror and sleepwalking.

Narcolepsy is marked by sleep attacks leading to 10-20 minutes of sleep. After this, the patient feels refreshed but remains tired throughout the rest of the day. It can happen at inappropriate times such as while working, eating, talking, or driving. The onset is usually between the ages of 10-20 years, after which it persists for life.

Cataplexy (sudden muscle weakness), hypnopompic (hallucinations upon awakening), or hypnagogic (hallucinations at the onset of sleep) hallucinations are associated features. Sleep paralysis may also be seen, in which the patient upon awakening will be unable to move his muscles.

A polysomnogram and multiple sleep latency tests are done to diagnose the condition. Modafinil, methylphenidate, and venlafaxine are the drugs used in the management.

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

Nocturnal enuresis

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

 

Events occurring in REM sleep:

Events

Description

Nightmares

Fearful sleep without autonomic disturbances that are well remembered in the morning.

TCAs may be used for treatment.

Nocturnal penile tumescence

A normal phenomenon that can be used to differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Narcolepsy

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

Associated with symptoms such as cataplexy, hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.

 *Hypnogogic hallucinations are those that occur at the start of sleep and hypnopompic hallucinations are those that occur at the end of sleep.

 

Others:

Events

Description

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Frontal lobe epilepsy

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep talking

Occurs in all stages of sleep and may accompany night terrors and sleepwalking.

Common in children.

No treatment is necessary.

questions.text: A boy was taken away from his guardian without his guardian's consent. This will constitute as 'kidnapping' in India if the boy's age is under _____.
questions.solution:
Taking away the male child below the age of 16 years without the consent of his guardian constitutes kidnapping.

According to Section 361 IPC, whoever takes or entices any male under 16 years of age and any female under 18 years of age commits the crime of kidnapping.

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her 18-year-old daughter for a psychiatric evaluation as she has no friends and is overly fascinated by magical thoughts.  She also believes she has superpowers. What is the most likely type of personality disorder she has?
questions.solution:
The most likely personality disorder based on the clinical features is schizotypal personality disorder.

Inability to maintain close relationships, magical thinking, and a belief that they possess superpowers are suggestive of schizotypal personality disorder.

A schizotypal personality disorder is a cluster A personality disorder. It is characterized by strange perceptions, disturbed thinking, and behavior. They tend to have magical thinking, bizarre fantasies, and preoccupations, such as excessive superstition. Pscytherapy is the first line treatment for pateints for schizotypal personality disorder.

Personality disorders are divided into three clusters:

  • Cluster A: Schizotypal, schizoid, and paranoid
  • Cluster B: Narcissistic, borderline, antisocial, and histrionic
  • Cluster C: Obsessive-compulsive, dependent, and avoidant

Other options:

Option A: Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by extreme sensitivity to rejection and leads a socially withdrawn life but a strong desire for relationships.

Option B: Narcissistic personality disorder is marked by a heightened sense of self-importance. Individuals with this personality disorder display a lack of empathy and grandiose feelings. This is to mask their fragile self-esteem and vulnerability.

Option C- Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by a tendency for social withdrawal, isolation, and introversion. They tend to take up jobs that require minimal interpersonal interaction. They are emotionally detached, aloof, and avoid eye contact. 

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his friends after becoming aggressive at a party. He says he is hearing the voices of an invisible person. On examination, he is confused, agitated, and keeps on grimacing. Pupils were dilated and nystagmus is noted. He has tremors and mild motor incoordination. Elevated blood levels of which of the following substances is most likely responsible for this patient's clinical presentation?

Vitals:

  • HR- 120/min
  • BP- 150/100 mm of Hg
  • Temp. - 99.5F
  • RR- 18/min
questions.solution:
The most likely substance responsible for the above patient's clinical presentation is angel dust or phencyclidine.

A patient presenting with confusion, agitation, hallucinations, grimacing, nystagmus, and hypertension and hyperthermia is suggestive of phencyclidine intoxication. 

Phencyclidine (PCP) is a hallucinogen that can cause euphoria, agitation, confusion, auditory and visual hallucinations, tachycardia, and nystagmus. Nystagmus, hypertension, and hyperthermia are common effects of PCP. Muscle rigidity, grimacing, head rolling are also sometimes observed.

Physiological changes from hallucinogens include:

  • Pupillary dilation
  • Tachycardia
  • Sweating
  • Palpitations
  • Blurring of vision
  • Tremors
  • Incoordination

Treatment for phencyclidine toxicity includes supportive care and symptomatic management.

Other Options:

Option A-  Heroin is a form of morphine. Patients on intoxication with heroin present with heaviness in extremities, dry mouth, flushing, pupillary constriction, respiratory depression, and constipation. It usually causes dependence and withdrawal.

Option B- Marijuana is a form of cannabinoid. Patients on intoxication with cannabinoids present with red-eye (due to conjunctival blood vessel dilatation), mild tachycardia, increased appetite ('the munchies'), dry mouth. It causes orthostatic hypotension at high doses. Cannabis is the most widely used illegal substance in the world.

Option C- A crack is a form of cocaine. Patients on intoxication with cocaine present with compulsive behavior, severe insomnia, weight loss, irritability, impaired ability to concentrate.

Related Pearl: Acute drug intoxication

                                            Acute Drug Intoxication

Drug

  • Hypertension
  • Ataxia
  • Hallucinations
  • Violent behavior
  • Dissociation
  • Amnesia
  • Nystagmus

LSD

Hallucinogen
  • Tachycardia 
  • Hypertension
  • Ataxia
  • Visual hallucinations
  • Euphoria
  • Dysphoric/panic

Cocaine

  • Tachycardia
  • Hypertension
  • Agitation
  • Euphoria
  • Chest pain
  • Seizures
  • Mydriasis

 Methamphetamine

Stimulant
  • Tachycardia
  • Hypertension
  • Violent behavior
  • Psychosis
  • Diaphoresis
  • Choreiform movements
  • Tooth decay

 Marijuana (THC, Cannabis)

questions.text: A skull was found in an abandoned area, it was brought to the forensic department for identification. Which of the following features of the skull points to the female sex?
questions.solution:
Female skulls have a smaller and pointed mastoid process.

The differences between male and female skulls are summarized below:

S.No Feature  Male skull Female skull
1. General appearance larger, heavier, prominent muscle markings Smaller, lighter, smoother
2. Forehead Irregular, rough, less rounded Smooth, round
3. Cranial capacity More 1450-1550 cc Less 1300-1500 cc
4. Glabella Prominent Less prominent
5. Supraorbital ridge Prominent Less prominent
6. Frontonasal junction Distinct angulation Smoothly curved
7. Orbits Square, smaller Larger, sharp margins
8. Frontal and parietal eminences Less prominent Prominent
9. Zygomatic arch Prominent Not prominent
10. Occipital area Prominent Not prominent
11. Mastoid process Large, round, blunt Small, smooth, pointed
12. Digastric groove Deep  Shallow 
13. Condylar facet Long, narrow Short, broad
14. Palate  Long, U-shaped, broad Small, parabolic
15. Foramen magnum  Relatively large, long Smaller, rounded
16. External auditory meatus Bony ridge on the upper border is prominent Often absent

Note that features 7 and 8 deviate from the trend. In all the other features, the male skull is larger, more prominent, or more rugged than the female skull.

In the image below, the red arrow indicates frontal bossing, which is more apparent in the male skull. The nasal radix (green arrow) is consequently deeper in the male skull. The yellow arrow demonstrates greater prominence of the chin in the male skull. The blue arrow shows a greater mandibular height in the male as well.  

Related Pearl: Indices for determination of race and sex of an individual

To determine the sex of an individual -

Krogman's degree of accuracy in sexing adult skeletal remains:

  • Entire skeleton – 100%
  • Pelvis alone – 95%
  • Skull alone – 90%
  • Pelvis plus skull – 98%
  • Long bones alone – 80%

 

To determine the race of an individual -

questions.text: A patient being treated for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes for follow-up. He is tachypneic with a resting oxygen saturation of 86%. Which of the following will decrease mortality in this patient?
questions.solution:
Long-term oxygen therapy will decrease mortality in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). 

Supplemental oxygen is indicated in patients with resting O2 saturation of ≤88% or ≤89% with signs of pulmonary arterial hypertension or right heart failure. It has been proven to prolong survival and the benefits are directly proportional to the duration of oxygen administration (hours per day). Studies did not show significant benefits in patients with moderate hypoxemia. 

Patients with dependent edema, P-pulmonale on ECG, or hematocrit value >56% with PaO2 value between 56-59 mm Hg or SaO2 of 89% are also eligible for oxygen therapy.

COPD is a disease state characterized by chronic airflow obstruction.  It includes emphysema, chronic bronchitis, and small airway disease. Patients present with cough, sputum production, and dyspnea on exertion. Diagnosis is based on pulmonary function tests and the severity is graded according to the global initiative for chronic obstructive lung disease (GOLD) criteria. 

Pharmacotherapy of COPD includes:

  • Muscarinic antagonists: ipratropium, tiotropium
  • Beta-agonists: salbutamol, salmeterol
  • Theophylline
  • Inhaled corticosteroids

Acute exacerbations are managed with inhaled beta-agonists, muscarinic antagonists, oxygen, mechanical ventilation in the form of noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation, and antibiotics.

Smoking cessation and lung volume reduction surgery in some emphysematous patients are the other interventions associated with reduced mortality.

Other options:

Option 2: Long-term oral glucocorticoids are not recommended to treat COPD due to the significant adverse effects such as osteoporosis, weight gain, and cataracts.

Option 3: Inhaled corticosteroids are mainly used to reduce exacerbations. Patients with two or more exacerbations per year or hospitalized patients with one exacerbation can be considered. 

Option 4: Phosphodiesterase 4 inhibitors (PDE4) inhibitor roflumilast can be used to reduce the frequency of exacerbations in severe COPD and chronic bronchitis.

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule.

Type Area involved Other features

Centriacinar (most common)
  • Central part of acinus (respiratory bronchiole)
  • Upper lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in smokers
Panacinar
  • Entire acinus (respiratory bronchiole + alveoli)
  • Lower lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in young non-smokers
  • Associated with α-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Paraseptal
  • Distal part of acinus (alveoli)
  • Subpleural region
  • Commonly seen in young adults 
  • Increased risk for spontaneous pneumothorax 
Irregular
  • Focal and irregular involvement of acinus
  • Areas of the lung near scar tissue 
  • Not usually seen in COPD

questions.text: A midwife is examining a pregnant woman in labour when she noticed that the cord is prolapsed. What should be the next immediate step of management?

choices.text: Gently replace the cord inside the vagina
Inform the doctor and shift to OT
Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation

questions.solution:
In this scenario the midwife should put the pregnant women in a Trendelenburg position or in an exaggerated and elevated Sims’ position with a pillow or wedge under the hip or thigh.

Caesarean section is the recommended treatment of choice for cord prolapse. Prior to performing the procedure, several measures can be taken to alleviate cord compression. These measures involve:

  • Manually elevating the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the entire hand through the vagina
  • Positioning the patient in steep Trendelenburg, exaggerated Sim's position, or knee-chest position
  • Filling the bladder with 500–700 cc or more of saline (known as the Vagos method)

After the diagnosis of cord prolapse is made, it is crucial not to attempt cord replacement. Such attempts are not only ineffective but also result in the inevitable rupture of the membranes, leading to cord prolapse.

questions.text: In the metabolism of vitamin D, where does the conversion of calcidiol to calcitriol occur?
questions.solution:
In the metabolism of vitamin D, the conversion of calcidiol (25-hydroxycholecalciferol) to calcitriol (1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol) occurs in the kidney.

Vitamin D metabolism occurs in 3 steps:

Step 1- Skin: 7-dehydrocholesterol (an intermediate in cholesterol synthesis that accumulates in the skin) undergoes a nonenzymic reaction on exposure to ultraviolet light, yielding cholecalciferol, which is absorbed into the bloodstream. Note that 7-Dehydrocholesterol and cholecalciferol already contain one hydroxy group.

Step 2- Liver:  Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol. This is released into the circulation bound to a vitamin D–binding globulin, which is the main storage form of the vitamin.

Step 3- Kidney: 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol, the biologically active form by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase.

questions.text: A child treated for complaints of earache and discharge from the left ear now presents with mild hearing loss. On otoscopy, a bulging tympanic membrane is seen. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Myringotomy and aspiration of fluid is the next best step in serous otitis media, which the above clinical features are suggestive of. 

Serous otitis media is a condition with non-purulent effusion in the middle ear. The fluid is nearly sterile. Two mechanisms are associated with its pathogenesis - malfunctioning eustachian tube and increased secretory activity of the middle ear mucosa. 

Medical management of the condition includes topical decongestants, antibiotics, and anti-allergic measures. Frequently performing the Valsalva maneuver to aerate the middle ear is also helpful. Surgical treatment is indicated when medical management fails. Myringotomy and aspiration of fluid is the procedure carried out. If this fails, grommet insertion is carried out for sustained aeration of the middle ear.

The condition is mostly seen in children of the age group 5-8. They present with hearing loss, delayed or defective speech, and earaches. On otoscopy, the tympanic membrane is usually dull and opaque with a loss of light reflex. Mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted. Tuning fork tests and audiometry usually reveals conductive hearing loss.

Atrophic tympanic membrane, tympanosclerosis, and ossicular necrosis are some of the sequelae of long-standing disease.

Myringotomy is used to describe an incision of the tympanic membrane to drain any effusion or to aerate the middle ear in the presence of a eustachian tube dysfunction. The procedure is carried out under general anesthesia in children, using a myringotome shown in the image below. 

Other options:

Option A: Tympanoplasty includes inspection of the middle ear cavity to ensure ossicular integrity in addition to repair of the tympanic membrane. 

Option B: Myringoplasty is the closure of a perforation in the pars tensa of the tympanic membrane. It is done in chronic suppurative otitis media with perforation.

Option D: Meatoplasty is done in acquired atresia or stenosis of the external auditory meatus.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: While examining a pregnant woman, you measure her fundal height to be 32 cm and the station of the fetal head is at -2. What could be the probable weight of the fetus?
questions.solution:
The fetal weight in the above case is 3.1Kg.

In the above case, fetal weight can be estimated using Johnson's formula. Height of uterus is 32cm, the station is –2 implying the head is above the ischial spines. Therefore, it is calculated as follows: [32-12] x 155 = 3100 grams = 3.1Kg

Estimation of fetal weight:

  • Johnson’s formula: This is only applicable in vertex presentation.
    • If station of head is below the level of the ischial spine: [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-11] x 155 in grams
    • If station of head is above the level of the ischial spine: [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-12] x 155 in grams
  • Sonography: Fetal weight has been estimated by combining a number of biometric data, e.g. biparietal diameter (BPD), head circumference (HC), abdominal circumference (AC) and femur length (FL), using the following formulae:
    • Shepard’s formula
    • Hadlock’s formula.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient came with complaints of dyspnea, dysphagia, hoarseness of voice, and cough for a few months.  A mass in the thyroid gland was detected, and a diagnosis of Reidel's thyroiditis was made. Which among the following condition has pathophysiology similar to Reidel's thyroiditis?
questions.solution:
Riedel's thyroiditis is an IgG4 related disease. Among the given options, the condition that has pathophysiology similar to Reidel's thyroiditis is retroperitoneal fibrosis, which is also an IgG4 related disease.

IgG4 related disease is a group of disorders characterized by tissue infiltrates predominantly composed of IgG4 antibody-producing plasma cells and lymphocytes, fibrosis, obliterative phlebitis, and increased serum IgG4. It is predominantly seen in middle-aged men. The IgG4-Related disease spectrum includes:

  • Mikulicz syndrome 
  • Riedel thyroiditis
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis
  • Autoimmune pancreatitis
  • Inflammatory pseudotumors of the orbit, lungs, and kidney

Riedel thyroiditis is a rare disorder characterized by extensive fibrosis of the thyroid gland and adjacent structures. They present with a nontender, hard-fixed thyroid mass leading to suspicion of malignancy. Diagnosis requires an open biopsy and surgical resection relives compressive symptoms. It may be associated with IgG4 related disease-causing idiopathic fibrosis at other sites. 

Retroperitoneal fibrosis is an IgG4 related disease that presents with backache, low abdominal pain, lower limb edema, hydronephrosis from ureteral involvement.

Other options:

Option A- Hashimoto thyroiditis is autoimmune thyroiditis that destroys the thyroid gland and leads to gradual, progressive thyroid failure. This occurs due to the breakdown in self-tolerance to thyroid autoantigens. 

Option B- De Quervain thyroiditis is also known as granulomatous thyroiditis. It is triggered by a viral infection. A viral upper respiratory tract infection causes host tissue damage that stimulates a cytotoxic T lymphocytes response to one or more thyroid antigens that damages thyroid follicle cells.

Option D- Amyloidosis is a condition associated with inherited and inflammatory disorders in which extracellular deposits of abnormal fibrillar proteins cause tissue damage and functional compromise.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is found to have the following finding during the abdominal CT scan. She has no specific symptoms and this was an incidental finding on her imaging. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Angiography shows typical spoke wheel pattern
Rupture or infarctions  can occur in most cases
Asymptomatic patients do not require any treatment
Second most common benign tumor of the liver

questions.solution:
The given CT image shows a hypervascular lesion in the liver with a central non-enhancing scar which is suggestive of focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH). Complications like rupture or infarctions occur very rarely in FNH, unlike hepatic adenomas.

FNH is the second most common benign tumor of the liver after hemangioma (Option D). It is commonly seen in young women. It is believed to be a hyperplastic response to an anomalous artery. Patients are mostly asymptomatic and FNH is often an incidental finding. If symptoms are noted, vague abdominal pain is the most common symptom.

Contrast-enhanced CT is diagnostic for focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH). It appears as a well-circumscribed lesion with a central stellate scar containing a large artery branching out in a spoke-wheel pattern (Option A). It shows intense homogeneous enhancement in the arterial phase and it is isodense as compared to the background liver in the venous phase.

Due to the presence of Kupffer cells, FNH appears as a hotspot on the Tc 99m sulfur colloid scan. On histological examination, cords of hepatocytes are seen with atypical biliary epithelium scattered throughout. 

These tumors do not have the risk of malignant transformation, therefore asymptomatic patients do not require treatment (Option C). Careful observation of symptomatic FNH with serial imaging is reasonable, as symptoms may resolve in a significant number of cases. Patients with persistent symptomatic FNH or an enlarging mass should be considered for resection. If diagnostic uncertainty exists, resection may be necessary for histologic confirmation.

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: Which of the following is the single leading cause of death in children under 5 years of age worldwide?
questions.solution:
The single leading cause of death under the age of 5 years is pneumonia, accounting for around 15.6% of all under-five deaths. 

Under-5 mortality is the number of deaths under the age of 5 years per 1000 live births. It measures the probability of dying between birth and exactly 5 years of age. UNICEF considers this as the best single indicator of social development and well-being as it reflects income, nutrition, health care, and basic education. 

The Sub-Saharan Africa region has the highest under-five mortality rate in the world. On average, boys are expected to have a higher probability of dying before reaching age 5 years than girls. It is also higher in poorer households, rural areas, and children of uneducated mothers.

Causes of Under-5 mortality Percentage (%)
Preterm birth complications 17.9
Pneumonia 15.6
Intrapartum related complications 12.0
Diarrhea 8.2
Neonatal sepsis 7.0
Injury 6.1
Malaria 5.1
Meningitis 1.8
Measles 1.3
Tetanus 0.6
Others 14.3

questions.text: A young man presented to the casualty with a suspected abdominal injury following a road traffic accident. On examination, his vitals are found to be stable and there is some tenderness in the epigastric and umbilical areas. He was sent for a contrast-enhanced CT scan. Which of the following can be safely used as an intravascular contrast medium in him?
questions.solution:
Iodinated contrast can be safely used as an intravascular contrast medium in contrast-enhanced CT scan for this patient.

Contrast agents for CT can be divided into:

  • Water-soluble compounds (iodine-containing)
  • Non-water-soluble compounds (barium)

Iodine is the only element that can be safely used as an intravascular contrast medium for radiography including angiography and CT. The iodine provides radiopacity. The other elements of the contrast medium act as carriers of iodine which increases the solubility and reduces toxicity. They interfere with the clotting times. Hence, clotting tests are usually avoided until 6 hours after the administration of contrast media. They are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.

Iodine-based contrast media are classified as ionic and non-ionic, based on the nature of the compound to which the iodine is bound. Ionic media consists of iodine bound to inorganic compounds, while non-ionic media consists of iodine bound to an organic compound. The common examples of ionic and non-ionic iodine-based contrast media include iothalamate, iohexol respectively.

Other options:

Option A: Gadolinium (Gd) is used as a contrast medium for MRI. It contains paramagnetic metal ions that affect the MR signal properties of surrounding tissues. Since gadolinium ion is toxic, it is chelated with DTPA. Hence, Gd-DTPA is the agent used.

Option B: Barium sulphate (BaSO4) is a poorly soluble compound that is used to study the gastrointestinal tract. It is administered orally or rectally, in a finely divided aqueous suspension. It is avoided when there is a suspicion of aspiration, a fistula between the oesophagus and lungs, or perforation of the gastrointestinal tract due to the risk of leakage causing fatal mediastinitis or peritonitis.

Option C: Perflutren, as a microscopic gas bubble is a contrast media used in ultrasound imaging. It is administered intravenously. There are three agents available:

  • Air with galactose and palmitic acid as a surfactant
  • Octa fluoro propane (perflutren) with an albumin shell or a lipid shell
  • Sulphur hexafluoride with a phospholipid shell.

Related Pearl: Classification of iodinated contrast medias:

Types Ionic  Non-ionic
Subtypes  Monomer Dimer Monomer Dimer
Osmolarity

1400- 1600 mOsm (Not preferred due to high osmolarity)

 600- 800 mOsm 600- 800 mOsm 300 mOsm
Iodine: particle ratio 3:2 6:2 or 3:1 3:1 6:1
Examples 

Diatrizoate (Urograffin)

Iothalamate

Ioxaglate

Iohexol (most commonly used)
