questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was evaluated for delayed developmental milestones. Fundus examination revealed the findings as shown in the image below. The abdominal examination is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a fundus image showing a cherry-red spot at the macula is suggestive of Tay-Sachs disease. 

Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder due to the deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A which degrades GM2 gangliosides. GM2 ganglioside accumulates more commonly in neurons of the central and autonomic nervous systems and retina.

Tay-Sachs disease is common among people from the Ashkenazi Jewish population. Affected infants usually present with loss of motor skills, exaggerated startle response to noise (hyperacusis), seizures, and macrocephaly without hydrocephalus.

On examination of the fundus, a cherry-red spot appears in the macula in almost all patients. This is produced by the accentuation of the red color of the macular choroid, against the background of the rest of the retina appearing pale due to ganglion cells being swollen with GM2 ganglioside.

Histopathological examination reveals ballooned-out neuronal tissue with vacuoles representing lysosomes filled with gangliosides.

Note that cherry red spots are associated with multiple conditions, as discussed in the pearl below and should always be interpreted in the context of the clinical history. 

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases

    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with an obstetric score of G2P1, presented to the hospital at 37 weeks of gestation, with complaints of sudden onset of severe pain abdomen and vaginal bleeding. She has a past history of classical Cesarean section 3 years ago. A uterine scar rupture is suspected in this patient. All of the following findings indicate uterine scar rupture, except ______.

choices.text: Loss of station of presenting part

questions.solution:
Maternal tachycardia (not bradycardia) is a feature of uterine rupture.

Uterine rupture is one in which all the layers of the uterus (endometrium, myometrium, and serosa ) are disrupted any time after 28 weeks of pregnancy.

A previous history of classical cesarean section, obstructed labor, manual removal of placenta, dilatation, and curettage are some risk factors for uterine scar rupture.

Clinical features of scar dehiscence:

  • Maternal tachycardia
  • Fetal bradycardia
  • Maternal hypotension
  • Uterine scar tenderness
  • Bleeding per vagina
  • Hematuria 
  • Loss of station of presenting part

Management of uterine scar rupture includes resuscitation and laparotomy. Following resuscitative measures and laparotomy, subtotal hysterectomy is usually done unless there is sufficient reason to preserve the uterus.

questions.text: A newborn baby is vaccinated against tuberculosis disease. All of the following are true about the vaccine except:

choices.text: The dose given at birth is 0.05 ml
Distilled water is preferred for reconstitution

questions.solution:
BCG vaccine is primarily used against tuberculosis disease. Normal saline is recommended for reconstituting the vaccine, as distilled water may cause irritation. Hence, option D is not true. 

BCG (bacillus of Calmette and Guerin) is the only live bacterial vaccine. The WHO has recommended the Danish 1331 strain for the production of the BCG vaccine. It protects against severe forms of childhood tuberculosis and tuberculous meningitis. It also reduces morbidity and mortality against primary tuberculosis.

There are two types of BCG vaccine: the liquid (fresh) vaccine and the freeze-dried vaccine. The freeze-dried vaccine is a more stable preparation (option B) than the liquid vaccine. Currently, the vaccine is distributed in the freeze-dried form because of better storage qualities. Normal saline is recommended for reconstituting the vaccine, as distilled water may cause irritation. The reconstituted vaccine may be used up within 3 hours.

The usual strength for vaccination is 0.1 mg in 0.1 ml volume. The dose given at birth (option A) and for newborns < 4 weeks of age is 0.05 ml. It is injected intradermally (option C) just above the insertion of the left deltoid muscle using a tuberculin syringe.  

A papule develops at the vaccination site after 2-3 weeks. It increases slowly in size and then subsides or breaks into a shallow ulcer after 5 weeks. Healing occurs spontaneously within 6 to 12 weeks, leaving a permanent, tiny, round scar, typically 4-8 mm in diameter. Usually, the individual becomes Mantoux-positive after 8-14 weeks. 

Complications include prolonged severe ulceration at the vaccination site, suppurative lymphadenitis, osteomyelitis, and disseminated infection. It should not be given to patients with generalized eczema, infective dermatosis, hypogammaglobulinemia, immunodeficiency state, or pregnancy.

questions.text: A young woman presented with a history of falling on a partially flexed thumb of the right hand. On X-ray, a diagnosis of Bennett’s fracture was made. The joint that is present at the location of this fracture is a type of:
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient has Bennett's fracture which is an intra-articular fracture of the base of the 1st metacarpal. The joint that is present at this location is the 1st carpometacarpal joint which is a saddle type of synovial joint. 

The saddle joint is a biaxial joint that has both concave and convex regions as their articular surfaces. The convexity of one articular surface is opposed to the concavity of the other articular surface and vice versa.

The movements across this type of joint occur mainly in 2 axes i.e. flexion and extension, abduction and adduction. Due to the articular shape, it results in axial rotation. Examples are 1st carpometacarpal joint and the calcaneocuboid joint. 

Other options:

Option A: The ball and socket joint is a type of synovial joint where the articular surfaces include a globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket. These joints are multi-axial and movements occur around many axes. Flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, medial rotation, lateral rotation, and circumduction, all occur quite freely. Examples are the shoulder joint, hip joint, talocalcaneonavicular joint, and incudostapedial joint.

Option B: The hinge joint is a type of synovial joint where the movements occur in a single stationary axis, i.e., flexion/extension. Examples are the elbow joint, and interphalangeal joint.

Option D: A pivot joint is a type of synovial joint where an osseous pivot is present inside an osteocartilaginous ring allowing movement only around the axis of the pivot. Examples of this type of joint are atlantoaxial joint and superior and inferior radioulnar joint.

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with a painless inguinoscrotal swelling. Examination revealed a hard, non-tender swelling in the left hemi-scrotum. It was possible to get above the swelling. The left testis was not palpable separate from the swelling. The ultrasound scan of the left and right testes, labeled as A and B respectively, is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A painless inguinoscrotal swelling and an ultrasound showing a mass that is homogenous, hypoechoic compared to surrounding stroma, and arising from within testes (image A- left testicle) are suggestive of seminoma.

Seminoma is the most common type of Germ cell tumor. The peak incidence is seen in the fourth decade. It usually presents as painless testicular enlargement. Ultrasound is mandatory in all suspected cases of testicular tumors. 

Seminoma has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface that is devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis. Histology shows sheets of uniform round cells with clear cytoplasm and a large central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus. It is seen as a "fried egg appearance" as shown below.

Placental alkaline phosphate(PLAP) is the tumor marker of seminoma. A rise in hCG is observed in 30% of cases and AFP is never raised in pure seminoma.

Seminoma metastasizes mainly through para-aortic lymph nodes.

An orchidectomy through an inguinal incision is performed as a definitive treatment.

Other options:

Option B-Epididymal cyst occurs due to cystic degeneration of epididymis. They usually occur in middle age and are bilateral. The tense cysts are usually posterior to the testes and feel like clusters of tiny grapes. It is visible on USG as anechoic cysts different from the testes. Treatment involves the excision of the cyst if it is single. Partial or total resection of the epididymis is required in multilocular cysts.

The image below is an ultrasound of the scrotum showing an epididymal cyst.

Option C-Hydrocoele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis in the scrotum. It will be brilliantly transilluminating and testes will be separately palpable. USG will show anechoic (due to fluid) reflection. Treatment involves Jaboulay's operation, in which eversion of sac upon itself is done to prevent refilling of hydrocoele sac.

The image below shows an ultrasound of the scrotum showing an anechoic hydrocele surrounding the testicle.

Option D-Cancer of the scrotum is a rare entity, which previously occurred in chimney sweepers. It presents as a wart or ulcer on the scrotum which may involve testes as it grows. It is treated by excision of the lesion with a margin of normal tissue.

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

questions.text:
What is the effect of the mechanism of enzyme inhibition shown in the image below?

Km: Michaelis constant
questions.solution:
The given mechanism shows non-competitive enzyme inhibition. In this type of inhibition, Km remains the same.

In enzyme kinetics, Vmax is the rate of the reaction when the enzyme is saturated with the substrate. Km (Michaelis constant) is the substrate concentration at which the enzyme achieves ½ Vmax.

Km indicates the affinity of the enzyme to the substrate. When the enzyme has a high affinity for the substrate, ½ Vmax is achieved at a lower substrate concentration/ lower Km.

In non-competitive inhibition, an inhibitor binds to the allosteric site of the enzyme. This leads to a conformational change in the substrate-binding site which prevents the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. The free enzyme molecules have the same amount of affinity to the substrate because of which Km remains the same.

Since the inhibitor and the substrate bind to different sites, increasing the substrate concentration will not have any effect on reversing the inhibition. Therefore, non-competitive inhibition is considered irreversible inhibition. As some of the enzyme molecules become irreversibly inactive, Vmax is reduced in non-competitive inhibition.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman was found dead at home. She was brought to the mortuary by the police and the following findings were noted on examination. Which of the following is the likely cause of her death?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario and autopsy images showing carotid intimal tear and muscle hematoma with nail marks on neck and absence of ligature mark point towards a diagnosis of throttling.

Other options

Option A- Strangulation by ligature - ligature mark with signs of a struggle would've made this diagnosis more likely.

Option B- Hanging - ligature mark with a suicide note would've made it more likely.

Option C- Drowning- Body recovered from a pond or other water body with other suggestive features like frothing etc  would've made this more likely.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida is screaming in pain while being wheeled into the labor room at 2 am. On examination, her cervix is well-effaced and is 4 cm dilated. What is the preferred anesthetic technique to ensure this patient has a painless labour?
questions.solution:
A lumbar epidural is the preferred anesthetic technique to ensure that this patient has painless labor.

For adequate pain relief, the sensory block of T10-L1 is required during the first stage of labor, and S2-S4 is required during the second stage. The epidural catheter placed at L3-L4 or L4-L5 interspace sufficiently provides T10–S5 neural blockade.

Maternal hydration has to be ensured with normal saline or Hartmann's solution infusion before epidural blockade is commenced. The patient's heart rate, blood pressure, and fetal heart rate have to be monitored every 15 minutes following the induction of anesthesia, and maternal hypotension has to be treated promptly.  

Contraindications of epidural analgesia include neurological diseases, maternal coagulopathy or anticoagulant therapy, hypovolemia, supine hypotension, and skin infection at the injection site.

Complications of epidural analgesia include hypotension due to sympathetic blockade, post-spinal headache, pain at the injection site, and injury to nerves. 

Option A: Pudendal nerve block is given in the second stage of labor just before delivery of the baby to provide analgesia to the vulva and anus​. It is mostly used for forceps and vaginal breech deliveries. However, it has no effect on the pain of contractions. It is also given before repair of episiotomy or perineal lacerations.

Option B: Spinal anesthesia for labor analgesia has the advantage of a rapid and reliable onset of the neural blockade, and it is technically easier to administer compared to epidural analgesia. However, repeated intrathecal injections may be required for prolonged labor, thus increasing the risk of post-dural puncture headache.

Option C: Caudal epidural is largely avoided for pain relief in obstetrics. It requires large volumes of a local anesthetic to anesthetize upper lumbar and lower thoracic dermatomes to provide adequate labor analgesia. Though rare, accidental puncture of the fetus is a possibility.

questions.text: A young man presents with sudden onset nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of passing loose stools. He gives a history of having food from a nearby bakery three hours ago. Which of the following organisms is most likely implicated here?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of acute food poisoning most likely caused by Staphylococcus aureus. 

Food poisoning by Staphylococcus aureus is caused due to ingestion of preformed enterotoxin. The preformed enterotoxin is heat-stable. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known, of which, Type A toxin is responsible for most cases. It contaminates food products such as meat, fish, milk products, mayonnaise, cream pastries, etc. when left at room temperature for a long time.

Enterotoxin acts directly on the autonomic nervous system to cause food poisoning, rather than on the gastrointestinal mucosa. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity.

Staphylococcal food poisoning has a very short incubation period of about 1 - 8 hours. Patients usually present with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea 2-6 hrs after the consumption of contaminated food.

Other options:

Option A: Vibrio cholera leads to dysentery that presents with acute, profuse, watery stools (rice water stools) and vomiting which may lead to severe dehydration, hypokalemia, and shock. The incubation period is usually around 1-5 days. 

Option B: Salmonella typhi can present with diarrheal disease along with typical step-ladder patterns of fever, relative bradycardia, malaise, and abdominal discomfort. The incubation period is usually around 7-14 days.

Option C: Infection with Bacillus cereus causes food poisoning with a longer incubation period of 8-16 hours. But patients usually have a history of consumption of fried rice.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

Organism Symptoms Common food source
1–6 hrs incubation period  
Staphylococcus aureus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Ham, poultry, potato, cream pastries, mayonnaise
Bacillus cereus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Fried rice
8–16 hrs incubation period

Bacillus cereus Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals
>16 hrs incubation period

Salmonella species Inflammatory diarrhea Beef, poultry, eggs
Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli Watery diarrhea Salads, cheese, meats
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli Bloody diarrhea Raw milk, raw vegetables, apple juice

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrect about Eale's disease?

choices.text: Causes gradual painful loss of vision

questions.solution:
Eale's disease causes sudden, painless loss of vision. It does not cause a gradual, painful loss of vision.

Eales disease is an idiopathic occlusive peripheral periphlebitis. Tubercular etiology is implicated. There are 3 stages of this disease: inflammatory, occlusive, and retinal neovascular stage.

Symptoms include floaters or sudden, painless loss of vision due to vitreous hemorrhage. 

Diagnosis is made when fundoscopy reveals the following features:

  • Peripheral periphlebitis- perivascular sheathing, superficial retinal hemorrhages are seen in the inflammatory stage.
  • Occlusion of the involved vessels in the occlusive stage.
  • Neovascularization and recurrent vitreous hemorrhage may occur at the junction of perfused and non-perfused retina in the retinal neovascular stage. 
  • Macular involvement may occur.

Investigations should be performed to rule out other causes of vasculitis (e.g. sarcoidosis, tuberculosis) and peripheral retinal neovascularization (e.g. hemoglobinopathies). Fluorescein angiography will identify vasculitis and the areas of non-perfusion.

Medical management includes oral and topical steroids given during the stage of inflammation. Anti-tubercular therapy is also recommended in some cases. Surgical management includes laser photocoagulation used in the stage of neovascularization. Vitrectomy is done if there is persistent vitreous hemorrhage, tractional retinal detachment, or macular epiretinal membrane.

Complications include tractional retinal detachment, macular epiretinal membrane, neovascular glaucoma, rubeosis iridis, and cataract. The visual prognosis is good in the majority of cases.

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes to you in her second stage of labor. On per vaginal examination, frontal sutures, anterior fontanelle, and supraorbital ridges are palpated. What could the fetal presentation be?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the fetus could be in the brow presentation.

On per vaginal examination, the palpation of frontal sutures, anterior fontanelle, and supraorbital ridges indicate that the fetus is in the brow presentation. However, neither the mouth nor the chin can be palpated on per vaginal examination.

This is a rare presentation that is diagnosed when the portion of the fetal head between the orbital ridge and the anterior fontanel presents at the pelvic inlet.

The etiology of brow presentation includes:

  • Maternal: Multiparity with pendulous abdomen, lateral obliquity of the uterus, contracted pelvis.
  • Fetal: Congenital malformations with the most common being anencephaly, congenital goiter, dolichocephalic head

The brow presentation is commonly unstable and frequently converts to a face or occipital presentation. Management is easy in the case of a small fetus and a large maternal pelvis. However, in the case of a large fetus, delivery by cesarean section is usually indicated.

Other options:

Option A: Face presentation occurs when the neck is hyper-extended and the chin is the presenting part. The facial features may be palpable on per-vaginal examination. 

Option B: Vertex presentation occurs when the neck is well flexed. A quadrangular area of the fetal skull bound by the bregma, parietal eminence, and lambdoid sutures is palpable on per-vaginal examination.

Option D: Shoulder presentation can occur when the fetus is in the transverse lie. On per vaginal examination during labor, the shoulder is identified by palpating the following parts—the acromion process, the scapula, the clavicle, and the axilla. The characteristic landmarks are
the feeling of the ribs and intercostal spaces (gridiron feel). On occasion, the arm is found prolapsed.

questions.text: Which of the following functions is regulated by the lateral superior hypothalamus?
questions.solution:
The lateral superior hypothalamus regulates thirst. It is also an integrating area for hunger. 

Other options:

Option A: Body rhythm control is integrated by suprachiasmatic nuclei of the hypothalamus.

Option B: Sexual behavior is integrated by the anterior ventral hypothalamus.

Option D: Temperature regulation is integrated by the anterior and posterior hypothalamus.

Related Pearl: Functions of hypothalamus

  • Ventromedial
    • Satiety
  • Arcuate
    • Either increase or decrease appetite
  • Paraventricular nucleus
    • Oxytocin release
    • Satiety
    • ACTH and beta lipotropin and blood pressure
  • Medial Preoptic and anterior hypothalamus
    • Body temperature regulation -
      Anterior: responds to heat
      Posterior: responds to cold
    • Sweating
  • Supra optic
    • Vasopressin
  • Preoptic
    •  FSH and LH via GRH
  • Anterior hypothalamus
    • Osmoreceptor
  • Lateral hypothalamus
    • Hunger
    • Thirst

questions.text: The body of a woman found in a water body was brought for autopsy. There is frothing at the mouth, the hand is clenched with soil and weeds, and bloodstained froth is present in the lungs. The Gettler test reveals that the chloride content is 30 mg% lower on the left side of the heart compared to the right. With the above case scenario, which option best describes the drowning?
questions.solution:
The above case scenario shows the features of antemortem drowning in freshwater.

Frothing and cadaveric spasm are suggestive of antemortem drowning. The Gettler test findings are consistent with freshwater drowning.

Gettler test - Normally, the chloride content is 600 mg% on either side of the heart. A difference of more than 25 mg% between the right and the left sides is highly suggestive of antemortem drowning.

Freshwater drowning - The chloride content is lower on the left side of the heart due to dilution by freshwater.

Saltwater drowning- The chloride content is higher on the left side of the heart due to the entry of saltwater and hemoconcentration.

Given below are the features of antemortem drowning.

  • Froth - The presence of copious amounts of fine, shaving-lather-like froth at the mouth and the nostrils is the most characteristic finding of antemortem drowning. It is caused by the vigorous agitation of the tracheal and bronchial mucous secretions, edema fluid, and alveolar surfactant during respiratory efforts. 
  • Cutis anserina - The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and grainy appearance of the skin. This resembles goose skin; hence, it is called cutis anserina.
  • Washerwoman’s hand - Maceration of the skin on the palms and soles gives a wrinkled, sodden, and bleached appearance due to submersion.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning. The material also indicates the place of submersion.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Face - It is bloated and discolored, with cyanosis.
  • Eyes - Conjunctiva are suffused and pupils dilated.
  • Tongue - It may be swollen and protruded.
  • Antemortem injuries - These may be sustained by striking objects, such as rocks, during the fall into the water body. Examination for such injuries must be performed only after the body is dry.

Internal findings:

  • Lungs - They appear voluminous and distended show ballooning. The cut section will exude copious amounts of frothy, bloodstained fluid.
  • Larynx, trachea, and bronchioles - The presence of sand, silt, and aquatic vegetation in the trachea and lower respiratory tract are characteristic findings of antemortem drowning.
  • Heart and blood vessels- Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning. 
  • Diatom test- Diatoms are microscopic algae. Their presence in the organs, particularly in the bone marrow, is suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Stomach and small intestines- These organs may contain water in some cases. Water present in the small intestine is positive evidence of death by drowning.
  • Middle ear - The presence of water in the middle ear is highly suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Brain - It is congested, and edematous, with loss of gray-white junction.


Options A, C, and D are not correct as the case does not show the findings of postmortem or saltwater drowning.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

Feature        Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning
Froth/ foam at nostrils or mouth Present Absent
Cadaveric spasm Present Absent
Lungs

Emphysema aquosum

Edema aquosum(seen in unconscious) 

Lungs are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated

 

Passive collection of water in the lungs
Presence of foreign bodies (fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, etc) Present in bronchi and bronchioles Passively collected only in upper respiratory passage
Demonstration of diatoms  Present in the lungs, liver, brain, bone marrow, etc.

Present only in the lungs

Not spread to distant organs because of absence of circulation
Stomach contents 

Water

Foreign material like sand, weed, dirt etc  (swallowed while struggling for life)

Water (lesser quantity)

Related Pearl: Difference between freshwater and seawater drowning.

  Freshwater drowning Seawater drowning
Mechanism of death Disruption of surfactant - causes surfactant denaturation Disruption of surfactant - causes dilution of surfactant

Hyponatremia

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes with complaints of patchy hair loss, as seen in the photograph below. Dermoscopy of the scalp skin was normal. On histology, numerous empty canals were seen. Clefts were noticed in the hair matrix and the follicular epithelium is separated from the connec­tive tissue sheath. Intraepithelial and perifollicular hemorrhages were noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and image suggest that the most likely diagnosis is trichotillomania.

Trichotillomania is a psychiatric disorder characterized by com­pulsive hair pulling. There is increased tension before the hair-pulling and a relief of tension or gratification after the hair-pulling. It presents as an area of patchy hair loss, often in a bizarre pattern. The hairs are often twisted and broken at various distances from the scalp or may be present as a uniform, coarse stubble. The scalp skin appears normal.

Sites other than the scalp can also be affected, for example- eyelashes, eyebrows, beard, mons pubis, and perianal region.

Scalp biopsy shows intraepithelial and perifollicular hemorrhages. Numerous empty canals, severely damaged follicles, and clefts in the hair matrix are also seen. The follicular epithelium separates from the connec­tive tissue sheath.

Other options:

Option A: Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease causing non-scarring hair loss. It is characterized by a circumscribed, smooth patch of hair loss. Exclamation mark hairs are often seen at the margins of the bald patches during active phases of the disease. 

The image below shows alopecia areata:

Option B: Tinea capitis is the ringworm of the scalp. The appearance may vary from dull grey, broken‐off hairs with a little scaling to a severe, painful, inflammatory mass covering the entire scalp. Predominantly seen in children, however, adults can also be affected due to infection by T.tonsurans.

The image below shows Tinea capitis:

Option D: Traction alopecia is caused by hairstyles that impose a sus­tained pull on the hair roots. The pattern of the hair loss will reflect the dis­tribution of the traction.

questions.text:
Which of the given clinical findings are consistent with a diagnosis of class III hemorrhagic shock?

PR- Pulse rate; BP- Blood pressure
questions.solution:
A pulse rate of 126 bpm and decreased blood pressure of 80/50 mmHg fall under class III hemorrhagic shock.

Patients with hemorrhagic shock are classified based on their clinical signs and symptoms. According to this classification- a person with a pulse rate i.e PR >120 and decreased BP (blood pressure) falls under class III. Other features include an anxious or confused state, decreased pulse pressure, a respiratory rate (RR) between 30-40/min, and a urine output of 5-15 mL/hr. These patients can be replaced with crystalloids and blood. The blood loss is 30-40% in these patients.

Other options:

Option A: This comes under class I as the pulse rate is below 100 bpm and blood pressure is normal. Features include slight anxiety, normal pulse pressure, RR 14-20/min, and urine output >30 mL/hr. Crystalloids are useful.

Option C: This comes under class IV as the pulse rate is above 140 bpm and blood pressure is decreased. Confusion/ lethargy, decreased pulse pressure, RR >35/min, and negligible urine are seen. Crystalloids and blood transfusion are useful for these patients. 

Option D: This comes under class II as the pulse rate is between 100-120 bpm and blood pressure is normal. The patients falling under this class are mildly anxious with decreased pulse pressure, RR 20-30/min, and urine output of 20-30 mL/hr. Crystalloids are given to these patients.

Related Pearl: Classification of hemorrhagic shock

Parameters Class I Class II Class III Class IV
Blood loss in % <15 15–30 30–40 >40
Pulse rate <100 100–120 120–140 >140
Blood pressure Normal Normal Decreased Greatly decreased
Pulse pressure Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Respiratory rate 14–20 20–30 30–40 >35
Mental status Slightly anxious Mildly anxious Anxious, confused Confused, lethargic
Urine output (mL/hr) >30 20–30 5–15 Minimal

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient was diagnosed with pulmonary artery hypertension. He was prescribed an endothelin receptor antagonist for the management of the same. After starting the drug, he developed nasal congestion and pharyngitis. Which of the following drugs was prescribed?
questions.solution:
The drug prescribed is bosentan. 

The clinical scenario of the development of nasal congestion and pharyngitis after administration of an endothelin receptor antagonist given for the treatment of pulmonary artery hypertension suggests that the drug prescribed is bosentan.

  • ETA - This receptor is localized on the pulmonary artery smooth muscle cell. It is a G-protein coupled receptor and acts via the IP3-DAG pathway elevating cytosolic Ca2+ thus causing vasoconstriction.
  • ETB - This receptor is present on the pulmonary artery smooth muscle cell and endothelial cell. It is a G-protein coupled receptor and on activation, the ETB receptors on the endothelial cells increase the production of PGI2, NO and inhibit ET-1 production.

Endothelin receptor antagonists act by either non-selectively inhibiting both endothelin receptors or by selectively inhibiting ETA receptors only. The nonselective endothelin receptor antagonists are bosentan and macitentan. The selective endothelin receptor antagonists are ambrisentan and sitaxsentan. Sitaxsentan is the most selective ETA receptor antagonist. These drugs are predominantly used in the treatment of pulmonary artery hypertension.

Side effects:

  • Headache
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Nasal congestion/pharyngitis
  • Hepatotoxicity -  needs monitoring and contraindicated in patients with mild-moderate liver disease.
  • Teratogenic - contraindicated in pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A- Epoprostenol is a synthetic PGI2, It acts by inhibiting myosin light chain kinase and activating K+ channels. It is the mainstay of treatment of pulmonary artery hypertension, particularly in advanced stages. The important side effects include myalgia, jaw pain, nausea, flushing, and systemic hypotension.

Option C- Inhaled NO acts by activation of soluble guanylyl cyclase → activates cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). An important side effect is methemoglobinemia.

Option D- Sildenafil acts by competitive inhibition of phosphodiesterase 5 (PDE5). Important side effects are headache, flushing and blue-green vision.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH)

Drug Class Examples

Epoprostenol

Iloprost

Treprostinil
Endothelin receptor antagonist

Bosentan

Ambrisentan

Macitentan
PDE5 inhibitor

Sildenafil

Tadalafil
Soluble guanyl cyclase stimulator Riociguat
Calcium channel blocker

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presented with swelling at the lower end of the thigh. He has severe pain at the swelling during the night which reduces after taking aspirin. X-ray shows peripheral reactive sclerotic rim with central radiolucent nidus.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young man, with painful swelling in the lower end of the thigh which worsens at night, pain relieved on aspirin intake, and an X-ray showing peripheral sclerotic rim with central radiolucent nidus is suggestive of osteoid osteoma. 

Osteoid osteoma is a benign diaphyseal neoplasm most often seen in men between the ages of 5-25 years. Most of the cases appear in the lower extremities commonly in the femur and tibia. A patient typically presents with pain that worsens at night and gets relieved on NSAID intake.

Radiography shows a sclerotic peripheral rim with central radiolucent nidus. A CT scan can be used to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.

Anti-inflammatory medication can be used for long-term medical management. Percutaneous radiofrequency ablation can be used as an outpatient procedure. Removal of the entire nidus can be done by curettage or en-bloc resection.

Other options:

Option A: Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor occurring mainly in the diaphysis of long bones. On X-ray, the cortical destruction and new bone formation in layers are seen as onion peel appearance as shown below.

Option B- Chondroblastoma is a benign cartilaginous tumor occurring mainly in bones around the knee joint. On X-rays, they appear as a well-circumscribed, round, or oval lytic lesion in the center of the epiphysis of long bones with areas of calcification within the tumor. This is termed a mottled appearance.

The image below shows an X-ray with a well-circumscribed, round lytic lesion in the center of the epiphysis of the tibia suggestive of chondroblastoma.

Option D: Osteoblastoma is a benign bone tumor composed of vascular osteoid and newly formed bone. It also presents with pain but has a predilection for the jaw and spine. It occurs in patients in their second decade of life. Radiographically, the tumor appears as a well-defined, expansile lesion in the bone with a radiolucent appearance. Minimal formation of reactive new bone is observed.

questions.text: Which among the following anticancer drugs is least likely to cause pulmonary fibrosis as a side effect?
questions.solution:
Among the given drugs, carboplatin is the least likely to cause pulmonary fibrosis.

The important side effects of carboplatin are:

  • Dose-limiting toxicity is myelosuppression, primarily thrombocytopenia
  • Nausea, neurotoxicity, ototoxicity, and nephrotoxicity (lesser than cisplatin)
  • Hypersensitivity reaction.

Important drugs causing pulmonary fibrosis:

Antimicrobial agents
  1. Isoniazid
  2. Nitrofurantoin
  3. Amphotericin B

  5. Hydrochlorothiazide

questions.text: A 21-year-old previously healthy athlete suffers a sudden cardiac arrest while playing a sport. On autopsy, it was found that there was hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The gene encoding for which of the following proteins is most commonly mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The gene encoding for β-myosin heavy chain (β-MHC) proteins is most commonly mutated in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

HCM is a common autosomal dominant disorder characterized by myocardial hypertrophy, abnormal diastolic filling (with preserved systolic function), and intermittent left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. It is the leading cause of unexplained left ventricular hypertrophy.

It is caused by mutations in genes that encode sarcomeric proteins, including myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C) and β-MHC (MYH7). It can also rarely occur due to mutations in genes coding for cardiac TnI, TnT, and α-tropomyosin.

In HCM, myocardial hypertrophy occurs without ventricular dilation. Furthermore, there is asymmetric septal hypertrophy, where the ventricular septum is disproportionately thickened compared to the left ventricular free wall. The enlarged septum bulges into the ventricular cavity, giving it a banana-like shape. Hypertrophy is most marked in the subaortic region of the septum.

The most important histologic features in HCM are:

  • Massive myocyte hypertrophy
  • Myofiber disarray including that of myocyte bundles, individual myocytes, and contractile elements
  • Fibrotic narrowing of small intramural arteries
  • Interstitial and replacement fibrosis

The images below show normal cardiac myocytes and myofibril disarray in HCM, respectively:

 

Exertional dyspnea due to reduced cardiac output is seen, and a harsh systolic ejection murmur caused due to LVOT obstruction can be heard. Further, atrial fibrillation, stroke due to mural thrombus formation, and ventricular arrhythmias are common complications of HCM. 

β-adrenergic blockers can be used to decrease heart rate and contractility, and implantable cardioverter defibrillators are used for patients with ventricular arrhythmias.

Other options:

Option A: Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) occurs due to truncating mutations in the titin gene. The heart in DCM is flabby and hypo-contracting, in contrast with the thick-walled, heavy, and hyper-contracting heart in HCM. Histology reveals hypertrophied myocytes with hyperchromatic distorted nuclei with a ninja star-like appearance, as shown in the image below. Variable degrees of interstitial and endocardial fibrosis is also present.

Option C: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is an autosomal dominant disorder that occurs due to mutations of genes encoding desmosomal junctional proteins. It typically manifests as right-sided heart failure and can cause sudden cardiac death. Histology shows loss of myocytes, fatty infiltration, and focal fibrosis.

Option D: HCM occurs due to mutations in the gene encoding α-tropomyosin. However, this is rare, and HCM occurs most commonly due to mutations in genes encoding myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C) and β-MHC (MYH7).

Related Pearl: One-liners on Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Missense mutation
  • Most common mutation: Beta-chain of myosin
  • Myofibre disarray on histology
  • Asymmetric septal hypertrophy
  • Diastolic dysfunction
  • Systolic function normal
  • On Echocardiography:
    1. Left ventricular wall thickness >15 mm
    2. Systolic anterior motion of left leaflet
    3. Banana shaped left ventricle

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female patient with a history of epilepsy presented with a seizure episode lasting 30 minutes. The seizure activity was resolved after appropriate therapy was given. The patient complained of muscle pain, and investigations showed the following. What is the next best step in management?
Creatine kinase Markedly increased
Phosphate Increased
Calcium Decreased
Uric acid Elevated
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests prolonged seizure leading to rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury. The next best step in management is volume replacement. He may require up to 10 L of fluid per day.

Rhabdomyolysis occurred in this patient as a result of prolonged seizure activity causing muscle injury and lysis. As a result, the myoglobin released precipitates in the renal tubules resulting in endogenous kidney injury. Aggressive hydration will prevent further tubular injury.

Once the fluid replacement is adequate, diuretics may be administered if the patient has a urinary flow rate of less than 200-300 ml/hour.

Alkaline fluids like sodium bicarbonate in half-normal saline can help prevent injury to renal tubules. However, it may worsen hypocalcemia. Thus, sodium bicarbonate should only be given in patients who do not have hypocalcemia, whose arterial pH is less than 7.5, and serum bicarbonate is less than 30 mEq/L. 

The focus of acute kidney injury management in the setting of rhabdomyolysis is to maintain fluid and electrolyte status in order to maintain tissue perfusion. 

Other options: 

Option A - Diuretic therapy can be used after adequate volume resuscitation has been administered if the urine output is not satisfactory. However, they should not be used as initial treatment as it can worsen acute kidney injury. 

Option C - Hemodialysis can be used in severe cases of rhabdomyolysis to correct electrolyte imbalances but is not the first-line treatment. 

Option D - Rhabdomyolysis is associated with marked hyperphosphatemia and hypocalcemia. The electrolyte levels should be monitored closely during treatment but they are not the primary focus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female excavation worker presents with on and off episodes of productive cough, low-grade fever, and skin lesions as shown below. Sputum culture at 37℃ showed large, spherical, thick-walled budding yeast. A diagnosis of indolent blastomycosis was made. The drug of choice acts by:

choices.text: Ergosterol binding and membrane pore formation

questions.solution:
The drug of choice for indolent blastomycosis is itraconazole and the mechanism of action is inhibition of 14-ɑ-sterol demethylase.

Blastomycosis is a polygranulomatous infection caused due to the inhalation of conidia of Blastomyces dermatidis. It primarily involves the lungs and presents as an abrupt onset of fever, chills, pleuritic chest pain, cough, arthralgias, and myalgias. Cough is initially non-productive but becomes productive as the disease progresses. Skin disease is the most common extrapulmonary manifestation of blastomycosis and may present as the more common verrucous lesions or as ulcers. Most cases have been reported in North America as the region is endemic.

Itraconazole is an azole drug used in the management of blastomycosis. It is the agent of choice for non-CNS extrapulmonary disease and mild-moderate pulmonary disease. In severely immunocompromised or life-threatening CNS disease Liposomal amphotericin B is the initial treatment of choice.

Azoles by inhibiting the enzyme impair the biosynthesis of ergosterol leading to growth arrest. It impairs membrane-bound enzyme systems and disrupts the phospholipid chain of the cell membrane.

Organisms susceptible to treatment by azole antifungals are Candida albicans, C.tropicalis, C.parapsilosis, Cryptococcus neoformans, Blastomyces, Coccidiodes, H.capsulatum, Paracoccidiodes, and dermatophytes.

Organisms resistant to treatment by azole antifungals are candida krusei, Candida glabrata & agents of mucormycosis. Resistance to azoles is by mutations in the ERG11 gene coding for 14-ɑ-sterol demethylase and overexpression of ABC efflux pumps.

The common side effect of azoles is hepatotoxicity. Important specific side effects are:

  • Itraconazole -hypokalemia, edema.
  • Fluconazole -reversible alopecia.
  • Voriconazole -prolong QT interval, auditory and visual hallucinations. Co-administration with sirolimus is contraindicated.
  • Posaconazole -inhibit CYP3A4, prolong QT interval.
  • Isavuconazole -Inhibit CYP3A4.


Other options:

Option B- Liposomal amphotericin B acts by ergosterol binding and membrane pore formation. It is the drug of choice for mucormycosis and cryptococcal meningitis. In severely immunocompromised or life-threatening CNS disease in blastomycosis, Liposomal amphotericin B is the initial treatment of choice.
Important side effects: 

  • Infusion-related fever and chills are maximum with amphotericin B colloidal dispersion(ABCD).
  • Dose-dependent nephrotoxicity. They are contraindicated with other nephrotoxic drugs. Maximum with colloidal amphotericin B (C-AMB).
  • Hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia.
  • Hypochromic normocytic anemia and arachnoiditis with C-AMB.

Option C- Griseofulvin acts by inhibiting microtubule function and disrupting fungal cell division. Important side effects are leukopenia, neutropenia, punctate basophilia, and monocytosis.

Option D- Echinocandins act by inhibiting the 1,3-β-D-glucan synthesis and have no activity against dimorphic fungi.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with a history of frequent infections, fatigue, headaches and blurring of vision. On examination, he has lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood tests show normocytic normochromic anemia and a positive Coombs test, with serum electrophoresis revealing a sharp spike of monoclonal IgM. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has classic symptoms due to hyperviscosity, like headache and blurring of vision, and has a spike of monoclonal IgM. The most likely diagnosis is Waldenström’s macroglobulinemia.

Waldenström’s macroglobulinemia is a plasma cell disorder that results in increased proliferation of memory B cells. These cells produce large amounts of IgM, leading to the classic hyperviscosity syndrome. 

Patients present with anaemia, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, hyperviscosity, or peripheral neuropathy. Most commonly, they present with fatigue, weakness, and oozing of blood from the nasal or oral cavity. 

Haematological examination reveals Coombs’ positive test and rouleaux formation. This condition also has a greater incidence of normocytic normochromic anaemia.

The hyperviscosity state can be treated by plasmapheresis. However, most patients do not require therapy unless they are symptomatic (anaemia, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly.) It can be treated with ibrutinib, which targets the activated BTK mutation. Rituximab with cyclophosphamide can also be used. 

Option A - Hodgkin’s lymphoma is a condition that results in the proliferation of mature B lymphocytes. It is characterised by night sweats, fever, fatigue, and painless supraclavicular and axillary lymphadenopathy. There are no hyperviscosity symptoms or hepatosplenomegaly. 

Option B - Multiple myeloma and Waldenström’s macroglobulinemia are similar in course as they are both plasma cell disorders. However, there are several key differences between the two. Lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, and renal failure, which are more suggestive of myeloma, are not seen in this patient. Also, multiple myeloma has a spike of IgG in the majority of the cases.

Option D - Amyloidosis involves the extracellular deposition of fibrillary proteins. There is usually multiorgan involvement, most commonly leading to renal, splenic, and cardiac disease. The IgM spike that is present in this patient would not be seen in amyloidosis.

questions.text: While going through a patient's file at an infertility clinic, you note his semen analysis is reported to be normal.  What had his semen leukocyte level likely been?
questions.solution:
The normal leucocyte level in human semen is approximately 1 million/ml.

The semen sample should be collected after 2-7 days of ejaculatory abstinence. The patient should collect the sample by masturbation at the doctor's office. If not possible, then the sample may be collected at home and delivered to the laboratory within an hour of collection.

questions.text: A mother brought her 18-month-old child for a routine checkup to the sub-center.  According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme, what is the dosage and frequency of iron and folic acid supplementation in this child?

choices.text: 10 mg iron and 200 mcg folic acid, weekly
10 mg iron and 200 mcg folic acid, biweekly
20 mg iron and 100 mcg folic acid, weekly
20 mg iron and 100 mcg folic acid, biweekly

questions.solution:
According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme, 20 mg of iron and 100 mcg of folic acid are given biweekly to an 18-month-old child.

Prophylactic iron should be withheld in cases of acute illness such as diarrhea and pneumonia. It is also not recommended in known cases of thalassemia major or a history of repeated blood transfusions.

Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme follows a 6x6x6 strategy. Here, 6 groups of beneficiaries are assisted by 6 interventions and 6 institutional mechanisms.

The six distinct groups of beneficiaries are children of 6-59 months of age, children of 5-9 years, adolescents, women in the reproductive age group, pregnant women, and lactating mothers. 

The six interventions are:

  • Iron and folic acid supplementation prophylactically
  • Deworming
  • Behavior change communication campaign
  • Using digital methods and point of care treatment
  • Provision of iron and folic acid fortified foods
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Related Pearl: Causes of Iron Deficiency Anemia

Dietary lack

  • Infants, who are at high risk due to the very small amounts of iron in milk. Human breast milk provides only about 0.3 mg/L of iron.
  • The impoverished, who can have suboptimal diets for socioeconomic reasons at any age
  • Older adults, who often have restricted diets with little meat because of limited income or poor dentition
  • Teenagers, who subsist on junk food

Impaired absorption

  • Sprue
  • Gastrectomy (Billroth II surgery)

Increased requirement

  • Growing infants, children, and adolescents
  • Premenopausal women, particularly during pregnancy.
  • Economically deprived women having multiple, closely spaced pregnancies are at exceptionally high risk.

Chronic blood loss

  • Menorrhagia
  • Carcinoma of the cecum
  • Hookworm infestation

questions.text: A 6-week-old boy presents with low-pitched inspiratory stridor, present since a few days after birth. It subsides with prone positioning and increases with crying.  The observation made on direct laryngoscopy is shown in the image below.  What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of inspiratory stridor since birth with omega-shaped epiglottis, as shown in the image, is suggestive of laryngomalacia. The next step in management is expectant observation.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx. In this condition, the supraglottic portion of the larynx is excessively flaccid and subsequently gets sucked in during inspiration. This results in inspiratory stridor, a feature typical of laryngomalacia. It subsides on placing the child in a prone position but increases with crying. 

Direct laryngoscopy shows an elongated epiglottis that is curled upon itself, making it appear omega (Ω)-shaped. Other features include floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

Treatment of laryngomalacia is mainly conservative, as it self-corrects by the time the child is 2 years of age. Tracheostomy may be required in some cases with severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

Other options:

Options A & C: Endotracheal intubation and IV ceftriaxone are immediate management modalities of acute epiglottitis, which is a medical emergency. It is characterized by sore throat, dysphagia in adults, dyspnoea, and stridor in children, which are both rapidly progressive and associated with fever up to 40°C. Thumb sign, that is, a swollen epiglottis, is observed on a lateral view x-ray of the neck.

Option D: Nebulisation with racemic adrenaline is the immediate management of acute laryngotracheobronchitis. It is characterized by a low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and a barking cough.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.
