questions.text: What is the most common site of vulval cancer?
questions.solution:
The most common site of vulval cancer is the labia majora. 

Vulval cancer is an uncommon malignancy found in elderly women, usually in their 6th and 7th decades of life. It can also be seen in younger women who have been diagnosed with sexually transmitted infections such as HIV and HPV infections.

Risk factors include

  • Chronic vulval irritation
  • Immunosuppression such as in pregnancy
  • HIV infection, condyloma acuminata
  • Smoking, local dystrophies
  • Poor hygiene.

The most common type of vulval cancer is squamous cell cancer. The other types include melanoma, adenocarcinoma, and basal cell cancer. The labia majora is most commonly involved, but the clitoris and perineal area may be involved too. The anterior two-thirds of the vulva is usually involved. 

Clinical features include bleeding and foul-smelling discharge from the ulcerated lesion. Difficulty in micturition in case of urethral involvement, rectal bleeding, and painful defecation in case of rectal involvement.

Vulval cancer mainly proliferates by direct spread to adjacent regions, and by lymphatic spread. Hematogenous spread of vulval cancer is rare. 

Investigations include punch biopsy, cystoscopy in case of urethral involvement, anoscopy or proctoscopy in case of perineal involvement, CT and MRI scans, and lymphography. Lymphatic mapping and sentinel node biopsy should be done to provide adequate surgical management.

The image given below shows a 4*5cm warty lesion on the left labium majus of the vulva, most likely vulvar cancer.

Related Pearl: Staging of Vulval Cancer (FIGO)

Stage Features
I Tumor confined to vulva
IA Lesions ≤2 cm in size, confined to the vulva or perineum and with stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis
IB Lesions >2cm in size or with stromal invasion >1mm , confined to the vulva or perineum, with negative nodes
II Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with negative nodes
III Tumor of any size with/without extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IIIA i) With 1 lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm) or,
  ii)1-2 lymph node micrometastases(<5mm)
IIIB i) With 2 or more lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm), or
  ii) 3 or more lymph node micrometastases (<5 mm)
IIIC With positive nodes with extracapsular spread
IV Tumor invades other regional structures (upper 2/3rd urethra, upper 2/3rd vagina) or distant structures
IVA Tumour invades any of the following:
  i) Upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  ii) Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IVB Any distant metastasis including pelvic lymph nodes

Related Pearl: Treatment Modality in Vulval Cancer

Stage Treatment
1A
  •  Radical wide local excision
     
1B
  • Partial vulvectomy + ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
II
  • Tumor 2-4cm – total vulvectomy + B/L groin lymph node dissection
  • Tumor >4cm or poorly differentiated – radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
 
III
  • Megavoltage radiotherapy
  • Local surgical excision - Radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
  • Local recurrence – chemotherapy
 
IV
  • Chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Local excision on residual tumor
  • ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node + ve – contralateral node removed
  • Femoral lymph node +ve – pelvic lymph node removed

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man, who works in a mortuary was caught by the police while obtaining sexual gratification with a corpse. He is punishable under

IPC - Indian Penal Code, BNS- Bharatiya Nayaya Sanhita
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a man obtaining sexual gratification with dead bodies describes necrophilia. Necrophilia is punishable under Sec 301 BNS (297 IPC).

It deals with a punishment of imprisonment of up to 1 year and/or a fine for both necrophilia and necrophagia.

Necrophilia describes a person who obtains sexual gratification by intercourse with dead bodies. Necrophagia describes a person who sucks the wound, bites the skin, sucks the blood, and eats the flesh of a dead body to derive sexual pleasure.

Other options:

Option A: Sec 292 BNS (290 IPC) - Punishment for frotteurism with fine up to Rs. 1000.

Option B: Sec 296 BNS (294 IPC) - Punishment for exhibitionism with imprisonment of up to 3 months or a fine. 

Option D: Sec 101 BNS (300 IPC) - Definition of murder.

questions.text: A patient with chronic hepatitis C presents with skin rash and joint pains for the past 10 days. He also gives a history of hematuria. Investigations show low C4 levels and positive rheumatoid factor. Which of the following will be abnormal in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms, along with chronic hepatitis C, point to a diagnosis of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. Serum cryoglobulin levels will be abnormal in this condition.

Cryoglobulins are immunoglobulins that precipitate in colder temperatures, leading to a vasculitis syndrome called cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. This syndrome is strongly associated with hepatitis C infection and occurs due to an aberrant immune response to hepatitis C antigens.

Patients present with cutaneous vasculitis, arthritis, and glomerulonephritis. Laboratory findings show circulating cryoprecipitates. Rheumatoid factor is positive in most patients, and complement levels are low.  

Other options:

Option A: ANCA antibodies are positive in granulomatous vasculitis like granulomatosis with polyangiitis(Wegener's syndrome) and Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Option C: Anti-CCP antibodies are positive in cases of rheumatoid arthritis.

Option D: Anti-dsDNA antibodies are positive in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady comes to a cervical cancer screening camp for routine screening. A Pap smear was done and the image of the slide is shown below. What does the given Pap smear show?

choices.text: Atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance

questions.solution:
The image shown is of a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. (HSIL)

According to the Bethesda classification, CIN II (cervical intraepithelial neoplasia) and CIN III are included under high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions.

In CIN II (moderate dysplasia), the cells are mostly intermediate with moderate nuclear enlargement, hyperchromasia, irregular chromatin, and multiple nucleations.

In CIN III (severe dysplasia), cells are mostly parabasal with increased nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, irregular nuclei, and multiple nucleations. 

High grade squamous intraepithelial lesions are at an increased risk of progressing to invasive cancer, and hence need to be treated.

The pictures given below depict the cytology and histology of high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions.

 

Cells seen in a normal Pap smear are:

Type of cell Identification feature
Basal & Parabasal

Cells are small, rounded, basophilic with large nuclei 

Predominantly seen in smears from post-menopausal women
Middle layer (Intermediate)

Cells are squamous cells, transparent and basophillic (blue/green) with vesicular nuclei

Progesterone-dominant
Superficial layer

Cells are acidophilic (pink), with pyknotic nuclei

Estrogen-dominant

The cytology and histology images of a normal Pap smear and cervix are shown below.

 

Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (LSIL) include CIN 1. Intermediate cells are present with mild dysplasia, enlarged nuclei, and irregular outline.

The given images depict the cytology and histology of LSIL.

 

Atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. (ASCUS) are inflammatory cells that cannot be categorized as LSIL or HSIL lesions. 

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: A mother brings her 9-year-old child with complaints of polyuria. On examination, he has growth failure and bitemporal hemianopia. Laboratory evaluation reveals low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality. Findings on the MRI brain are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with MRI showing intracranial mass with foci of calcification at sella turcica and the laboratory findings suggestive of diabetes insipidus point to a diagnosis of craniopharyngioma.

Craniopharyngiomas are tumors that arise from the remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is an intracranial space-occupying lesion. It has bimodal age of presentation. Children usually present with frequent headaches, short stature, bitemporal hemianopsia (due to optic chiasm compression), and polyuria.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick brownish-yellow fluid and are compared to machine oil. They also show radiologically demonstrable calcification.

Treatment of central diabetes insipidus caused by craniopharyngioma includes supplementation with vasopressin analogs desmopressin (DDAVP) and resection of the tumor.

Other options:

Option B: Germinomas of the pituitary stalk also cause central diabetes insipidus. However, they are often missed in routine neuroimaging. 

Option C: Pituitary microadenomas usually present incidentally or with endocrine effects. They are <10mm in size and the tumor is confined to the sella. Visual field deficits are usually caused by pituitary macroadenomas. 

Option D: Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare cause of central diabetes insipidus. Symptoms include dermatological manifestations such as red, scaly papules, pain, and swelling in the limbs, characteristic bony lesions, and disseminated lymph node enlargement.

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

  • Neoplasms: 
    • Pituitary adenomas (most common)
    • Meningioma
    • Metastasis from lung and breast cancers
  • Infiltrative: 
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Genetic: 
    • Wolfram syndrome
    • Hand-Schuller-Christian disease 
  • Infections: 
    • Chronic meningitis
    • Viral encephalitis
    • Toxoplasmosis
  •  Inflammatory:
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  •  Vascular:
    • Sheehan’s syndrome
    • Aneurysm (internal carotid)
  • Head injury (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery
  • Snakebite
  • Lymphocytic hypophysitis

questions.text: Surgical consultation is planned for a neonate in the neonatal intensive care unit. On examination, the following findings were found along with a bifid uvula. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this child?

choices.text: Cleft soft palate repair at 9 to 12 months
Cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months
Cleft soft and hard palate repair at 12-15 months

questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for this patient would be cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months. 

As the neonate in question has a unilateral right-sided cleft lip along with cleft hard and soft palate, the appropriate management for this patient would be (two separate procedures):

  • Cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months, followed by 
  • Hard palate repair with or without a revision surgery for the lip and soft palate at 15 to 18 months.

The different types of facial clefts are shown below:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only

Clefts of the lip, alveolus and hard and soft palate are the common congenital anomalies of the orofacial structures.

Cleft-lip repair techniques:

  • Millard’s rotation advancement technique (most common)
  • Thompson
  • Le Mesurier
  • Tennison–Randall

Techniques of hard palate closure include the use of the following:

  • Unipedicled hard palate mucoperiosteal flaps as in the Wardill-Veau-Kilner repair 
  • Bipedicled hard palate mucoperiosteal flaps as in the von Langenbeck repair

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient was rushed to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. He opens his right eye to pressure to the sternum and the left eye could not be opened on his own due to swelling. When spoken to, he replies with inappropriate words. On stroking with a sharp object on his arms, he withdraws his hand and does not scratch the location. His right pupil is reactive to light while his left pupil is unreactive to light. Calculate the GCS-P score.

GCS-P: Glasgow coma scale-Pupillary reactivity score
questions.solution:
The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) for the given case scenario is 9 and the pupillary reactivity score (PRS) is 1. Thus the GCS-P Score for this patient is 8.

The GCS-P score is calculated by subtracting the PRS from the GCS total score. It is calculated as follows:

GCS for the given case is 9 (E2 V3 M4). PRS for the given case is 1 (P1).

  • E: opening of the right eye to pressure- 2
  • V: inappropriate words- 3
  • M: withdraws his hand on stroking- 4
  • P: one pupil does not react to light- 1
  • Total GCS-P: 2+3+4-1 = 8 

GCS is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury.

Minimum GCS value: 3

Maximum GCS value: 15

The severity of head injury based on GCS:

  • Mild- 13-15
  • Moderate- 9-12
  • Severe- 3-8

Pupillary reactivity score:

  • Both pupils unreactive to light- 2
  • One pupil unreactive to light- 1
  • Neither pupil unreactive to light- 0

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of myocardial infarction  4 weeks back, now developed fever, malaise, pericardial chest pain, and pericardial effusion. A diagnosis of Dressler syndrome is made. What would be the effective management in this case?
questions.solution:
Dressler syndrome occurs 1 week to 8 weeks after MI (post-myocardial infarction syndrome). It is treated with aspirin 650mg every 4 hours.

Dressler syndrome is a post-myocardial infarction syndrome that presents as pleuritic chest pain, fever, and sometimes a pleuritic rub and effusion. It is an autoimmune phenomenon occurring due to immune-complex deposition in the pericardium and lung pleura. It commonly occurs 1-8 weeks after MI. However, it can recur over months.

First-line therapy consists of aspirin. NSAIDs and glucocorticoids are avoided in these patients within 4 weeks of MI as these have the potential to impair wound healing and can lead to ventricular rupture. 

Other complications of MI are:

Myocardial rupture occurs when there is transmural necrosis of a ventricle. Rupture of the left ventricular free wall (most common) results in hemopericardium and cardiac tamponade. Rupture of the ventricular septum creates an acute ventricular septal defect (VSD) and left-to-right shunting. Free-wall rupture usually occurs 3 to 7 days after MI. The risk factors for free-wall rupture include age above 60 years, first MI,  anterior and lateral wall MI, and absence of left ventricular hypertrophy.

Severe pump failure occurs in 10% of patients following acute MI, resulting in cardiogenic shock.

Arrhythmia or a rhythm disturbance is seen in most patients following myocardial infarction. Ventricular fibrillation is the most common arrhythmia within one hour of MI.

A ventricular aneurysm is a late complication that may contribute to thromboembolism.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is being evaluated for seizures. There is no history of weakness of any part of the body. A CT scan was done, and the image is given below. The characteristic sign depicted in the image is ______.

(MCA- middle cerebral artery)
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the CT image showing the bracket sign is suggestive of pericallosal lipoma. 

The most common site of lipoma in the brain is pericallosal region. Calcification at the periphery of the midline lipoma produces the characteristic bracket sign. Approximately 50% of patients present with seizures. Many cases are detected incidentally in utero by antenatal sonography.

Pericallosal lipomas can be grouped into two distinct types based on imaging:

  • Tubulonodular
  • Curvilinear

The tubulonodular variety is usually associated with more severe and extensive abnormalities and patients are symptomatic.

Other options:

Option B: The racing car sign refers to widely spaced lateral ventricles due to agenesis of the corpus callosum with intervening Probst bundles.

Option C: Hyperdense MCA sign- It refers to the hyperdense middle cerebral artery seen on non-enhanced CT images in acute stroke.

Option D: Dural tail sign: It refers to a linear, contrast-enhancing tail-like extension from the tumor, along the dura matter. It is most commonly seen in meningioma (present in about 60% of the cases).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is due to the accumulation of α-synuclein:
questions.solution:
Multiple system atrophy is due to the accumulation of α-synuclein.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is an adult-onset, rare, sporadic, multisystem, rapidly progressive neurodegenerative fatal disease. Loss of cells or degeneration in the striatonigral and olivopontocerebellar structures of the brain and spinal cord is the neuropathological hallmark of MSA.

It is accompanied by glial cytoplasmic inclusion bodies known as α-synuclein inclusions in the oligodendrocyte, which is the characteristic feature of multiple system atrophy

α­-synuclein is a presynaptic neuronal acidic protein and a major component of the Lewy body. When they are present in oligodendrocytes, become more sensitive to oxidative stress and show impaired interaction with the extracellular matrix.

α­-synuclein inclusion is mainly found in MSA and parkinsonism disease. So both diseases are referred to as synucleinopathies.

Clinically MSA is characterized by features of autonomic failures like neurogenic orthostatic hypotension or a neurogenic bladder and either parkinsonism (MSA-p) like tremor/rigidity, or cerebellar syndrome (MSA-c) like loss of muscle coordination/balance.

The below image shows a hot cross bun sign (arrow) due to severe atrophy of pons seen in multiple system atrophy-c.

Other options:

Option A- In amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, the inclusions accumulated are   TDP-43, FUS

Options B and C- In progressive supranuclear palsy and corticobasal degeneration, the inclusion accumulated are Tau protein. Tau protein accumulation is not seen in multiple system atrophy. 

Proteins Disease with Inclusion
Aβ Alzheimer disease
Tau

Alzheimer disease

Frontotemporal degeneration

Parkinson's disease with LRKK2 mutation

Progressive supranuclear palsy

Corticobasal degeneration
TPD-43

Frontotemporal degeneration

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
FUS

Frontotemporal degeneration

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
α- synuclein

Parkinson disease

Multiple system atrophy
Polyglutamine aggregates

Huntington's disease

Some form of spinocerebellar ataxia

Spinal bulbar muscular atrophy

Related Pearl: Synucleinopathies and tauopathies

Synucleinopathies:
  • Parkinson’s disease
  • Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Multiple system atrophy
  • REM behavioral disorder
  • Pure autonomic failure 
Tauopathies:
  • Alzheimer’s disease
  • Down syndrome
  • Progressive supranuclear palsy
  • Corticobasal degeneration
  • Pick’s disease/frontotemporal dementia
  • Chronic traumatic encephalopathy/punch drunk syndrome/dementia pugilistica
  • Postencephalitic parkinsonism
  • Pantothenate kinase-associated degeneration
  • Niemann Pick disease type C
  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman admitted to the surgical ward had been diagnosed with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Which of the following is not a suitable next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Switching to warfarin is not a suitable next step for patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). 

Warfarin should not be administered in HIT until platelets return to their baseline level. If warfarin was administered, give vitamin K to restore the INR to normal. 

Patients with HIT, particularly those with associated thrombosis, have increased thrombin generation that can lead to consumption of protein C. If these patients are given warfarin without a concomitant parenteral anticoagulant to inhibit thrombin or thrombin generation, the further decrease in protein C levels induced by the vitamin K antagonist can trigger skin necrosis.

HIT is a life-threatening complication of exposure to heparin. It occurs more with unfractionated heparin than with low molecular weight (LMW) heparin. It is more common in surgical patients and more common in women than in men.

HIT results from an autoantibody directed against endogenous platelet factor 4 (PF4) in complex with heparin. These antibodies bind simultaneously to the heparin-PF4 complex and to platelet Fc receptors, activating the platelets and generating platelet microparticles. This can cause catastrophic arterial and venous thrombosis.

Features:

  • Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count of ≤100,000/μL or a decrease in platelet count of ≥50%
  • Platelet count falls 5–10 days after starting heparin.
  • Venous thrombosis more common than arterial thrombosis

Investigations:

  1. ELISA to detect antibodies against heparin-PF4 complexes (most sensitive)
  2. Platelet activation assays
  3. Serotonin release assay (most specific)

Treatment:

  1. Stop all heparin.
  2. Give an alternative anticoagulant, such as lepirudin, argatroban, bivalirudin, fondaparinux or rivaroxaban.
  3. Do not give platelet transfusions.

Other options: 

Option A - Heparin should be discontinued if the patient has HIT. 

Option B - Lepirudin can be administered as it is an alternative anticoagulant. 

Option D - Rivaroxaban can be given as it is an alternative anticoagulant.

questions.text: A seven-year-old boy presented to the emergency department with high-grade fever, headaches, confusion, and projectile vomiting. A lumbar puncture was done and a gram stain of the cerebrospinal fluid revealed gram-negative diplococci in pairs inside polymorphs. Which of the following is not true about the organism implicated in this condition?

choices.text: It is catalase and oxidase positive
It can utilize glucose and maltose
It can grow in ordinary culture media
The human nasopharynx is the only reservoir of this organism

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitides (Meningococcus). It cannot grow in ordinary culture media.

Meningococcus requires media enriched with blood, serum, or ascitic fluid which promotes growth by neutralizing certain inhibiting factors. Blood agar, chocolate agar, and Thayer Martin media are used to culture meningococci. They form smooth, bluish-grey, round, glistening colonies on solid media. They grow best at a pH of 7.4-7.6.

Meningococci are gram-negative, oval, or spherical cocci, usually found in pairs inside polymorphs (Image shown below). They are catalase and oxidase positive and utilize glucose and maltose, which helps them differentiate from gonococcus, which can only utilize glucose.

The human nasopharynx is the only known reservoir of meningococcus. It is implicated in diseases including cerebrospinal meningitis and meningococcal septicemia. It travels to the meninges from the nasopharynx through the perineural sheath of the olfactory nerve through the cribriform plate. On reaching the central nervous system, a suppurative lesion of the meninges is set up, involving the cortex and the spinal cord. Case fatality is high and survivors may suffer from deafness or blindness as long-term sequelae. 

It can also lead to septicemia which presents as fever with chills, shock, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and multi-system failure. This is also known as Waterhouse- Friderichsen syndrome.  

Treatment of meningococcal meningitis includes intravenous Penicillin G. Ceftriaxone or Ceftazidime can be used to initiate the treatment before the etiology is known. 

Chemoprophylaxis is given to the household and other close contacts of a patient with meningococcal disease. Rifampicin or ciprofloxacin is recommended for chemoprophylaxis. 

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

Appropriate culture media for various bacteria:

Organism Medium for culture

ludlam’s medium
salt milk agar
Strep. Pyogenes Crystal violet blood agar
Neisseria meningitidis Thayer martin medium
Corynebacterium Potassium tellurite agar
Tinsdale medium
Mcleod medium
B.anthrax PLET medium
B.cereus MYPA (Mannitol egg yolk phenol red polymyxin agar)
PEMBA(polymyxin in egg yolk mannitol bromothymol blue agar
Clostridium  CCFA ( cefoxitin cycloserine fructose agar)
Shigella DCA, XLD, SSA
Salmonella Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium
Vibrio TCBS
Monsur GTTA
Pseudomonas Cetrimide agar
B.pseudomallei Ashdown medium
H. influenza Fildes agar
Levinthal medium
Bordetella Bordet-Gengou glycerine potato blood agar
Brucella Casteneda medium
B.burgdorferi BSK medium
Campylobacter

Skirrow's, Butzler's and Campy BAP media
Legionella pneumophilia

questions.text: A  first-born, 5-weeks-old male infant presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. The abdominal radiograph shows the following finding. Which of the following will be the preferred investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the radiographic image showing the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble) are suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). Ultrasound examination is the investigation of choice for this condition.

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) is characterized by abnormal thickening of the pylorus muscles in the stomach leading to gastric outlet obstruction. First-born male infants are at the highest risk.

Infants usually present with 

  • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting due to gastric outlet obstruction, most commonly between 3 and 6 weeks of age.
  • Olive-shaped mass palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium.
  • Visible peristalsis after feeding, moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.
  • Metabolic abnormalities include hypokalemic, hypochloremic, metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.

Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm.

Ultrasound signs seen in Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric stenosis are:

  • Target sign (Hypoechoic thickened pyloric muscle with a hyperechoic central mucosa)
  • Cervix sign
  • Nipple sign.
  • Antral nipple sign

The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected before proceeding to surgery. The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

The ultrasound image given above shows hypertrophied pylorus resembling that of the uterine cervix (cervix sign) and double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protruding into the stomach, (Nipple sign).

The ultrasound image given above shows redundant pyloric mucosa protruding into the antrum - Antral nipple sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with a gradually progressive swelling over the right upper leg associated with pain. His radiographic image is shown below. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which among the following is false?

choices.text: Radioisotope scan would show marked increase in activity
It is mostly seen on femoral or tibial metaphysis
The condition is a form of chronic osteomyelitis
Staphylococcus aureus would mostly be involved

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiographic image showing a lytic lesion with a sclerotic rim are suggestive of Brodie's abscess which is a form of subacute osteomyelitis, not a chronic form.

The patient is usually a child or adolescent, who would present with pain and swelling on the affected limb. The temperature, WBC counts, and blood cultures are usually normal, with sometimes elevated ESR. There is often very little to suggest an infection.

The radioisotope scan shows markedly increased activity. The organism mostly involved would be staphylococcus aureus.

It most commonly involves the metaphysis of the proximal tibia and distal femur. The patient presents with intermittent pain and tenderness in the affected area. A biopsy is often needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Immobilization and antibiotics (flucloxacillin and fusidic acid) IV for 4-5 days and followed by orally for another 6 weeks. The healing may take up to 12 months.

Curettage is needed if the X-rays show no healing after conservative management.

questions.text: A 56 year old male patient has been on an antipsychotic for the last 2 years. He presents with stereotypical, repetitive and involuntary tic like movements of the face, eyelid spasm, and slow twisting movements of the tongue. Diagnose and identify the proposed mechanism of action of the condition.
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is tardive dyskinesia and the proposed mechanism of action is dopamine receptor supersensitivity.

Tardive dyskinesia is an extrapyramidal side effect (EPSE) of antipsychotic drugs that present after long-term usage. It usually presents after months to years of drug usage. It is more common in the elderly population. It is characterized by orofacial involvement. Stereotypical involuntary, repetitive tic-like movements of the face, eyelid spasm, and slow twisting movements of the tongue are the presenting symptoms. The movements disappear during sleep and may vary in intensity with relation to the degree of emotional distress.

The proposed mechanism of action is dopamine postsynaptic receptor supersensitivity leading to increased nigrostriatal dopaminergic activity. Management of tardive dyskinesia-

  • FDA-approved VMAT2 inhibitors - valbenazine and deutetrabenazine are used as drugs for treatment.
  • Anticholinergics are contraindicated as they worsen the symptoms.
  • Switching patients to clozapine can be effective

Note:

Dystonia - The characteristic symptoms for diagnosis of dystonia are acute onset within 1-5 days of starting treatment. It is more common in the younger population. The proposed mechanism of action is D2 blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway. There is typical involvement of head and neck muscles and presents in a variety of forms, such as torticollis, trismus, “mouth opening” dystonia, grimacing, dysarthria, oculogyric crisis, blepharospasm, and swallowing difficulties.

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

Adverse reactions

questions.text:
A young man with type 1 diabetes mellitus is brought with severe nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. A bolus of both normal saline and IV short-acting insulin is administered. What is the next step in management?

Random blood sugar: 500mg/dl
Urine ketones ++
Serum potassium - 5.4mEq/L

choices.text: Start normal saline infusion and continuous insulin infusion
Administer bicarbonate 50 mEq in sterile water
Start continuous insulin infusion and administer potassium

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The next step in management is to start normal saline infusion and continuous insulin infusion.

DKA is a complication of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus common in type 1 diabetes mellitus but can also occur in type 2. It occurs in the setting of absolute or relative insulin deficiency along with glucagon excess leading to extreme hyperglycemia.

Clinical features include severe nausea, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, and severe volume depletion. Signs include Kussmaul breathing, fruity odor on the patient’s breath, tachycardia, dehydration, and hypotension. 

The diagnosis of DKA is made based on the following parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia >250 mg/dL
  • Ketosis or ketones in the urine
  • Metabolic acidosis with pH <7.4 and HCO3 <15 mEq/L
  • High anion gap due to ketoacids and lactic acidosis

Pseudohyponatremia (dilutional) is seen as a result of hyperglycemia due to osmotic shift. Normal sodium levels on admission indicate severe dehydration. Potassium levels at presentation may be normal or elevated despite total body deficit, due to intracellular shift. If the initial serum potassium <3.3 mEq/L, insulin should be administered only after the correction of hypokalemia. This is because treatment with insulin and fluids can worsen hypokalemia.

The mainstay management of diabetic ketoacidosis includes urgent fluid resuscitation and maintenance, along with insulin therapy, electrolyte replacement, and supportive care. The algorithm of management is given below. 

Criteria for resolution of ketoacidosis include:
  • Blood glucose <200 mg/dL, and
  • Two of the following criteria:
    • Serum bicarbonate level ≥15 mEq/L
    • Venous pH >7.3
    • Anion gap ≤12 mEq/L

Related Pearl: Comparative Features of Diabetic Ketoacidosis and Hyperglycemic Hyperosmolar State

questions.text: In a modern sewage treatment plant, a light green oxidized flocculent material is formed after secondary treatment with the trickling filter method. This material is called as____.
questions.solution:
The light green oxidized sewage formed after secondary treatment (trickling filter method) is called humus. It is then led towards the secondary sedimentation.

Other options:

Option B- Sludge is the organic matter that settles down in the tank during the sedimentation step of the primary treatment of sewage.

Option C- The effluent, formed from the primary sedimentation tank, contains a proportion of organic matter in solution or colloidal state and numerous living organisms.

Option D-Sullage is the waste water that doesn't contain human excreta.

Related Pearl: Modern Sewage Treatment

Primary treatment:

  • Screening
    • A large metal screen is used to intercept large floating objects like dead animals, wood, rags, etc., so as to prevent clogging
  • Grit chamber
    • It is also called detritus chamber
    • It allows for the settlement of heavier solids like gravel or sand and permits the organic matter to flow through
    • The grit that is collected at the bottom is then disposed of
  • Primary sedimentation
    • In a primary sedimentation tank, sewage is allowed to flow slowly so that suspended matter that sediments form sludge which is then removed
    • Biological action takes place here and breaks down complex organic solids
    • Scum in the form of grease and fat collects on top of the tank
    • Sometimes, chemicals like lime are added to the effluent to enhance precipitation

Secondary treatment:

The effluent from the primary sedimentation tank is subjected to aerobic oxidation by trickling filter method or activated sludge process.

  • Trickling filter method
    • The trickling or percolating filter is a bed of crushed stones or clinker
    •  Effluent from the primary sedimentation tank is spread over the filter bed and as it percolates through it, it gets oxidized by bacterial flora. There is no actual filtration that occurs.
    • The oxidized sewage forms a light green material called humus. It is then led into secondary sedimentation tanks.
  • Activated sludge process
    • The heart of the activated sludge process is the aeration tank
    • In these tanks, the effluent from primary sedimentation is mixed with activated or return sludge (sludge from the final settling tank) and is then exposed to aeration for 6 to 8 hours.
    • During aeration, organic matter is oxidized into carbon dioxide, nitrates and water with the help of aerobic bacteria in the activated sludge.
  • Secondary sedimentation
    • From the trickling filters or aeration tanks, the oxidized sewage is allowed into a secondary sedimentation tank where it is held for 2 – 3 hours
    • Here, aerated sludge or activated sludge is formed, part of which is pumped back into an aeration tank
  • Sludge digestion
    • Sludge digestion can be done by incubating it under favourable conditions to allow anaerobic auto-digestion. This is done in sludge digestion tanks.
    • Disposal of sludge is also done by sea disposal
    • Sludge can also be disposed of by composting with solid refuse
  • Disposal of effluent
    • Disposal of effluent can be done by dilution in water bodies which has to then be chlorinated
    • Disposal on land is possible if the effluent can be used for irrigation purposes

questions.text: A 30-year-old  man has been admitted in the hospital for 6 months after a road traffic accident. He has spontaneous cycles of eye opening and closing. Grimacing and non-purposeful movements are also seen. He is able to ventilate without mechanical support. Which of these electroencephalogram (EEG) findings are seen in this state?

choices.text: Low amplitude delta with theta activity
High amplitude delta and theta activity

questions.solution:
The given case vignette shows features of a vegetative state. The EEG findings in a vegetative state are high amplitude delta and theta activity and the absence of EEG features of sleep.

The other features of a vegetative state:

  • Spontaneous cycling of eye-opening and closing.
  • Grimacing and non-purposeful movements
  • Usually able to ventilate without mechanical support.

These features differentiate it from a coma in which eye-opening and movements are not seen. In both these states, there is no awareness in the patient.

Other options:

Option A- Low amplitude delta with intermittent bursts of theta and alpha activity is seen in a coma. The patient will be unresponsive and arousal will not be possible. The brainstem is functionally intact and the arterial blood gases are also normal.

Option C- Isoelectric EEG pattern is seen in brain-stem death. There is no respiratory response to apneic oxygenation test along with the total loss of brain-stem reflexes.
 
Option D- EEG features of REM sleep are seen in normal sleep. The above mentioned scenario does not indicate normal sleep.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old male patient came with complaints of difficulty in breathing, cough, fatigue, and malaise for a few months. His sputum was chunky, gelatinous, and PAS-positive. A histological specimen of the lung is given below. The above condition is caused by autoantibodies against the function of _______.

PAS: Periodic acid–schiff 

GM-CSF: Granulocyte-macrophage - colony stimulating factor
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of dyspnea, cough with chunky, gelatinous, PAS-positive sputum, and histological specimen of lung showing alveoli filled with pink, dense, homogeneous, amorphous material with the intact alveolar wall are suggestive of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)which is caused by autoantibodies against the function of granulocyte- macrophage-colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF).

PAP is an interstitial lung disease caused by defect in the function of pulmonary macrophages. This is due to reduced signaling of GM-CSF which results in the accumulation of surfactants in the intra-alveolar and bronchiolar spaces. Surfactant proteins can be demonstrated by immunohistochemical stains. It is predominantly seen in adults. They present with progressive dyspnoea, cough with sputum containing gelatinous, chunky PAS-positive material. It can be associated with clubbing and cyanosis. On radiological examination, asymmetric patchy opacifications mainly on the hilar regions of both lungs are seen. GM-CSF replacement therapy and whole-lung lavage are effective treatments. 

PAP is classified into 3 types:

Autoimmune PAP is due to the presence of circulating antibodies that bind and neutralize the function of GM-CSF. It primarily occurs in adults and this represents 90% of all cases. Autoimmune PAP lacks familial predisposition. 

Secondary PAP is due to the diverse diseases that impair the GM-CSF signaled macrophage function, leading to inadequate clearance of surfactant from alveolar spaces.

Hereditary PAP is due to GM-CSF and GM-CSF receptor gene mutations. This occurs in neonates and is extremely rare.

Other options:

Option A. Lecithin (dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine), Option B. protein A, Option C protein B are surfactants. The deficiency of these surfactants causes respiratory distress syndrome.

questions.text: The most abundant subclass of IgG present in the serum is ______.
questions.solution:
IgG1 is the most abundant subclass of IgG present in serum. It represents about 65% of the total IgG.

IgG antibody has 4 subclasses. It plays a role in immunological reactions such as complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of viruses and toxins. IgG1 has the highest concentration in the serum, while IgG4 has the lowest concentration. 

IgG is the only maternal immunoglobulin that is normally transported across the placenta, especially the IgG1 and IgG3 subclasses. 

IgG2 is directed against polysaccharide antigens and hence is important in the host defense mechanism against encapsulated bacteria.

IgG3 is an effective activator of the complement, whereas IgG4 does not activate complement due to its compact structure.

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with muscle pain, early fatigue, painful cramps, and cola-colored urine after joining a gym. The muscle biopsy reveals the findings shown in the slide below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A clinical scenario of a 20-year-old presenting with muscle cramps, pain, fatigue, and likely myoglobinuria (causing cola-colored urine), and muscle biopsy specimen showing vacuolar myopathy is suggestive of McArdle's disease. It is caused by the deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase. 

McArdle disease, also known as type V glycogen storage disorder, is an autosomal recessive condition. It typically presents during late childhood or in the second decade of life. The muscle glycogen phosphorylase enzyme deficiency interferes with ATP generation by glycogenolysis in the muscles. This causes muscle glycogen accumulation.

Symptoms are exercise intolerance associated with muscle cramps. Due to high-intensity exercise, sudden persistent muscle contraction occurs. This leads to severe muscle damage resulting in a massive release of muscle proteins and myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria secondary to rhabdomyolysis leads to the passage of burgundy-colored urine in some patients. 

A unique feature associated with McArdle is the improvement in symptoms after a rest for a few minutes. This is termed as the second wind phenomenon. 

Standard diagnosis includes muscle biopsy, which shows periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive vacuoles of high glycogen content due to lack of myophosphorylase and genetic testing (PYGM gene sequencing). Avoiding strenuous exercise prevents symptoms. Glucose administration before exercise can improve tolerance. Vitamin B6 is also recommended.

Other options:

Option B: Cori's disease is due to the deficiency of glycogen debranching enzyme. Infants usually present with ketotic hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and hyperlipidemia. Muscle weaknesses are mostly seen in the third to the fourth decade of life. 

Option C: Hers disease is due to the deficiency of liver glycogen phosphorylase. Untreated children present with poor growth, ketotic hypoglycemia, and hepatomegaly.

Option D: Andersen disease is due to the deficiency of glycogen branching enzyme. Infants present with failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, progressive liver cirrhosis, and cardiomyopathy. Death occurs mostly by the age of 5 due to liver failure. 

Related Pearl: Glycogen Storage Diseases

questions.text: Mutation in the HFE gene on the short arm of the 6th chromosome is observed during the DNA sequencing study of a patient. The histopathology section of the liver is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mutation in the HFE gene on the short arm of the 6th chromosome and the histopathology section of the liver showing golden yellow hemosiderin granules are suggestive of hemochromatosis.

Hereditary hemochromatosis is caused due to mutation of the homeostatic iron regulator gene (HFE) leads to excessive absorption of iron, which gets deposited in the liver, and pancreas, followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs. Histopathology shows golden yellow hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes which stain positive with Prussian blue stain. Serum iron level is raised. Serum ferritin level is significantly increased.

Hepatomegaly will be present in the majority of the patients with symptoms. Skin shows bronze pigmentation due to the increased deposition of iron and melanin over the dermis. Diabetes mellitus is seen in advanced diseases due to the direct damage of the pancreatic islet cells by the deposition of iron. Arthropathy develops in some patients. The joints of the hands, especially the second and third metacarpophalangeal joints, are usually the first joints involved. Congestive cardiac failure is the most common cardiac manifestation of hemochromatosis. Hypogonadism due to failure of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis by deposition of iron. This may manifest as testicular atrophy or amenorrhea

It is managed by weekly or twice weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL. Chelating agents like subcutaneous deferoxamine and oral deferasirox are effective. 

Other options:

Option A: Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder due to the mutation in the ATP7B gene. This leads to deficiency of ATP7B protein deficiency causing impaired excretion of biliary copper into bile. This results in copper toxicity primarily involving the liver, brain, and eyes. 

Option B: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. This is due to the mutation of the canalicular membrane protein transporter gene, multidrug resistance-associated protein 2 (MRP2). The liver may appear grossly black due to the accumulation of dark, coarsely granular pigment in the lysosomes of centrilobular hepatocytes. 

Option C: Rotor syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. This is due to a deficiency of canalicular membrane protein transporter organic acid transporter protein (OATP).

questions.text:
A 28-year-old primigravida in her third trimester presented with a history of sudden onset of painless vaginal bleeding. On evaluation, a diagnosis of placenta previa was made. A decision was taken to manage her condition using the McAfee and Johnson regimen. Which of the following criteria should be met for the same?

1) Assured fetal well being

2) Duration of pregnancy > 37 weeks

3) No active vaginal bleeding 

4) Maternal hemoglobin > 10g%
questions.solution:
The patient has been diagnosed with placenta previa. The criteria which have to be met for the expectant management regimen proposed by McAfee and Johnson include assured fetal well-being, no active vaginal bleeding, and maternal hemoglobin > 10 g%. 

A patient with diagnosed placenta previa and duration of pregnancy >37 weeks cannot be managed expectantly. The aim of conservative management is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health. Termination of expectant management is done at 37 weeks when the fetus is sufficiently mature to survive.

McAfee and Johnson expectant management regimen:

Prerequisites:

  • Availability of blood for transfusion 
  • Facilities for cesarean sections are available 

Selection of cases for expectant management for placenta previa: 

  1. Mother is hemodynamically stable (Hb >10 g% and/or hematocrit > 30%) 
  2. Duration of pregnancy < 37 weeks 
  3. No active vaginal bleeding 
  4. The fetus was normal on ultrasound and reactive on cardiotocography

Conduct of expectant treatment: 

  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity 
  • Bed rest or pelvic rest
  • Periodic monitoring of mother for bleeding PV
  • Fetal surveillance with USG  
  • Tocolytics if contractions are present
  • Anti-D to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women

questions.text: In northern, southern and western blot tests respectively, the samples being tested are?
questions.solution:
The test samples in northern, southern, and western blot tests are RNA, DNA, and protein respectively. 

Blot transfer tests are of three types based on the sample being tested and the probes used. Here is a table summarizing the test samples and probes used in the blot transfer test.

  Northern blot Southern blot Western blot
Test sample RNA DNA Protein
Probe  cDNA cDNA Antibody

 

The common step between them is the transfer of the separated fragments onto a specific blotting paper after gel electrophoresis. The probe is then added and it binds to complementary fragments which are then detected by specific methods like X-ray imaging or autoradiography.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl was on levetiracetam for the treatment of focal seizures for the past 6 months. Identify the false statement about the drug.

choices.text: Acts by inhibiting N-type Ca channels
Acts by inhibiting synaptic vesicle protein 2A

questions.solution:
The false statement is that behavioral changes are common with levetiracetam. Behavioral changes are a less common side effect of levetiracetem, but are serious when they do occur. 

The common side effects of levetiracetam are somnolence, asthenia, ataxia, and dizziness. Behavioral changes are less common but serious.

Although the main mechanism of action of levetiracetam is inhibition of synaptic vesicle protein 2A (SV2A), it also acts by inhibiting N-type Ca channels. SV2A inhibition may modify the release of glutamate and GABA from pre-synaptic vesicles and vesicle recycling following exocytosis of neurotransmitters. It is also used as an add-on treatment for focal seizures in adults and children, for primary onset tonic-clonic seizures, and for myoclonic seizures of JME.

Levetiracetam does not induce enzymes and is not a substrate for CYPs, hence there are minimal drug interactions compared to other anti-epileptic drugs. 95% of the drug is excreted via the kidneys.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of common anti-epileptics

questions.text: A patient with Graves' disease presents with the following finding. Which statement regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: Acropachy is strongly associated with this condition.
It occurs in more than 50% of patients with Graves' disease.
It occurs almost always in the presence of moderate or severe form of ophthalmopathy.
Skin changes can occur after trauma.

questions.solution:
The given scenario along with the image is suggestive of thyroid dermopathy. It occurs in <5% of patients with Graves’ disease. Thyroid dermopathy is almost always associated with ophthalmopathy.

Thyroid dermopathy is most frequently observed over the anterolateral parts of the lower leg. Hence, it is termed pretibial myxedema. Skin changes can occur at other sites, particularly after trauma. The typical lesion is a noninflamed, indurated plaque with a deep pink or purple color and orange peel-textured papules.

Thyroid acropachy refers to a form of clubbing rarely observed in Graves’ disease. It is strongly associated with thyroid dermopathy.

Thyroid dermopathy usually does not need any active treatment, but if necessary, treatment includes topical, high-potency glucocorticoid ointment under an occlusive dressing or octreotide can be useful in some cases.

The following image shows thyroid dermopathy and acropachy:

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient presented to the casualty with severe upper abdominal pain and recurrent retching without vomiting. A nasogastric tube insertion was tried but it was unsuccessful. His X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is most likely present in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and X-ray showing a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen are suggestive of gastric volvulus. Borchardt's triad will most likely be present in a case of gastric volvulus.

Gastric volvulus is the rotation of the gastric fundus occurring on the longitudinal (organoaxial) or vertical (mesenteroaxial) axis of the stomach. This occurs due to the laxity in the peritoneal attachment of the stomach.

The Borchardt triad comprises:

  • Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain
  • Recurrent retching with minimal vomitus
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube

Organoaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the longitudinal axis of the stomach It is the most common type and often occurs acutely. It is associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Mesenteroaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the vertical axis. It is partial (<180 degrees) and recurrent. It is not associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

 

Radiograph images shows a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen due to rotation of gastric fundus on the axis of the stomach. Gastric volvulus can be confirmed by a barium study. In barium study, the stomach may be inverted with greater curvature above the lesser curvature, or as the pylorus above the cardia. 

Emergency surgery is indicated for acute volvulus which includes decompression, reduction, and prevention of recurrence. The surgical intervention includes simple gastropexy with diaphragmatic hernia repair. 

Other options:

Option B- Dieulafoy’s triad is seen in acute appendicitis. It comprises of hypersensitiveness of skin, reflex muscular contraction, tenderness at Mc Burney’s point.

Option C- Quincke's triad is seen in hemobilia. It comprises upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage, abdominal pain, and obstructive jaundice.

Option D- Saint's triad comprises hiatus hernia, gallstones, and colonic diverticulosis.

Related Pearl: Triads in Surgery

Triad

Seen in

Components

Borchardt’s Triad

Gastric Volvulus

Epigastric pain + Inability to vomit + Inability to pass a nasogastric tube

Cushing’s Triad

Intracranial hypertension

Hypertension + Bradycardia + Irregular respiration

Dieulafoy’s Triad

Acute appendicitis

Hypersensitiveness of skin + Reflex muscular contraction + Tenderness at Mc Burney’s point

Galezia's Triad

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 8 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic for her routine evaluation. On performing a bimanual examination, you notice regular rhythmic contractions of the uterine wall. Which early sign of pregnancy is being elicited here?
questions.solution:
The early sign of pregnancy being elicited here is the Palmer's sign.

Palmer’s sign denotes the regular, rhythmic contractions of the uterine wall during a bimanual examination. It is seen as early as 4-8 weeks of gestation.

Other options:

Option A- Hegar’s sign is an early sign of pregnancy. At 6-8 weeks of gestation, the lower part of the uterus softens and on bimanual examination, the approximation of vaginal and abdominal fingers is possible.

Option C- Osiander's sign describes the pulsations felt in the lateral fornix due to increased vascularity. It is seen around 8 weeks of gestation.

Option D- Goodell’s sign is a sign of early pregnancy which describes the marked softening of the cervix in contrast to the non-pregnant state. It is seen around 6-8 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of seizures. On examination, she has a port-wine stain on her face. CT scan showed characteristic tram-track calcifications in the cerebral cortex. Which of the following is not an ocular finding commonly associated with this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Sturge-Weber syndrome. Optic nerve glioma is not an ocular finding associated with the Sturge-Weber syndrome, it is associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. 

The characteristic features of Sturge-Weber syndrome include port-wine stain on the face, a history of seizures, and tram-track calcifications in the cerebral cortex. The ocular findings commonly associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome are choroidal hemangioma, iris heterochromia, and ipsilateral glaucoma.

Important ocular manifestations in neurofibromatosis type 1 include:

  • Eyelid plexiform neurofibroma- S-shaped deformity of the upper lid, with a 'bag of worms' like texture.
  • Optic nerve glioma - A pilocytic astrocytoma that typically occurs in young children.
  • Bilateral Lisch nodules are hamartomas that develop during the second–third decades.
  • Spheno-orbital encephalocele - due to dysplasia of the greater wing of the sphenoid

The various neurocutaneous syndromes and their ocular manifestations are as follows: 

Neuro-
cutaneous syndrome		 Ocular
manifestations
Neuro-fibromatosis
type 1

Eyelid plexiform neurofibroma

Optic nerve glioma

Bilateral Lisch nodules

Congenital ectropion uveae

Prominent corneal nerves

Congenital glaucoma

Spheno-orbital encephalocele 
Neuro-fibromatosis
type 2

Posterior subcapsular cataract

Hamartomas of the
retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and retina
