questions.text:
An unconscious man without any ID on him is brought to the casualty by bystanders after an RTA. His blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. USG abdomen reveals a ruptured spleen. He is shifted for surgery without obtaining consent. What is the medico-legal justification for this course of action called?

ID - Identity document
RTA - Road traffic accident
questions.solution:
The medico-legal justification for this course of action is the doctrine of implied consent.

According to IPC section 92, if a patient is unconscious and there is an imminent danger to the life of the patient and there is no designated relative or the relative is unavailable, then consent is deemed to have been given. This is called the doctrine of implied consent. However, for this doctrine to be applicable, the patient must require emergency treatment to save life or limb. This doctrine is not applicable in a non-emergency or after the emergency has been handled adequately.

Other options:

Option A: Res ipsa loquitur means 'the thing speaks for itself'. It is used as supportive evidence of negligence on the part of the doctor. Say leaving behind a scalpel or scissors whilst operating leading to sepsis/peritonitis speaks for itself.

Option C: A competent person who is aware of being entitled to informed consent may give up the right to give consent, if he so wishes. This is called a therapeutic waiver.

Option D: If full disclosure is disadvantageous to the patient (e.g. in patients with anxiety), then the doctor can withhold certain information from the patient. However, he should disclose the full information to a competent relative of the patient. This is called therapeutic privilege.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old patient presents with a history of urinary frequency, nocturia, and excessive thirst. Her laboratory evaluation results are given below. Brain MRI shows the absence of a bright spot in the pituitary. Her past medical history includes an episode of meningitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Urine osmolarity <300 mOsm/L
Urine output >50 ml/kg/day
Random blood glucose 150 mg/dl
Antidiuretic hormone level (ADH) Decreased
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the lab results indicating increased urine output with low urine osmolarity and decreased ADH levels suggest the diagnosis of central diabetes insipidus. 

Diabetes insipidus can be of two types - central or peripheral (nephrogenic). Central DI occurs due to deficiency of ADH. 

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder of the posterior pituitary. It is characterized by decreased ADH leading to large volumes of urine production. Patients present with excessive thirst, nocturia, and urinary frequency. The urine is dilute with an osmolarity of < 300 mOsm/L. The 24-hour urine volume is >40 ml/kg and the basal plasma ADH is <1 pg/ml.

Central DI occurs due to damage to the neurohypophysis in the posterior pituitary. It can be congenital or acquired. In this patient, meningitis has led to the development of DI. 

Central DI can be treated with desmopressin, an ADH analogue. Nephrogenic DI requires treatment with a thiazide diuretic, amiloride, low sodium diet, and indomethacin. 

In nephrogenic DI, ADH levels may be normal or increased because the kidney has become resistant to its effects. The two can be differentiated by the water deprivation test. (Option A)

Option B - Primary polydipsia would have a bright spot on the brain MRI. Primary polydipsia presents with an excessive thirst that reduces the serum osmolarity. There is a compensatory increase in free water excretion that offsets the increased intake to maintain a normal serum sodium level. 

Option D - Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion would have increased ADH secretion, concentrated urine, and hyponatremia. 

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 

  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

  • Neoplasms: 
    • Pituitary adenomas (most common)
    • Meningioma
    • Metastasis from lung and breast cancers
  • Infiltrative: 
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Genetic: 
    • Wolfram syndrome
    • Hand-Schuller-Christian disease 
  • Infections: 
    • Chronic meningitis
    • Viral encephalitis
    • Toxoplasmosis
  •  Inflammatory:
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  •  Vascular:
    • Sheehan’s syndrome
    • Aneurysm (internal carotid)
  • Head injury (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery
  • Snakebite
  • Lymphocytic hypophysitis

questions.text:
A 38-year-old post-cholecystectomy patient presents with pain in the right upper quadrant on the third postoperative day. Evaluation reveals a collection in Morrison's pouch. A bile leak was suspected. Which of the following investigations will be most helpful in this case?

ERCP - Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

MRCP - Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography

HIDA - Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid 

CT - Computed tomography
questions.solution:
ERCP is the most useful investigation in a patient suspected of post-cholecystectomy biliary leaks. It has the advantage of being diagnostic as well as therapeutic.

ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography) is useful post-cholecystectomy as there is a high likelihood of a retained stone and stone extraction and or temporary stenting may be required. 

ERCP allows the insertion of a stent in the bile duct to manage the biliary leak. 

The most common post-cholecystectomy biliary leak is from the cystic duct. This can be managed by placing a biliary endoprosthesis (stent) in the common bile duct across the origin.

Other options:

Option A- MRCP (magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography) can demonstrate fluid collection arising from the biliary leak but, it can not differentiate these from other fluid collections. 

Option C and Option D- Both HIDA (hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid) scintigraphy and CT can demonstrate biliary leaks. HIDA is more sensitive and CT provides more anatomical information.

questions.text: A 30-year-old truck driver presented with a painless ulcer in the genital area. On examination, a single ulcer with an indurated base was found. An image of the tissue section is shown below. Identify the staining method.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by Levaditi's method. Single painless ulcer with indurated base points towards a diagnosis of syphilis.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacillus. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Intrauterine transmission can lead to congenital syphilis. It shows corkscrew motility which can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. 

Treponema can be stained by silver impregnation methods. 

  • Fontana's method is used on smear
  • Levaditi's method is used for tissue sections

The clinical manifestations of syphilis include:

Primary syphilis: The typical primary chancre usually begins as a single painless papule that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, with a characteristic cartilaginous consistency on palpation of the edge and base of the ulcer.

Inguinal lymphadenopathy is bilateral and may occur with anal as well as with genital chancres. The chancre generally heals within 4–6 weeks (range, 2–12 weeks), but lymphadenopathy may persist for months.

Secondary syphilis: The various features include mucocutaneous or cutaneous lesions and generalized nontender lymphadenopathy. macular, papular, papulosquamous, and occasionally pustular syphilides. Other features of secondary syphilis include sore throat, fever, weight loss, malaise, anorexia, headache, and meningismus. Ocular findings associated with secondary (or later/ unknown-stage) syphilis include pupillary abnormalities and optic neuritis as well as the classic iritis or uveitis.

Latent syphilis: Early latent syphilis is limited to the first year after infection, whereas late latent syphilis is defined as that of 1 year’s duration (or of unknown duration). T. pallidum may still seed the bloodstream intermittently during the latent stage, and latent syphilis in a pregnant woman may infect the fetus in utero. 

Neurosyphilis:  The major clinical categories of symptomatic neurosyphilis include meningeal, meningovascular, and parenchymatous syphilis.

Cardiovascular syphilis: Cardiovascular involvement results in uncomplicated aortitis, aortic regurgitation, saccular aneurysm (usually of the ascending aorta), or coronary ostial stenosis.

Congenital syphilis: The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or “snuffles”; mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray examination of long bones; hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, anemia, jaundice,  thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.

Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

  1. Screening or diagnosis (RPR or VDRL),
  2. Quantitative measurement of antibody to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy (RPR or VDRL)
  3. Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test (FTA-ABS, TPHA, EIA/CIA)

Treatment of syphilis is with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident. After initial stabilisation, a CT scan of the head and neck was ordered and is shown below. Which of the following statements is true about the force causing this fracture?
questions.solution:
The CT image shows fracture of pars interarticularis of axis (C2), also known as Hangman's fracture. It usually occurs due to distraction and extension force. A common mechanism is head-on motor vehicle collisions. This causes hyperextension of the spine due to abrupt deceleration.

It is also known as traumatic C2 spondylolisthesis.

In most cases, there is no neurological deficit. A Philadelphia collar immobilization can be used to provide a rigid cervical support. 

In the below X-ray of the cervical spine, a Hangman's fracture can be noted.  It can be observed that C2 (red outline) has moved forward with respect to C3 (blue outline).

Other options:

Option B-  Flexion force about an axis to anterior longitudinal ligament causes horizontal avulsion fracture of vertebral bodies. This is termed as a Chance fracture. This occurs mostly in people who wear lap belts without a shoulder harness. So it's also called a seat belt injury. 

Option C- Axial compression with flexion of the cervical spine leads to crushing of the vertebral body in a neutral position. This results in burst fracture as shown below.

Option D- Sudden forceful extension following a rear-end collision causes whiplash injury causing injury to longitudinal ligaments of the spine.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the vertebra

Burst fracture - Vertical compression injury

Chance fracture - horizontal fracture of the vertebral body

Clay-shoveller's fracture - spinous process fracture of C6, C7 or T1

Dens fracture - Odontoid process fracture

Hangman's fracture - fracture of both pedicles of C2

Holdsworth fracture - unstable spinal fracture-dislocation at the thoracolumbar junction

Jefferson's fracture - fracture of first cervical vertebra

Motorcyclist's fracture - transverse fracture across base of the skull

Whiplash's injury - hyperextension followed by flexion 

Undertaker's fracture -Post-mortem fracture of the lower cervical spine with C6-C7 disc disruption

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy who was treated for acute otitis media 2 weeks back presents with fever,  and pain behind his right ear. On examination, tenderness is present over the mastoid and the pinna is pushed anteriorly suggesting acute mastoiditis. A fluctuant swelling is present between the tip of the mastoid and the angle of the jaw. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along is most likely suggestive of the diagnosis of Bezold's abscess.

Bezold abscess is defined as a complication of acute coalescent mastoiditis and is formed when pus breaks inferiorly, through the thin medial aspect of the tip of the mastoid and collects in the upper part of the neck, most commonly into the sheath of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The abscess can also take any of the following locations: 

  • Deep to the sternocleidomastoid
  • Along the posterior belly of the digastric presenting as a swelling in the tip of the mastoid or the angle of the jaw
  • The upper part of the posterior triangle
  • Parapharyngeal space
  • Along with the carotid vessels.


Treatment:

  1. Cortical mastoidectomy for coalescent mastoiditis
  2. Drainage of the abscess in the neck with insertion of a drain through a separate incision
  3. IV antibiotics

Other options:

Option A: Zygomatic abscess forms due to infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the zygoma.  Patients present with swelling in front and above the pinna with associated edema over the upper eyelid. Here the pus collects either superficial or deep to the temporalis muscle.

Option C: Luc abscess is defined as a subperiosteal temporal abscess. It develops following the spread of infection from the middle ear along the external auditory meatus, directly, to the temporal region. Swelling is present in the deep part of the bony meatus. 

Option D: Citelli’s abscess is formed posterior to the mastoid, occupying a position more towards the occipital bone. It is also considered an abscess of the digastric triangle. In any case, a diagnosis of Bezold abscess is more appropriate for this patient owing to the location of the abscess.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old male patient was brought into the emergency room after he collapsed at his residence. Attendants inform that he complained of weakness, chest pain, difficulty in breathing before he collapsed. On examination, the following findings are observed. His ECG revealed inferior wall myocardial infarction and the patient was started on an inotrope. Identify the inotrope of choice and what are the predominant receptors that it acts on?

Blood pressure- 80/64 mmHg

Pulse- 110 bpm, irregular

Respiratory rate -26/min

Urine output- normal

Ejection fraction- 34%
questions.solution:
The inotrope of choice is dobutamine and it acts predominantly by agonist action on beta1 & beta 2 receptors.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute congestive heart failure with systolic dysfunction, reduced ejection fraction & maintained urine output. In cases of acute CHF with systolic dysfunction, dobutamine is the inotrope of choice. 

Beta 1 receptors act mainly on the myocardium increasing the force of contraction, thus having a positive inotropic effect. The vasoconstriction due to alpha 1 agonist action is partly negated by the vasodilation due to beta 2 agonist action. The net effect is that of increased stroke volume(inotropic) with a mild decrease in afterload (vasodilation by beta 2 agonism).

Dobutamine is an exogenic catecholamine. The major dose-reducing side effects of dobutamine include tachycardia and supraventricular arrhythmia. 

Concurrent use of beta-blockers may blunt the response of dobutamine, during the management of patients with acute CHF with systolic dysfunction. Thus a higher dose of dobutamine is given. Beyond 4 days, patients might develop tolerance and phosphodiesterase 3 (PDE3) inhibitors such as milrinone and enoximone may be added.

PDE3 inhibitors are more advantageous in patients on beta-blockers and with high systemic/pulmonary vascular resistance as compared to catecholamines such as dobutamine in the management of acute CHF with systolic dysfunction. PDE3 inhibitors or levosimendan may be preferred over catecholamines in patients already on beta-blockers at presentation.

Other options: 

Option A-  Dopamine in inotrope doses acts by agonist action on beta 2 receptors and is not antagonistic. Dopamine is used as the drug of choice in acute CHF with oliguria and has a dose-dependent action. 

  • At <2mcg/kg/min as a diuretic due to agonist action on D2 receptors.
  • At 2-5mcg/kg/min as an inotrope due to agonist action on beta 1. 
  • At 5-10mcg/kg/min as a potent vasoconstrictor by alpha1 agonist action

Option C- Norepinephrine acts as a potent agonist at alpha 1 & beta 1 receptors, with weak agonism at beta 2 receptors. The positive inotropic effect is due to beta 1 receptors. Peripheral vasoconstriction and increased afterload are due to alpha 1 receptors. Alpha 1 agonist action promotes cardiac ischemia and resistance to cardiac output, hence it is not used as an inotrope. But, due to the same effect, it is used in vasogenic shock in spite of good cardiac output.

Option D-  Epinephrine acts as an agonist at alpha 1, beta 1 & beta 2 receptors. Although the net effect is similar to dobutamine, it is considered the second inotrope of choice in the management of Acute CHF due to the higher tachycardic effect.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in heart failure

Drugs used in acute decompensated heart failure:

Nesiritide Recombinant human BNP

Dobutamine

Dopamine

Epinephrine

Enoximone

Milrinone

Levosimendan

Pimobendan

Drugs used for rapid symptom relief

Bumetanide

Furosemide

Torasemide

Morphine Opioid - to calm the patient and decreases cardiac O2 consumption
 
Drugs used in chronic heart failure:
Drugs Uses

ARBs Used in case of intolerance to ACE inhibitors
Beta-blockers Used as first-line therapy  

Spironolactone

SGLT-2 inhibitors Used as 1st line therapy- reduces mortality and morbidity
Sacubitril/Valsartan Neprilysin inhibitor/ARB(ARNI)
Ivabradine Inhibitor of If current in the sinoatrial node
 

Related Pearl: Summary of Pathogenesis of Major Findings in Congestive Heart Failure

Summary of Pathogenesis of Major Findings in Congestive Heart Failure

Abnormality

Cause

Weakness, exercise intolerance, fatigue

Left ventricle output inadequate to perfuse muscles; especially, failure of output to rise with exercise

Ankle, sacral edema

Increased peripheral venous pressure →increased fluid transudation.

Hepatomegaly

Increased peripheral venous pressure →increased resistance to portal flow.

Pulmonary congestion

Increased pulmonary venous pressure →pulmonary venous distention and transudation of fluid into air spaces

Dyspnea on exertion

Failure of left ventricular output to rise during exercise → increased pulmonary venous pressure

Paroxysmal dyspnea, pulmonary edema

Probably a sudden failure of left heart output to keep up with the right heart output →acute rise in pulmonary venous and capillary pressure →transudation of fluid into air spaces.

Orthopnea

Normal pooling of blood in lungs in supine position added to the already congested pulmonary vascular system; increased venous return not put out by the left ventricle. (Relieved by sitting up, raising the head of the bed, lying on extra pillows.)

Cardiac dilation

Greater ventricular end-diastolic volume.

questions.text:
You are educating a group of young mothers at the village health camp about breastfeeding. Which of the following statements are true regarding the components of breastmilk?
  1. Polyunsaturated fatty acids help in nerve myelination.
  2. Lactoferrin has antimicrobial action.
  3. Breast milk is deficient in vitamin C.
  4. Exclusive breastfeeding causes vitamin D deficiency.
questions.solution:
The true statements are statements 1, 2, and 4.

Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) in breast milk help in nerve myelination. Lactoferrin helps in immunomodulation, iron chelation, and antimicrobial action. Breastmilk is deficient in vitamin D and exclusively breastfed infants can develop vitamin D deficiency unless adequately supplemented. Breast milk is a rich source of vitamin C and is found in higher levels than in cow milk.

PUFA like docosahexenoic acid (DHA) present in breast milk plays an important role in the growth and nervous system development. Human milk contains taurine and cysteine which are required for neural development. The epidermal growth factor present in breast milk helps in intestinal cell maturation and repair. The other components present in breast milk are secretory IgA, transforming growth factor, nerve growth factor, platelet-activating factor, bifidus factor, and glutathione peroxidase. Breastmilk has high water content and infants who are exclusively breastfed need not be supplemented with water during their first few months of life. 

The protein content in breast milk is low compared to animal milk. Whey constitutes 70-80% of breast milk's protein content. The predominant whey protein is α-lactalbumin in human milk and β-globulin in cow milk.  Lactose is found in high concentrations in breastmilk and its component galactose is necessary for the formation of galactocerebrosides. It also promotes the growth of lactobacilli. Breastfed infants are at a lower risk of dying from serious gastrointestinal and respiratory illnesses.

Breast milk is deficient in vitamin K and infants have to be supplemented with the same to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant lady at 32 weeks of gestation presents with vaginal discharge associated with itching and burning. On examination, the following finding is seen. Which of the following can be used in the treatment of this patient?

choices.text: Metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days

questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the image showing curdy white vaginal discharge is suggestive of monilial vaginitis/vaginal candidiasis. A single dose of fluconazole 150 mg can be used in the treatment of this condition.

Local intravaginal application of antifungal agents such as imidazole, miconazole, clotrimazole, butoconazole or ter­conazole vaginal pessaries or creams used for 3–6 days is also very effective. Since the use of fluconazole has been associated with embryotoxicity and increased risk of cardiac malformations, it is recommended to be avoided during the first trimester.

Risk factors for candidal infection include pregnancy, medications such as oral contraceptive pills, steroids, HIV, and diabetes mellitus. Clinical features include itching, curdy-white discharge, burning, and dysuria with vaginal pH <4.5. 

The diagnosis can be confirmed by microscopic examination of the smear of vaginal discharge with 10% KOH solution. The smear shows budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae. Culture can be done on Sabouraud's agar and Nickerson's medium.

Treatment includes control and elimination of risk factors including maintaining personal hygiene, adequate control of diabetes, and stopping contributing medications, in addition to pharmacotherapy as mentioned above. Routine treatment of the partner is not recommended unless the partner is symptomatic.

Other options:

Option A- Metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days is used in the treatment of vaginosis/bacterial vaginitis/nonspecific vaginitis.

Option B- Azithromycin 1 g single dose is used in the treatment of chlamydial infections and chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Option D- Metronidazole 2 g single dose is used in the treatment of vaginosis/bacterial vaginitis/nonspecific vaginitis.

questions.text: A microbiology resident is using the Lowenstein-Jensen medium as a selective medium for the culture of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The presence of which of the following components makes it a selective medium?
questions.solution:
The presence of malachite green makes Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium a selective medium by inhibiting other bacteria. 

Contents of LJ medium:

  1. Egg: Provides fatty acids and protein required for metabolism.
  2. Malachite green: prevents the growth of contaminants.
  3. Mineral salt solution: Acts as a buffer.
  4. Glycerol: Source of carbon, favors the growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. Bovis.
  5. L-asparagine: Source of Nitrogen.  

Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are dry, rough, raised, and irregular with a wrinkled surface. They are creamy white or buff-colored, tenacious, and difficult to emulsify (rough, tough, buff). 

Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

  • Solid culture media: Lowenstein–Jensen (A commonly used, egg-based, selective media).
  • Liquid culture media: Dubos' media, Middle Brook’s media. Virulent strains tend to form long serpentine cords in liquid media, while avirulent strains grow in a more dispersed manner.
  • Automated Culture Media: 
    • BACTEC 460: Uses radioisotopes
    • BacT/ALERT: A colorimetric method
    • BACTEC MGIT: A fluorometric detection method. 

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

questions.text: Which of the following changes will inhibit appetite and control food intake?
questions.solution:
An increase in cholecystokinin will inhibit appetite and control food intake.

Cholecystokinin (CCK) is a short-acting hormone that is released in response to feeding. It stimulates the receptors on sensory nerves in the duodenum. This signals the brain via the vagus and inhibits appetite and decreases food intake to prevent overeating. CCK levels are low during fasting and rise immediately after food intake.

Other gastrointestinal hormones which inhibit appetite are peptide YY and glucagon-like peptide (GLP), leptin.

CCK is secreted by I cells in the mucosa of the upper small intestine. Its functions include:

  • Stimulation of pancreatic enzyme secretion
  • Gallbladder contraction
  • Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi to allow the flow of bile and pancreatic juice into the intestinal lumen
  • Inhibits gastric emptying

Other options:

Option A- Neuropeptide Y is produced from orexigenic neurons of arcuate nuclei. It stimulates appetite.

Option C- Ghrelin is produced by the endocrine cells in the oxyntic glands of the stomach. It stimulates appetite. Ghrelin levels increased during fasting, peaking just before the beginning of food intake.

Option D- Cortisol is an orexigenic hormone that increases appetite.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old African-American woman is at the risk of developing metabolic syndrome and has been suggested to switch to the Mediterranean diet which is rich in monounsaturated fatty acids. Which of the following describes the effect of monounsaturated fatty acids?

HDL - High-density lipoproteins
LDL - Low-density lipoproteins

choices.text: Increase HDL + decrease LDL + decrease plasma triacylglycerol
Decrease HDL+ decrease LDL + decrease total cholesterol
Decrease HDL + decrease LDL + decrease plasma triacylglycerol
Increase  HDL + decrease LDL + decrease total cholesterol

questions.solution:
MUFA (Monounsaturated fatty acids) causes an increase in HDL levels and decreases serum LDL and total cholesterol levels. Plasma triacylglycerols remain unchanged.

The Mediterranean diet is rich in monounsaturated fatty acids (from olive oil) and n-3 fatty acids (from fish oils and some nuts), but low in saturated fatty acids. It contains seasonally fresh food, abundant plant material, low amounts of red meat, and olive oil as the principal source of fat. When substituted for saturated fatty acids in the diet, MUFAs lower both total and LDL cholesterol and increase HDL. This may explain why the Mediterranean diet, is associated with decreased serum total and LDL cholesterol compared with a typical Western diet high in saturated fats.

Unsaturated fatty acids contain one or more double bonds. These are classified into monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA) and polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA). Unsaturated fatty acids lower blood cholesterol levels by the upregulation of LDL receptors on the cell surface, causing an increase in the catabolism of LDL. Omega-3 (ω3) fatty acids also have an anti-inflammatory effect and decrease triacylglycerol levels.

Monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA) contain a single double bond, Ex:

  • Palmitoleic acid (ω7)
  • Oleic acid (ω9)
  • Elaidic acid (ω9)

Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) are divided into two types based on the position of double bonds (when counted from the methyl end of the fatty acid molecule)

  • ω-3 fatty acids: The first double bond is at the third carbon atom
  • ω-6 fatty acids: The first double bond is at the sixth carbon atom

PUFA lowers plasma cholesterol and LDLs, but HDLs, which protect against coronary heart disease, are also lowered. 

Related Pearl: Unsaturated Fatty acids

questions.text: A sample of water is being tested to assess whether it is suitable for drinking. The detection of which organism provides definitive proof of faecal contamination?
questions.solution:
The detection of Escherichia coli provides definitive proof of fecal contamination.

The presence of fecal pollution in a water sample suggests that the source may be contaminated with enteric pathogens. Two tests are done in succession to identify the presence of E.coli which provides definite proof of fecal pollution. They are

  • Presumptive coliform count
  • Differential coliform count/ Eijkman test

Presumptive coliform count - The basis of the presumptive coliform test is the inoculation of the water to be tested into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium. These are then incubated and examined after the appropriate period of time. The test is called presumptive because the acid and gas formation observed in the tube may occasionally be due to the presence of some other organism and it has to be confirmed. 

Differential coliform count/ Eijkman test - Following the presumptive test, subcultures are made from all the bottles showing acid and gas to fresh tubes of single-strength Mac Conkey medium pre-warmed to 37°C. These tubes are incubated at 44°C and examined after 24 hours. If Escherichia coli is detected, it is definitive proof of fecal contamination.

Interpretation:

  • The Durham's tubes with the presence of gas are deemed to contain E.Coli.
  • This can be further confirmed by testing for indole production and citrate utilization.

Other options:

Option A- Recent fecal contamination of water is suggested by the presence of enterococcus (fecal streptococci). Fecal streptococci are found in feces in smaller numbers than E.coli. Streptococci are useful for routine control testing after laying new pipelines or repairs in distribution systems and to detect groundwater contamination.

Option C- Clostridium perfringens also occur regularly in feces but in much smaller numbers than E.coli. The spores are capable of surviving in water for a long time, and they usually resist chlorination. The presence of spores of Clostridium perfringens in natural water suggests that fecal contamination has occurred. But in the absence of the coliform group, it suggests that fecal contamination is a long time ago. They can also be used to assess filtration systems.

Option D- Bacteroides species are present in feces but do not play a significant role in testing and sampling for fecal pollution of water.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding atrial myxomas?

choices.text: Stellate or globular cells can be seen
More commonly seen  in the right atrium
Most common primary tumor of the adult heart
Most common site of origin is fossa ovalis in the atrial septum

questions.solution:
Myxomas are the most common primary tumor of the heart in adults and atrial myxoma is most commonly located in the left atrium.

Myxomas are benign neoplasms that arise from primitive multipotent mesenchymal cells. 90 percent of myxoma are located in the atria, sporadic, and are usually single. The left-to-right ratio of the myxoma is approximately 4:1. The most common site of origin is fossa ovalis in the atrial septum. 

They mainly present with symptoms that mimic mitral valve disease. A characteristic low pitched sound, a "tumor plop", is heard on auscultation during early or mid diastole as a result of the impact from the tumor against the mitral valve or ventricular wall.

They also present with constitutional symptoms like fever, cachexia, and malaise due to the elevation of cytokines like interleukin 6. 

Myxomas are composed of stellate or globular myxoma cells embedded within an acid mucopolysaccharide ground substance. Peculiar vessel-like or gland-like structures are characteristically seen along with hemorrhage and mononuclear inflammation.

The image below shows an abundant amorphous extracellular matrix containing scattered multinucleate myxoma cells in various groupings, including abnormal vessel-like formations.

Mobile tumors exert a “wrecking-ball” effect, causing damage to the valve leaflets.

Myoma can be sessile or pedunculated lesions. They appear as a globular hard mass mottled with hemorrhage arising from the fossa ovalis as shown below.

Transesophageal/ Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is the diagnostic investigation.

The below image of TTE shows a mass in the left atrium suggestive of atrial myxoma.

Surgical excision is done regardless of the tumor size.

questions.text: A primigravida underwent quadruple testing at 16 weeks of gestation. On further evaluation, her fetus was found to have trisomy 18. Which of the following parameters are likely to be reduced?
questions.solution:
Parameters including maternal serum alfa-fetoprotein (MSAFP), beta hCG, and unconjugated estriol levels are significantly reduced in trisomy 18/ Edwards syndrome.

Inhibin A levels are also modestly reduced in Trisomy 18.

Quadruple testing is usually done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. The 4 parameters that are measured are maternal serum alfa-fetoprotein (MSAFP), beta hCG, unconjugated estriol, and inhibin A. In trisomy 21, trisomy 18, and neural tube defects, the changes in the screening markers are as follows:

Parameter Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect 
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal

Various antenatal screening tests for aneuploidy are as follows:

Dual test (1st trimester) Triple test (2nd trimester) Quadruple test
(2nd trimester)

1. Beta HCG 

2. PAPPA (Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A)

This can be combined with nuchal translucency by USG

1. Beta HCG 

2. Unconjugated estriol 

3. MSAFP  

1. Beta HCG 

2. Unconjugated estriol 

3. MSAFP 

4. Serum inhibin

questions.text: Passive immunisation is not used in the prevention of disease caused by which of following viruses ?
questions.solution:
Passive immunization is not given in cytomegalovirus (CMV) exposure. At present, there is no role for post-exposure prophylaxis with antivirals or immune globulin. The only method of preventing maternal CMV infection is by limiting exposure to the virus by maintaining good hand hygiene.

Passive immunization is a short-term measure useful only when exposure to infection has just occurred or is likely to occur within the next few days. The duration of immunity is short and variable (1-6 weeks).

There are three types of preparations available for passive immunization -

  • Normal human immunoglobulin,
  • Specific (hyperimmune) human immunoglobulin
  • Antisera or anti-toxins.

Passive immunization has a limited value in the mass control of the disease. It is recommended for non-immune persons under special circumstances. Undesirable reactions may occur, especially with antisera of non-human origin. 

Passive immunization using immunoglobulins is done for the following diseases:

  • Hepatitis A
  • Hepatitis B
  • Hepatitis C
  • Rubella
  • Varicella-zoster
  • Measles (rubeola)
  • Rabies
  • Tetanus
  • Rh isoimmunization.

Passive immunization using antisera/ antitoxin is done for the following diseases:

  • Diphtheria
  • Tetanus
  • Gas gangrene
  • Rabies
  • Botulism

Other options:

Option A- Varicella-zoster immune globulin (VZIG) is used in immune-suppressed contacts of acute cases or newborn contacts for pst-exposure prophylaxis.

Option B- Immune globulin (IG) is used in women exposed to the rubella virus during pregnancy.

Option D- The immune globulin for measles is used in infants less than 1-year-old or immune-suppressed contacts of acute cases, exposed less than 6 days previously.

questions.text: For effective protection against pregnancy after unprotected intercourse, what is the correct method of taking centchroman?

choices.text: One 30mg tablet taken once within 24 hours
One 30mg tablet taken twice at an interval of 12 hours
Two 30mg tablets taken twice at an interval of 12 hours
Two 30mg tablets taken once within 24 hours

questions.solution:
For emergency contraception, the dosage of centchroman tablets to be taken is 2 tablets each of 30mg (total of 60mg) taken twice at an interval of 12 hours, within 24 hours after unprotected intercourse:

  • 1st dose- 2 tablets of 30 mg each
  • 2nd dose (After 12 hours of the first dose)- 2 tablets of 30 mg each

Centchroman (Ormeloxifene) is the first non-steroidal oral contraceptive pill to be manufactured in the world. It was released in India under the brand name- Saheli. The Govt. of India has included Centchroman in the National Family Planning initiative for its distribution to women free of cost under the brand name Chhaya. 

It offers a combination of weak estrogenic and potent antiestrogenic properties. It is the only contraceptive that neither suppresses ovulation nor interferes with the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis.

Centchroman can be taken as a regular oral contraceptive pill. The schedule is as follows:

  • First 3 months: One tablet (30mg) has to be taken twice weekly
  • After 3 months: One tablet (30mg) once weekly

It inhibits the implantation of the fertilized ovum and thus prevents pregnancy, but at the same time, it does not appear to disturb the other estrogen effects. Fertility returns about 6 months after stopping centchroman.

Apart from contraception, Centchroman is also used in the management of dysfunctional uterine bleeding, mastalgia, and fibroadenoma and has promising therapeutic efficacy in a variety of cancers including breast cancer.

The side effects of using Centchroman include headache, nausea, weight gain, and endometrial hyperplasia in case of prolonged usage.

The contraindications of using Centchroman are 6 months of lactation, polycystic ovarian disease, hepatic dysfunction, and cervical dysplasia.

Other emergency contraceptives include: 

Drug Dose
Levonorgestrel 0.75mg stat and after 12 hours
Etinyl estradiol 50μg + Norgestrel 0.25 mg 2 tab stat and 2 tab after 12 hours
Conjugated estrogen 15mg BD x 5 days
Ethinyl Estradiol 2.5mg BD X 5 days
Copper IUD's

Insertion within 5-7 days after accidental unprotected exposure.

 
Ulipristal 

30mg tablet within 5 days

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male chronic smoker presents with intermittent claudication pain of the legs for a few months. On examination, a gangrenous ulcer was present in the right big toe. Angiography revealed skip lesions in the right lower limb. Which of the following is the best treatment modality in this case?

Blood glucose and lipid profile within normal limits.
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of Buerger's disease or thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO). The best treatment in the above case is amputation.

A young male smoker, presenting with claudication pain, with no history of diabetes and hyperlipidemia and ulcer along with angiography showing skip lesions, are points in favor of Buerger's disease.

The treatment in the given scenario is amputation. Bypass graft will not be successful due to multiple arterial occlusions. Absolute tobacco cessation can cause clinical remission but cannot reverse the present condition (gangrenous ulcer). No effective pharmacological treatment is available.

Buerger's disease is a nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder involving small and medium-sized arteries of the upper and lower limb.

It is predominantly seen in young male smokers. Patients mainly present with claudication pain of extremities and later with ischemic rest pain and ulcers. Atherogenic conditions like diabetes and dyslipidemia should be excluded.

They may also present with pain, paresthesia, and color changes of the digits of the hand and feet in response to cold and anxiety. This is called as Raynaud phenomenon. 

The image below shows the Raynaud phenomenon in the digits of the hand.

The following criteria must be met for the diagnosis of TAO:

  • Age younger than 45 years
  • History of tobacco use
  • Distal extremity ischemia like claudication pain or ulcer
  • Autoimmune diseases, hypercoagulable state, dyslipidemia, and diabetes mellitus must be excluded
  • Consistent arteriographic findings in the limbs
  • A proximal source of atheroemboli must be excluded

Angiography shows segmental occlusions as skip lesions of the small and medium-sized vessels with the formation of extensive collaterals around the occlusions. These are called corkscrew collaterals. These represent dilated vasa vasoram of the occluded vessels.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman came with complaints of progressive hearing loss and tinnitus for a few weeks.  Pure tone audiometry was done as shown below. Which of the following phenomenon is seen in the above patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of pregnant women presenting with progressive hearing loss, tinnitus, and pure tone audiometry showing Carhart's notch is suggestive of Otosclerosis. Paracusis willisii is seen in patients with stapedial otosclerosis.

An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. The louder voice is better transmitted through the fixed stapes. This phenomenon is known as Paracusis willisii.

Otosclerosis is caused by bony overgrowth involving the enchondral layer of the otic capsule. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It Is known to worsen during stress & hormonal variations like during pregnancy and menopause.

The types of otosclerosis and the sites involved are:

Type Site
Stapedial otosclerosis Near oval window
(fissula ante fenestram)
Cochlear otosclerosis Round window
Histologic otosclerosis  asymptomatic

In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane is usually normal unless there is another co-existing pathology. Sometimes, a reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. Tuning fork tests show negative Rinne.

Tympanometry shows an ossicular stiffness type of curve. Pure tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the bone conduction curve at 2000 Hz known as Carhart's notch as shown below.

 

Surgical management includes stapedectomy and stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis.

The types of stapedial otosclerosis are:

  • Anterior focus
  • Posterior focus
  • Circumferential
  • Biscuit type (thick plate)
  • Obliterative

 

Option B - Tullio phenomenon is seen in Meniere's disease. In this phenomenon, loud sounds or noise produce vertigo. This is due to the distended saccule lying against the footplate of the stapes.

Option C - Recruitment is seen in diseases of the cochlea such as Meniere's disease and presbycusis, in which there is reduced tolerance to loudness. 

Option D - Roll-over phenomenon is seen in patients with acoustic neuroma. It is the reduction of discrimination score when the loudness is increased beyond a particular level. This reduction is disproportionate to the pure tone hearing loss

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: A 20-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after he suffered a stab wound in the anterior chest wall. CT-scan revealed arterial extravasation from injury to the internal thoracic artery. The condition causes a decrease in blood supply through all of the following blood vessels, except:
questions.solution:
Posterior intercostal arteries are not branches of the internal thoracic artery, hence there would be no decrease in blood supply through these arteries. 

Branches of the internal thoracic artery:

  • Terminal branches at the level of the 6th intercostal space:
    • Superior epigastric artery
    • Musculophrenic artery
  • Sternal branches to:
    • Transversus thoracis muscle
    • Periosteum of the posterior sternal surface
    • Sternal red bone marrow
  • Anterior intercostal arteries for the first 6 intercostal spaces.
  • Perforating branches that pierce and supply pectoralis major and then become direct cutaneous vessels that supply the skin.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is being evaluated for intellectual disability. On examination, the child had large ears, a long, prominent square jaw, and enlarged testes. Genetic analysis reveals trinucleotide repeats. Which of the following is not true about this particular syndrome?

choices.text: It is caused due to mutations in the FMR1 gene
The nucleotide repeats involve the CGG sequence
The larger the triplet repeat expansion, the lesser the intellectual disability
Females can also be affected by this syndrome.

questions.solution:
The patient’s clinical features are strongly suggestive of Fragile X syndrome. The larger the triplet repeat expansion in fragile X syndrome, the more significant the intellectual disability.

It is caused due to trinucleotide repeat expansion (CGG) of DNA in the long arm of chromosome X involving the FMR1 gene. The main clinical features in affected males include intellectual disability, autistic features,post-pubertal macroorchidism, and characteristic facial features including large ears, a long face, and a  square jaw. Affected females also show varying degrees of intellectual disability. 

Diagnosis is made by DNA testing which shows more than 200 trinucleotide (CGG) repeats. Premutation repeats(55-200 repeats) are associated with fragile X–associated tremor/ataxia syndrome, and premature ovarian failure. Unaffected individuals show fewer than 50 trinucleotide repeats.

The image shown below is of a boy who was diagnosed with Fragile X syndrome. Note the large ears, long face, and prominent square jaw.

questions.text: Magnesium sulphate has no role in:

choices.text: Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia
Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia
Prevention of RDS in premature baby

questions.solution:
Magnesium sulfate has no role in the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in a premature baby, where there is a deficit of surfactant (which results in alveolar collapse).

Magnesium in the MgSO4 competes with calcium on voltage-gated calcium channels, thereby altering its uptake and release. Functions of MgSO4 include :

  • Membrane protector and neuro stabilizer. It is used in the prevention of cerebral palsy in very low birth weight neonates.
  • Reduction of motor endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine, and thus is used as an adjunct in the management of acute severe asthma in children and adults
  • Blocking of neuronal calcium influx, and is thus used in the conservative management of pre-term labor (tocolytic, option D)
  • Inducing cerebral vasodilatation, dilating the uterine arteries, increasing the production of endothelial prostacyclin, and inhibiting platelet activation. Hence it is used in the management of pre-eclampsia (option A) and to prevent progression to eclampsia (option A).

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy  working in a factory was brought to the outpatient department after being injured. Which article in the constitution prohibits this?
questions.solution:
Article 24 prohibits the employment of children below the age of 14 in factories.

Article 24 states the right to be protected from hazardous employment till the age of 14 years.

Other options :

Option A- Article 21 A states the right to free and compulsory elemental education in the 6 -14 year age group.

Option B- Article 39 (e) states the right to be protected children from being abused and forced by financial necessity to enter any occupations not suited for their age and strength.  

Option C- Article 45 states the right to early childhood care and education for all children until they complete the age of 6 years.

questions.text: A patient who underwent a renal transplant 3 months ago came with complaints of diarrhea for the last 9 days. The stool sample subjected to Kinyoun staining is shown below. Which of the following is true about the causative organism?

choices.text: It requires two hosts for completion of its life cycle
Metronidazole is the drug of choice

questions.solution:
Diarrhea in a post-transplant patient with Kinyoun stain-positive oocysts of size 6 µm is suggestive of cryptosporidiosis. It shows autoinfection. 

Cryptosporidium is a coccidian parasite. It causes chronic diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. The two cryptosporidium species responsible are C. hominis and C. parvum. They complete their life cycle in one host i.e. they are monoxenous (option B). The infective form is the oocyst which is spherical, 4-6µm in size, acid-fast and contains 4 sporozoites. The oocysts are immediately infectious (unlike isospora oocysts, which require maturation), and may cause autoinfection or person-to-person transmission.

The sporulated oocysts are excreted in feces (option A) and can be acquired through drinking contaminated water or recreational water activities. Once ingested, 4 sporozoites are released from the cyst and attach to the small intestinal mucosa. Patients present with crampy abdominal pain and non-inflammatory watery diarrhea. Treatment is mainly supportive (option D), though nitazoxanide has been FDA-approved for use.

Comparative features of coccidian parasites:

Property  Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Cystoisospora

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient comes to the clinic to follow up on managing her obesity. Her body mass index (BMI) is 41. She has increased her physical activity for the last few months and has reduced her caloric intake. She is still unable to lose weight. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Increase intensity of physical exercise regimen

questions.solution:
The best next step in the management of this patient is a referral for bariatric surgery because she has a body mass index-BMI of 41 kg/m2 and has failed to lose weight with conservative methods.

Bariatric surgery should be considered in patients with

  • severe obesity - BMI ≥40, or
  • moderate obesity - BMI ≥35 with severe obesity-related medical conditions 

Bariatric surgery can be classified into restrictive, restrictive-malabsorptive, and malabsorptive. These affect eating behaviors, reduction of appetite, satiety, energy intake, and possibly physical activity.

Surgeries like laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding (LAGB) and laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy restrict the capacity of the stomach and slow emptying.

Surgeries such as roux-en-y gastric bypass, biliopancreatic diversion (BPD), and BPD with a duodenal switch combine the features of restrictive and malabsorptive surgeries, which reduce the surface area and subsequently reduce the absorption of nutrients. 

Bariatric surgery can produce an average of 30-35% weight loss that is maintained up to 5 years after the surgery. It is also successful in reducing comorbid conditions related to obesity like type 2 diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, and hypertension. 

Other options:

Increasing the intensity of the physical exercise regimens (Option A) and increasing caloric deficit (Option D) can be attempted in those with mild to moderate obesity. This patient has already attempted diet and exercise, and it has not been effective. 

Option C - Starting anti-obesity medications should be considered in patients with a BMI of ≥30 or those with a BMI of ≥27 with obesity-related diseases. This patient has better chances of weight loss with surgery than medical therapy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presented with sudden onset headache with 10/10 intensity. She does not have any vision disturbances, photophobia, or watering eyes. A non-contrast CT of the head was performed and found to be normal. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) as she has a sudden onset, intense headache of 10/10 intensity without any visual disturbances, photophobia, or watering eyes. Patients usually describe these headaches as ‘the worst headache they’ve had in their entire life.’ The best next step in management is to perform a lumbar puncture.

Most cases of SAH are usually diagnosed with a non-contrast head CT. However, if high suspicion for SAH remains after an initial negative non-contrast head CT, then a lumbar puncture should be performed. Visual inspection of the CSF will reveal xanthochromia. However, this can only be seen 6-12 hours after the onset of SAH. However, lumbar puncture should only be performed as first-line testing if CT facilities are unavailable. 

If the SAH is due to a ruptured aneurysm, the patient must undergo a 4-vessel x-ray angiography (both carotids and both vertebral arteries) to localize the aneurysm and identify other potential unruptured aneurysms. Alternatively, CT angiography can be performed. Definitive treatment includes endovascular coiling or aneurysmal clipping. 

Other options: 

Option A - A repeat non-contrast head CT is unlikely to reveal new information and will just subject the patient to unnecessary radiation also CT scan is more sensitive in the initial hours for SAH.

Option C - 100% oxygen inhalation is used to treat cluster headaches. This patient is unlikely to have a cluster headache as it is not an episodic retro-orbital headache. Cluster headache is usually associated with conjunctival injection or excessive lacrimation.

Option D- Sumatriptan is a selective 5HT 1B/1D receptor agonist that can be used in combination to treat acute migraine headaches. This patient is unlikely to have a migraine as she does not have any of the accompanying symptoms (aura) of visual disturbances or photophobia and 10/10 intensity is more characteritsic of SAH

questions.text: Identify the muscle marked by the red arrow and its nerve supply.

choices.text: Mylohyoid; posterior division of mandibular nerve
Medial pterygoid; trunk of mandibular nerve
Lateral pterygoid; anterior division of mandibular nerve
Masseter; anterior division of mandibular nerve

questions.solution:
The marked muscle is the medial pterygoid muscle. It is innervated by the trunk of the mandibular nerve, which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve.

The medial pterygoid is a part of muscles of mastication. The muscle is identified by the lingual nerve, which runs on the surface of the medial pterygoid. The motor innervation for the muscles of mastication arises from the special visceral efferent column in the pons. 

The mandibular nerve is the largest branch of the trigeminal nerve and is a mixed nerve. It gives sensory innervation to the teeth and gums of the mandible, skin in the temporal region, part of the auricle, lower lip, the lower part of the face, anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and the oral cavity. The motor innervation is given to the muscles of mastication, tensor veli palatini, tensor tympani, mylohyoid and anterior belly of digastric.

The mandibular nerve, after supplying the medial pterygoid, divides into anterior and posterior divisions. 

Muscles of mastication

Medial pterygoid:

It has two heads. The deep head arises from the medial surface of the lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone. It is inserted into the posteroinferior part of the medial surface of the ramus and the angle of the mandible.

Its main actions are elevation of the mandible/ closing of the mouth, jaw protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the trunk of the mandibular nerve.

 

Lateral pterygoid:

It has two heads. The upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and the infratemporal crest of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule, and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint.

Its main actions are depression of the mandible/ opening of the mouth, jaw protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

 

Temporalis:

It arises from the temporal fossa up to the inferior temporal line and temporal fascia. It is inserted into the coronoid process and the anterior border of the mandibular ramus. It causes elevation of mandible/ closing of the mouth, jaw retraction, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

 

Masseter:

It arises from the zygomatic arch and from a thick aponeurosis from the maxillary process of the zygomatic bone. It is inserted into the angle and lower posterior half of the lateral surface of the mandibular ramus. Its main actions are elevation of the mandible/ closing of the mouth and jaw protrusion. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is an alkylating agent?
questions.solution:
Among the anti-neoplastic drugs mentioned above, busulfan is an alkyl sulfonate that is classified as an alkylating agent. 

Alkylating agents: Alkylation of reactive amines, oxygens, or phosphates on DNA is the principal mechanism of the chemotherapeutic effect. They consist of 6 major classes of drugs:

  1. Nitrogen mustards
  2. Ethyleneimines
  3. Alkyl sulfonates
  4. Nitrosoureas
  5. Triazenes
  6. Methylhydrazine

These drugs have the common property of forming highly reactive carbonium ion intermediates that covalently link to sites of high electron density.

The N7 atom of guanine is particularly susceptible to the formation of a covalent bond with bifunctional alkylating agents. Cytotoxic effects are predominantly seen in bifunctional alkylating agents such as nitrogen mustards. Monofunctional methylating agents like procarbazine and temozolomide have a greater capacity for mutagenesis and carcinogenesis.

Busulfan is an alkyl sulfonate that was used as the primary agent in the treatment of the chronic phase of myelocytic leukemia. It has now been largely replaced by imatinib mesylate.

Important side effects of high doses of busulfan are:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Hepatic Veno-occlusive disease.
  • Seizures
  • Thrombocytopenia 
  • GI side effects.

Concurrent therapy with anticonvulsants such as lorazepam or clonazepam is recommended to protect against seizures associated with high-dose busulfan therapy.

Other options:

Option A - Topotecan is a camptothecin analogue that acts by inhibiting the topoisomerase I enzyme.

Option B - Capecitabine is a pyrimidine analogue that is classified as an antimetabolite agent.

Option C - Cladirabine is a purine analogue that is classified as an antimetabolite agent.

questions.text: A young man presented with chronic cough and evening rise in body temperature. He has a history of decreased appetite and weight loss. On examination, a mass is found in the right iliac fossa. A barium meal follow-through image of the patient is given below. Which of the following radiological findings is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the barium meal follow-through study showing conical caecum, narrowing of the terminal ileum, and proximal ileal dilation are suggestive of ileocaecal tuberculosis. The radiological finding not seen in ileocecal tuberculosis is the apple-core sign. Apple-core or napkin-ring sign is typically seen in carcinoma colon as seen in the image below. It appears as short irregular stenosis with sharp shoulders at either end (yellow arrows).

 

Intestinal tuberculosis is an infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients typically present with cough, evening rise in temperature, weight loss, malaise, abdominal pain with distension, and intermittent diarrhea. On palpation, the abdomen feels doughy and a mass may be palpated in the right iliac fossa. The ileocaecal junction is the most common site of tuberculosis in the gastrointestinal tract. Other sites involved in the abdomen are the proximal colon and peritoneum.

Barium meal follow-through study findings in ileocaecal tuberculosis include:

  • Fleischner sign- narrow ileum with the thickened ileocecal valve
  • The ileocaecal angle becomes obtuse
  • Caecum appears pulled up and hepatic flexure is pulled down
  • Contracted conical caecum
  • Gooseneck deformity - due to contracted, and pulled-up cecum as well as straightening of the terminal ileum
  • String sign - due to persistently narrowed intestinal segment due to inflammation

The image below shows the findings seen in ileocaecal tuberculosis:

  • Yellow arrow- shrunken conical caecum
  • Red arrow- strictures narrowing of the terminal ileum and ileocaecal junction
  • Blue arrow- proximal ileal dilation

Related Pearl: Barium studies in GI tuberculosis

  • Earliest feature is spasm and hypermotility, with edema of the valve.
  • Thickening of the valve lips, with narrowing of the terminal ileum: Fleischner or inverted umbrella sign is characteristic of TB.
  • In advance disease, the characteristic deformity includes symmetric, annular, napkin-ring stenosis and obstruction or shortening and pouch formation.
  • The cecum is shrunken and retracts out of the iliac fossa due to contraction of the mesocolon: Pulled-up cecum
  • Loss of ileocecal angle with dilated terminal ileum: Gooseneck deformity
  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum due to irritability, along with shortened rigid cecum: Sterlein sign
  • Persistent narrow stream of barium in the bowel indicates stenosis: String sign

questions.text: An infant was brought to the pediatrics department with poor sucking and difficulty in taking feed. He also had severe foul smelling greasy loose stools. A peripheral smear showed acanthocytosis. A biopsy specimen of the small intestine is shown below. Identify the underlying condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of an infant presenting with failure to thrive, steatorrhea, acanthocytosis in the peripheral smear, and a histopathological image showing lipid-laden vacuolated epithelium is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia.

Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare autosomal recessive disease. It is caused due to the mutation in microsomal triglyceride transfer protein which leads to the inability to assemble triglyceride-rich lipoproteins. Thus lipids get accumulate intracellularly. It is predominantly seen in children during their first year of life. They present with failure to thrive and steatorrhea.

Deep tendon reflexes are absent due to peripheral neuropathy and peripheral smear shows acanthocytosis due to lipid membrane defects, which is secondary to marked vitamin E deficiency.

Histopathology shows normal intestinal mucosa except lipid-laden vacuolated epithelium due to triglyceride accumulation. Accumulated lipids disappear after infants stop taking feed.

Low fat, high caloric, vitamin-enriched diet, and vitamin E in large doses should be given. Inadequate supply of vitamin E results in neurological degeneration and the development of retinitis pigmentosa.

 

Diarrhea is defined as an increase in stool mass, frequency, or fluidity, typically greater than 200 gm per day. It can be classified into 4 types:

  • Secretory diarrhea is an isotonic stool and persists during fasting.
  • Osmotic diarrhea is due to the osmotic force exerted by unabsorbed luminal solutes. The diarrheal fluid is greater than 50 mOsm. Diarrhea decreases on fasting.
  • Malabsorptive diarrhea is due to failure of nutrient absorption. It is associated with steatorrhea and it gets relived on fasting.
  • Exudative diarrhea is due to inflammatory diseases which has pus and blood on them, it continues during fasting.

Other options:

Option A- Lactase deficiency is due to the absence of lactase in the villous epithelial cells. Lactose remains in the intestinal lumen and exerts an osmotic force causing osmotic diarrhea. Since the defect is biochemical, histology appears normal.

Option C- Celiac disease is an immune-mediated disorder triggered by gluten-containing foods. Histology shows villous atrophy intraepithelial lymphocytosis and crypt hyperplasia. Plasma cells, mast cells, and eosinophils are seen in lamina propria.

Histopathology image of celiac disease is shown below:

 

Option D- Whipple's disease is a malabsorptive syndrome. Histology shows foamy macrophages in the small intestinal propria. The macrophages are laden with gram-positive, periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) positive, diastase resistant granules that have partially digested Tropheryma whipplei within the lysosome.

Related Pearl: Investigations in Malabsorption Syndrome

The following are the general tests for malabsorption:

Disorder Investigation
Fat malabsorption

Quantitative: 24h fecal fat >7g

Qualitative: Sudan III staining

C14 Triolein breath test

Fecal steatocrit
Carbohydrate malabsorption

D-xylose test

Lactose hydrogen breath test
Protein malabsorption C13 egg-white breath test

The following are the specific tests for malabsorption:

Disorder Investigation
Celiac disease

Anti-endomysial antibodies

Mucosal biopsy showing villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, lamina propria infiltrates, and normal mucosal thickness.

questions.text: A mother brings her 7-year-old daughter to the outpatient department with concerns about early breast development in the child. All of the following conditions could have caused precocious puberty in this child, except ________.
questions.solution:
All of the listed options present with precocious puberty, except Prader-Willi syndrome, which presents with delayed puberty.

Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by the deletion of a part of the paternal chromosome 15. The clinical features include neonatal hypotonia, childhood obesity, growth failure, dysmorphic facial features, delayed puberty, and behavioral problems.

Precocious puberty is defined by the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years in females and 9 years in males. Precocious puberty with secondary sexual characteristics of the patient's own gender is termed isosexual, and that with secondary sexual characteristics of the opposite gender (such as virilization in girls) is termed contrasexual.

Isosexual precocious puberty can be categorized as follows:

  • Complete - This occurs due to the premature activation of the intact hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. The causes of complete isosexual precocious puberty, which is GNRH-dependent include the following:
    • Idiopathic true precocious puberty
    • Central nervous system disorders such as hypothalamic hamartomas, encephalitis, and brain abscess
  • Incomplete - This includes premature thelarche and premature adrenarche. The causes of incomplete isosexual precocious puberty are as follows:
    • GnRH-secreting tumors
    • Increased androgen secretion by adrenal or testis such as in congenital adrenal hyperplasia
    • Ovarian cysts and estrogen-secreting ovarian or adrenal neoplasms
    • McCune-Albright syndrome

Contrasexual precocial puberty can be seen in both males and females:

  • Feminization in males due to conditions such as adrenal neoplasms and chorioepithelioma
  • Virilization in females due to conditions such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia, virilizing adrenal neoplasms, and iatrogenic exposure to androgens

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man has been on a poor unhealthy diet for the past 6 months. Which of these findings will be most likely seen with low calcium levels in his blood?

Ca- Calcium

choices.text: Decreased Ca- binding protein in intestinal epithelium

questions.solution:
The most likely finding seen with low calcium levels is an increase in 1,25- dihydroxy cholecalciferol.

1,25-dihydroxy cholecalciferol is inversely affected by calcium levels. Hypocalcemia is a potent stimulation for parathyroid (PTH) secretion. PTH promotes the conversion of 25- hydroxycholecalciferol to 1, 25 dihydroxy cholecalciferol in the kidneys.

This increase in 1,25 dihydroxy cholecalciferol functions as a hormone to promote intestinal absorption of calcium by increasing calbindin, a calcium-binding protein in the intestinal epithelium. 

PTH maintains the extracellular calcium and phosphate by regulating intestinal reabsorption, renal excretion, and osseous metabolism.

A slight decrease in calcium ion concentration in the extracellular fluid stimulates the parathyroid gland to secrete parathyroid hormones in minutes. And if the condition persists, the glands will become hypertrophied causing hyperparathryroidism.

Other options:

Option B- 24, 25-dihydroxy cholecalciferol is an inactive metabolite with no vitamin D effect. It increases only when the body has a high calcium concentration.  

Option C- Calcitonin decreases the plasma concentration of calcium ions. Its secretion is stimulated as a response to increased calcium ion concentration, hence low calcium levels due to a poor diet would not result in increased calcitonin levels.

Option D- A decrease in calcium-binding protein in intestinal epithelium aggravates hypocalcemia. In fact, this protein level would actually increase, to promote intestinal calcium absorption.
