questions.text: A 21-year-old patient presents with loss of pain and temperature sensation in both upper limbs. An MRI is done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the image showing a hyperintense area in the spinal cord is syringomyelia. 

Syringomyelia is a progressive disease of the spinal cord in which there is an enlarging cavity in the cord. Syrinx cavities are acquired cavities of the cord in necrosed areas secondary to trauma, myelitis, and spinal cord tumors. It usually presents in adolescence or early adulthood with central cord symptoms. 

Most patients present with regional loss of pain and temperature of the upper limbs. Touch and vibration senses are intact. The loss of sensation has a 'cape distribution' as it affects the nape of the neck, shoulders, and upper arms. Eventually, expansion of the cavity may lead to compression of the long tracts. This results in spasticity, weakness, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and Horner's syndrome. 

There is no satisfactory treatment for this condition. 

Other options: 

Option A: Spinal epidural abscess presents with fever, pain, and progressive weakness. The pain may be radicular. There would be elevated white cell count and inflammatory markers. The image below shows a spinal epidural abscess compressing the spinal cord. 

 

Option B: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. Patients present with paresthesias in the hands and feet and progressive ataxic weakness. They would be areflexic due to peripheral neuropathy. The image below shows a hyperintensity in the posterior part of the spinal cord due to the involvement of the posterior columns. 

 

Option D: Spinal cord infarction occurs due to infarction of one of the three arteries (anterior spinal artery and two posterior spinal arteries.) Infarction of the anterior spinal artery leads to quadriplegia or paraplegia, loss of pain and temperature, and sparing of vibration and position sense. Posterior spinal artery involvement leads to a loss of posterior column functions. 

Related Pearl: Extent of important structures/spaces in the Spinal cord

Structure / Space  Terminal extent 
Spinal cord at birth  L3 upper border 
Spinal cord at 2 years  L1 lower border 
Adult Spinal cord  L1 lower border  
Filum terminale  1st coccygeal segment 
Filum terminale internum , Dural sac S2 lower border 
Filum terminale externum  1st coccygeal segment 
Piamater  1st coccygeal segment 
Subarachnoid sheath and space, Subdural space  S2 lower border 
Cervical enlargement  C3-T2 spinal segments 
Lumbar enlargement  L1-S3 spinal segments

questions.text: All of the following changes in the patient's behavior suggest an increased risk of suicide, except ______.

choices.text: Patient recovering from a suicidal depression
Patient with a history of multiple suicidal attempts
Sudden peace of mind in patient with depression
Patients with depression having low energy state

questions.solution:
Patients with depression having a low energy state are at a relatively lower risk for suicide. 

Antidepressants like fluoxetine (serotonergic action) may increase the energy state of patients with suicidal depression. This permits the patient to act on preexisting suicidal impulses because they have more energy. Due to this possibility of an association between selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and suicidal attempts, the FDA has issued a black box warning regarding the use of SSRIs.

In patients recovering from suicidal depression as the depression lifts, the patients become ener­gized and, thus, are able to put their suicidal plans into action. This is known as paradoxical suicide.

Patients with a history of suicidal attempts in the past have a relatively high risk of attempting suicide. Patients with depression who suddenly appear with peacefulness should be suspected of having a secret decision to commit suicide.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man was posted for bronchoscopy under procedural sedation. After the administration of anesthetic drugs, he developed chest wall rigidity and ineffective spontaneous ventilation. Attempts at manual ventilation were unsuccessful due to the non-compliant chest wall. The opioid that is most commonly associated with this condition is?
questions.solution:
Chest wall rigidity and ineffective ventilation is a classic presentation of 'wooden chest syndrome'. This opioid-induced muscle rigidity is most commonly associated with the use of lipophilic opioids such as fentanyl and its congeners (alfentanil, sufentanil, and remifentanil).

Risk factors for wooden chest syndrome:

  • Rapid administration of a large dose of fentanyl
  • Concomitant use of nitrous oxide
  • Old age

The clinical presentation can vary from mild hoarseness to chest wall rigidity severe enough to prevent adequate bag-and-mask ventilation.

Management of wooden chest syndrome:

  • Discontinuation of the opioid
  • Replacement of the opioid with a non-lipophilic version (such as hydromorphone or morphine) for analgesia
  • Consider naloxone for reversal (you do not want to reverse analgesia on an intubated patient unless absolutely necessary)
  • Addition of a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker for paralysis
  • Supportive ventilatory care

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with complaints of fatigue and weakness. Pallor of the conjunctiva and pale skin are evident. Yellowing of the sclera is also seen. Abdominal examination shows splenomegaly. The image of the peripheral smear is given below. The urine urobilinogen levels in this patient will be ______
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the peripheral smear point to the diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis. The urine urobilinogen levels are increased in cases of hemolytic jaundice.

This patient's fatigue, weakness, pallor of the conjunctiva, and pale skin are indicative of anemia. Yellowing of sclera is indicative of jaundice and splenomegaly suggests that the of anemia is likely to be hemolytic. Further, the peripheral smear shows numerous spherocytes. These are red blood cells which appear abnormally small and lack the central pale area that is present in normal red blood cells. All these findings make hereditary spherocytosis the most likely diagnosis.

Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) causes hemolytic anemia due to a red cell membrane defect. The mode of inheritance of hereditary spherocytosis can be autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive (more severe). It can be caused by mutations of ankyrin and spectrin which are proteins found in membrane-cytoskeleton complex.

The diagnosis can be made with a positive family history, typical peripheral smear findings and some special tests. These include the osmotic fragility test, the acid glycerol lysis test, the eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test, and SDS-gel electrophoresis of membrane proteins. Sometimes a definitive diagnosis may require molecular studies for demonstrating specific gene mutations.

When the jaundice is secondary to hemolysis, there is increased production of bilirubin. This results in the increased production of urobilinogen in the intestine. This is reabsorbed into the blood and appears in increased amounts in the urine. The increased levels of urine urobilinogen and the absence of urine bilirubin is suggestive of hemolytic jaundice.

Related Pearl: Types of Jaundice

Type of jaundice Serum bilirubin Urine Urobilinogen Urine bilirubin
Pre-hepatic ↑ Indirect          ↑        -
Hepatic ↑ Direct and indirect   Normal/ ↓       +/-
Post-hepatic ↑ Direct          -        +

questions.text: A drug X is to be administered orally to a patient weighing 60 kg. The target plasma concentration is 15 mg/L, the apparent volume of distribution is 0.3 L/kg, and the bioavailability of drug X is 50%. Calculate the loading dose of X.
questions.solution:
The loading dose of drug X is 540 mg.

The loading dose is the amount or dose of a drug given to achieve target plasma concentration quickly when the treatment requires an immediate therapeutic response. It is usually given at the onset of therapy.

Loading Dose is given by the formula: 
Loading dose = (Cp x Vd )/ F

where, 

  • Cp is the target plasma concentration
  • Vd is the total volume of distribution, and
  • F is bioavailability.

In this case, the weight of the patient is 60 kg, and the apparent volume of distribution is 0.3 L/kg. Therefore Vd is:
Total volume of distribution (Vd) = apparent volume of distribution x weight = 0.3 x 60 
Therefore, Vd = 18 L

Target plasma concentration (Cp) = 15 mg/L
Bioavailability (F) = 50% = 0.50

On substituting the values in the given formula for the loading dose, we get:
Loading dose= (15 mg/L x 18 L) / 0.50 = 540 mg
